story:
After graduating from Acting Coach Scotland in 2018, Victoria J Valliere and Cecile Durel founded a small production company, Rove St. Productions, to create and produce meaningful new theatre. The biggest project of 2019 for Rove St. is an ambitious full run at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival of two original plays.

Hello? Hello. is a female driven play written by Victoria J Valliere that explores what unfolds when a young woman, calling a helpline in a moment of desperation, calls the wrong number and someone else picks up instead. A play dealing with mental health, societal restrictions, and childhood trauma. A poetic, stripped down celebration of the value of community and friendship, and the power of an individual to create change.  

Costume Design sketch for Hello? Hello.

There Is No Problem (Here) is a fast-paced comedy written by Cecile Durel dealing with individualism at the heart of a community. It is set up in a common room shared by infamous Disney characters that you haven't seen enough of before: including the Queen of Heart's cards from Wonderland, Aladdin's magical Carpet, and the cursed help from the Beast's castle. If you have ever wondered what Cogsworth is like off the clock, this is the show for you.

Costume Design sketch for There Is No Problem (Here)

The two shows will be performed alternatively at theSpace on North Bridge - in the Hilton Hotel - between August 2nd and August 24th at 17:30 every day. Every odd day you will have a chance to catch Hello? Hello. and every even day There Is No Problem (Here). (exception for previews) 

First read through of the plays with some very talented actresses

Previews: 

Hello? Hello. August 2nd, 17:30 at theSpace on North Bridge, Fife Theatre

There Is No Problem (Here) - August 3rd, 17:30 at theSpace on North Bridge, Fife Theatre

 

Victoria and Cecile are both incredibly passionate about the Fringe and these two plays. Rove St. is bringing together a group of talented and international actors and artists to make these shows possible and we all truly believe that with your help we will create something very special.

Looking forward to seeing you after the show,

Rove St. Productions

story:
The Story

On June 08, 2012, Mike Bratlie's light plane went off radar along the coast of Lake Superior. He is still missing.


Mike's daughter Carin Bratlie enlisted her brass quintet Mike's Brass, writer Ben Tallen, and choreographer Windy Bowlsby to collaborate in creating a live music/dance piece, High Flight, that traces the journey of friends and family members in the wake of ambiguous loss, and how we all, in a sense, live with ambiguity. This unique meditation on a true story is themed around John Gillespie Magee Jr.'s poem "High Flight."

Through dance, music, and spoken word it explores the question, "How do you deal with the loss of a loved one when the loved one is actually lost?"

  • Performances as part of the 2015 Minnesota Fringe Festival
  • A universal meditation on loss and renewal through the lens of a unique situation.

We need your support to make it happen.

What We Need & What You Get

It's no surprise to anyone that art costs money.

  • musicians
  • dancers
  • actors
  • festival fees
  • rehearsal space
  • printing
All money raised will go towards High Flight, even if we don't make our goal the project will still happen because we have built a flexible budget. If we make more than our goal we have plans in place.

Fixed Expenses: $1500 (fees, rehearsal space, printing, taxes)

Flexible Expenses: $2500 (stage manager, choreographer, writer, music director, musicians, dancers, actors, new portable stands)

Our goal: $4000

By joining us you are contributing to the uniqueness of this project, the longevity of Mike's Brass, and the honor of Mike Bratlie. You will be part of something special.


The Impact

This project is inspired by a specific story, but loss speaks to everyone. Losing a loved one is universal. We feel strongly that this story of ambiguous loss can make a difference in people's lives.

The artistic leadership on High Flight has a long history of successful theater production, both at the Fringe Festival and in the Twin Cities theater community.

    • Carin Bratlie - Artistic Director, Theatre Pro Rata. 15 years of production and direction experience, numerous successful Fringe shows.
    • Windy Bowlsby - Choreographer for the Fringe hits "Jumpin' Jack Kerouac," "Boogieography," and "Top Gun: The Musical".
    • Ben Tallen - Writer, Tedious Brief Productions, numerous successful Fringe shows.
Mike's Brass has played together for over 20 years, and brings a love of music to the project.  The dancers and actors have been hand selected because of their skill and passion for the project.  You are contributing to something with high artistic integrity and quality.

Risks & Challenges

We've already begun developing the script, rehearsing the music and dance, and planning the project.  

There are a lot of great shows at the Fringe Festival (over 150!) and sometimes it's hard to be heard in that sea of noise.  Your support helps expand the reach of this project so as many people as possible can experience it.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, there are other ways you can help!

  • Spread the word about 'High Flight.' Tell your Fringing friends! http://www.fringefestival.org/show/?id=20150117
  • Like Mike's Brass on Facebook. https://www.facebook.com/mikesbrass
  • Join the event page on Facebook.  https://www.facebook.com/events/933422403345209/

  • venue: The Illusion Theater.
    528 Hennepin Ave, 8th Floor.
    Minneapolis, MN 55403.

    performance dates:
    7/30/15 8:30 PM
    8/2/15 5:30 PM
    8/4/15 10:00 PM
    8/6/15 7:00 PM
    8/8/15 4:00 PM

    Part of Minnesota Fringe Festival, 
    July 30- August 9, 2015.
    Tickets $14 + $4 admission button; save with multi-show passes
    Tickets at fringefestival.org, coming soon!

Thank you for your support!

story:
THE PAST
The disorder In August 2011, across the cities in England has shown that most youths of today place little or no value on life as several homes, offices and companies were destroyed and lives of innocent citizens were lost and several shops looted.

THE PRESENT
There is a total loss of cultural and social values in different communities and ethnic groups and a void has been created between the youths and adults in various communities.

THE FUTURE
We believe in the benefits of musicals and efficacy of theatrical arts to transform lives of young people, close these voids and serve as a bridge from the youth to society.

When art programmes are instituted and young people are offered an alternative to social ills, healthy communities are created, crime, drugs, unplanned pregnancies and school dropout rates are lowered.

We endeavour to produce pertinent art programmes to benefit families, communities and others who are struggling with new ways to combat the problem of juvenile social adjustments.

We Are
Theatre, the Stage brought to You!
Music, in its subtleness to your Soul
Dance in its Suppleness for your entertainment
Drama, a way of Life!
We are TMD SQUARED 

AND WE NEED YOUR HELP!

As part of our mission to project African cultural heritage  and also to engage the youths in the United Kingdom, we are planning to present a major Stage play Musical titled 'The gods are not to blame'.

This published book is a classic tragedy written by Ola Rotimi (Late). It is a post-colonial interpretation of Sophocles Oedipus Rex within the context of African culture. Although this play has been presented several times all over the world, this is the very first time it will be presented as a Musical full of glamour, music and dance with original composed songs from the roots of Africa.

We will be having our first presentation of this Musical in London on the 17th, 18th and 19th of September 2015 after which we will be taking it on a tour of the United Kingdom.

To make this dream a reality, we need to raise £75,000 pounds to enable us cover our production cost and expenses which includes cast fees, set design, accommodation, costumes, organising workshops and all.

We invite you to join us in this journey by sponsoring this project, as we project Africa to the world. We also have a theatre workshop  along-side tagged ''The 4Es'' where we engage, educate, enlighten and entertain youths in the community to create a better tomorrow and keep them off the streets and out of mischief.

We promise to also keep you posted all through the way from casting till the final day of presentation and keep you informed of our activities as we take this play on  a tour of the United Kingdom. Support us today and help project Africa to the world



MEET THE TEAM

             


OLUGBENGA AJAYI (Director/Co-Ordinator)

TMD Squared was born, out of the creative womb of Olugbenga Ajayi. He graduated as a Cinema Director, /Line and Feature Film Producer from the Hollywood Film Institute and worked tirelessly as a Theatre/Film director. He has featured in several productions like 'Who is afraid of Soyinka, 'The gods are not to blame', 'Sweet Sixteen', 'Josiah my Love' and many more.  He also helped birth plays like 'Moremi', 'The lion and the jewel', 'The devil is a woman. Some of the  plays written by him includes 'Darkness Within', 'Tango with the gods' , 'Fadekemi' (an African adaptation of Cinderella) and 'Temptation'. 

Funmi Ogunwo-Adesanya (Executive Producer)

Funmi is a producer with a passion for the arts and a stellar vocalist. She bagged a Masters degree in Film Making, cinematography and Post Production at the University of Greenwich U.K. She is an advocate for positive change in the UK theatre and has produced notable plays and short films including 'Jand Hustle' which won the award for Best Experimental Film at the 10th African International Film Festival, 2013 and was also nominated as 'Best Movie-Comedy' at the Africa Magic Viewers' Choice Awards (AMVCA) 2015. Other films she produced includes 'The Arrangers' and a comedy series coming soon to TV stations across the UK titled 'London Boy'. She also worked on the BAFTA award winning U.K documentary 'Welcome to Lagos'

Andrew McPherson (Assistant Director)

Andrew McPherson is an actor, director, facilitator and playwright benefiting from over eight years of professional experience all across the UK. Alongside many freelance projects, Andrew is the Founding Director of Faceache Theatre Company where he directs grassroots experimental work that tests the medium of theatre and challenges the audience. Andrew has an incredible eye for detail and an exercised aptitude for encouraging actors to always deliver their best.

In his own words;                                                                                                                         "This performance stands to awaken British audiences to Africa's true nature. It is time to shift our thinking of this fine continent and start celebrating its glamour, cultural richness and power."

Ola Ajayi  (Research Analyst/Vocalist)

Ola  has a background in market research and analysis.  She is a seasoned actress, vocalist and entertainer. She studied Creative Arts at the University of Lagos, Nigeria and featured in 'Alaafin Kanran', 'The Lion and the Jewel' and 'Darkness Within'. Armed with her creativity and passion for the happiness of children, she founded 'Ola Part', a Party Planning and Entertainment Company for kids in the UK where she works as a consultant.

In her own words                                                                                                                ''A very creative director , an inspirational script and a formidable team.....this is set to blow your mind''

Daniela Fleckenstein (Operations Manger)

Daniela  graduated with a degree in Photography and has ever since passionately explored the world of art and photography with particular interest in people and  culture. She has had serveral exhibitions of her paintings and fermented her ambition for people by working as development & outreach worker in the philanthropic sector,

She also worked as a certified life coach, coaching private clients and taking on managerial duties, but her longing to be in the creatives inspired her to set up a freelance career predominantly in photography and also as a supporting artist in TV & Film. (www.danielafleckenstein.com)

In her own words                                                                                                        ''Being a member of a team and being of support in a very aspiring, organised and creative project drew me to work in this Production''


YOUR SUPPORT WILL HELP COVER THE FOLLOWING EXPENSES

Cast Fees
Food And Refreshment
Costumes
Set design
Administration
Venue Hire
Rehearsal Space Hire
Accommodation
Transportation
Media Coverage(photos & videos)
Printing
Publicity
Insurance
legal fees

                                 

                                 


               PERKS

               


Other ways you can please help are;

Share this campaign

Like our Facebook page! 

Follow us on Twitter tmdsquared.com

Check out our Website: www.tmdsquared.com

story:
The storyline is set in the year 2050 when the nations of the world have jointly overcome the major challenges facing humanity: pulling the planet back from the brink it nearly toppled over due to regional conflict worldwide; environmental issues, overconsumption, school violence, intercultural misunderstanding, and conflict over natural resources such as water and fossil fuels. This musical gives young people a chance to have a voice in changes that can help create the world in which they want to live!

The international cast is comprised of 20-25 young performers from around the world and will be backed up by a chorus of 100 local children.

This play changes lives. It empowers kids to make a difference in their world. It provides kids from very different backgrounds a chance to work together to solve problems. It has been performed all over the world (Russia, Ukraine, South Africa, Northern Ireland, Jordan, England, Japan, Bulgaria, and many more countries), and now will be produced in Thousand Oaks.

“Peace Child” is a musical play, a curriculum, a movement, and a passion. It is a strategy for cultural change that works. Here’s how:

The original story was set in the future. The play looks back to the 1980s and tells of an American boy and a Russian girl who meet in Washington DC, where their parents are diplomats. Initially, they express distrust of each other; later, they realize they are equally frightened of fighting each other in a nuclear war.

Determined to “do something,” they slip unannounced onto a TV talk show, express their wish for peace, become media celebrities, and finally get invited to meet with their presidents.

The heart of the play is in the dialogues with their two presidents where the children get a sense of the magnitude of the problems, and the presidents see in the innocent trusting of the children perhaps a way that points towards world peace.

The end of the story sees the two presidents going off on a fishing trip, determined to get to know each other better. Or, it ends some other way, because the script is just a starting point. David Woollcombe must be one of the few playwrights in history who actively encourages kids to rip up his text and re-write it in their own words.

“I hate acting; nothing offends me more than to see smart-as little kids reciting other people’s words with ghastly inflections and poses.” - D.W.

Children need to be honored and respected as equals, not coddled as an exalted kind of domestic pet. We love kids to be real on stage, and the best way of making them real is to have the kids write their own lines within the framework of an existing play. We encourage them to do this through a process of background reading, research, discussion, and joint analysis followed by staged improvisations.

From all this, the writers go away and write up the scenes. In this way, each child who is in the play knows that he/she has helped to create it. The kids are empowered to believe that they could become the children of the story, and that they could bring peace to the world.

They have explored their own inner resources and, in most cases, found that they have some views on the crucial question of survival. Expressing those views on stage gives them great confidence, makes them want to explore more. The artists, everyone, must dare to stir up the spirit of rebelliousness in young people. Make them angry, make them see that the survival of this great country and of the planet is at stake. Make them recognize the terror, and then give them enough love to enable them to overcome it.

Empowerment is the name of the game. Give them the feeling of their own power and then teach them the means to powerfully express it. We adults always have to keep our aspirations one step ahead of theirs. We have to dare to be wrong, dare to be great; dare to fail - dare to hope! We must dare to rejoice in a future that is by no means guaranteed, but one that guarantees survival. It is important to share with our kids the generosity and idealism that lurks so close to the surface of this wonderful country.

Please give generously. Your donations will enlighten a new generation. Thank you for your support.

Dr. Stacey McEnnan, founder and director of education at the Alexandria Academy for gifted children is the play's producer. The play, entitled “Peace Child 2015-We Create Our Future,” will be showing at the Thousand Oaks Civic Arts Plaza in Thousand Oaks, California USA on August 28th, and 29th, 2015.

Make them angry, make them see that the survival of this great country and of the planet is at stake. Make them recognize the terror, and then give them enough love to enable them to overcome it. Empowerment is the name of the game. Give them the feeling of their own power and then teach them the means to powerfully express it. We adults always have to keep our aspirations one step ahead of theirs. We have to dare to be wrong, dare to be great; dare to fail - dare to hope! We must dare to rejoice in a future that is by no means guaranteed, but one that guarantees survival. It is important to share with our kids the generosity and idealism that lurks so close to the surface of this wonderful country.Please give generously. Your donations will enlighten a new generation. Thank you for your support.Dr. Stacey McEnnan, founder and director of education at the Alexandria Academy for gifted children is the play's producer. The play, entitled “Peace Child 2015-We Create Our Future,” will be showing at the Thousand Oaks Civic Arts Plaza in Thousand Oaks, California USA on August 28th, and 29th, 2015.

story:
Summary

What is Endometriosis?

Endometriosis is a chronic disease affecting 176 million women worldwide and 1 in 10 girls and women in the U.S. It is present when tissue similar to that of the lining of the uterus is found in other parts of the body, often causing chronic, severe pain and complications such as cysts and infertility. There is no confirmed cause or cure, and many women go undiagnosed for years, being told it’s “all in your head” or just a “bad period.”

What is ENDOME?

I was diagnosed with endometriosis 10 years ago. As a poet, I took to exploring my symptoms and medical treatment through writing. Seven years later I ended up with a long poetic manuscript that had led me on a deep, transformative psychological journey. Yet I still felt my work was unfinished. I had a strong desire to share my experience with others and to raise awareness for this insidious yet often unacknowledged disease, so I teamed up with visual and video artists, musicians, actors, and an amazing director to make an experimental multimedia performance for the Philadelphia Fringe Festival, to be staged at the Sedgwick Theater on September 11, 12, and 13, 2015.

ENDOME infuses medical records and surgery reports with memories, songs, and dreams and examines boundaries and bonds between patient and physician, psyche and soma, and art and science. $5 of each ticket sold will be donated to the Endometriosis Foundation of America, an organization dedicated to increasing recognition of the disease as well as providing advocacy, facilitating expert surgical training, and funding landmark research.

What will your donation fund?

  • Theatre rental
  • AV equipment rental
  • Fringe registration and fees
  • Stipends for the actors, director, and artists involved

About ENDOME's writer:

Holly Bittner is Director of Writing and Assistant Professor of English and Creative Writing at Moore College of Art & Design. She has presented various short excerpts of her ENDOME manuscript recently at the following events:

  • Widening the Cycle, a group art exhibition in conjunction with the 21st Biennial Conference of the Society for Menstrual Cycle Research, Boston, MA, June 2015
  • Society for Science, Literature, and the Arts conference, Dallas, TX, October 2014
  • “Identity · Memory · Testimony” multi-disciplinary conference hosted by the Maine Women Writers Collection and Maine Women’s Studies Consortium, University of New England, Portland, ME, March 2012
  • “A Celebration of the Poetry and Criticism of Rachel Blau DuPlessis,” Temple University, October 2011
  • Practice + Process: 2010 Faculty Triennial Exhibition, Moore College of Art & Design, Philadelphia, PA, October 2010 (with designer Heather Ujiie)

The Impact

Whether or not they have "endo," many people experience the suffering and isolation that a medical condition can bring. It is my hope that this performance will not only result in greater awareness of a specific disease but offer emotional support for those with any physical illness and related mental anguish. I hope to show through ENDOME that physical symptoms can be an invitation to psychological healing and even social and spiritual community. Your donation is instrumental in this important effort. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Apart from financial contributions, you can help in other ways that are just as valuable! We are in need of:

  • Volunteers to help with show preparation, as well as stagehands and "techies." 
  • Help with publicity! Share this campaign through your social networks and tell others about the show. Spread the word and help endometriosis get heard!

story:
Hi Everyone!  Thank you for visiting our page and giving us an opportunity to tell you more about us and how you can help us find a dance home! 

Nickelz Production was started in Falls Church, VA last year with a goal to provide dance classes, performance and choreography services to the greater DC area.  To get started we rented studio space from a small latin dance studio. It was a great first step to start the company off, familiarize ourselves with the community and our customer base.  Our first class had just two people in it and as the company has grown we have had over 300 dancers come through our drop in classes, we have a performance company of 9 principle dancers that have performed at the Washington DC Cherry Blossom Festival, have been cast in commercials, and volunteered at after school programs and charity events.  

We have had an award winning kids hip hop dance team and we have provided choreography services for up and coming artists and wedding couples for their big day!  Although we are making great progress we have had some challenges with establishing a permanent dance home for our dance company.  The latin studio where we initial rented space was no longer able to rent to our dance company due to scheduling conflicts and the current studio where we rent has limited availability for classes.  Being at the whim of another studio and constantly changing addresses impedes our ability to grow as a company and establish our own brand and identity which detracts from the art of dance.  We are asking for your contribution to help us raise money to lease and renovate our own studio space that we can call home!  

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need: 

  • $2,500 to install mirrors for the dance studio space
  • $2,500 to install dance flooring (absorbs shock and prevents dancer injuries)
  • $2,000 to install speakers/sound system and sound insulating materials
  • $5,000 for point of sales equipment, office supplies, signage and working capital for the studio

The Impact

One thing that we've realized in the past year is the impact that dance has on people.

  • We have helped young dancers gain confidence and a sense of accomplishment
  • We have helped adults become part of a dance community that is supportive, healthy, friendly and encouraging.
  • And we've helped create several special memories in our clients whether it was making their wedding day, birthday or their evening after work a little bit brighter.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge in finding a dance home is finding a space that caters to the unique needs of a dance studio.  It needs to be in a space that allows for the sound of music playing, have an open floor layout with high ceilings for jumping and available parking.  This has been a challenge to find but we have located a space that we feel would be a perfect fit if we can raise enough money before it is leased by another tenant.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute but looking for another way you can help?

  • Share our campaign with friends and family!
  • Become a Nickelz Production volunteer - we are always looking for volunteers to help us at our annual showcase and special events throughout the year!

story:
I started The DC Music Theatre Workshop to bring exciting new music theatre works to DC, and there's nothing that excites me more than Family Portrait, by Theo Jamieson.

It's a brilliant musical that's never been performed in the US. It's a virtuosic piece that combines stylistic elements of Stephen Sondheim, Adam Guettel, and Jason Robert Brown, but is entirely Theo Jamieson. I've honestly never heard anything quite like it. It's almost unbelievable that Theo wrote it when he was in his early 20s, while an undergraduate at Trinity College of Music, and it's even more unbelievable that in addition to writing the music, he also wrote the lyrics. And orchestrated it. And played the piano in the original performance.

Speaking of the original performance, it can be viewed in it's entirety on YouTube here: Family Portrait.

The cast of our Family Portrait includes some familiar faces to the DC theatre scene as well as some incredible up and coming talents: Harv Lester and Katie McManus as Sam and Mary, the parents, and Kristin Cardinal, Madeline Cuddihy, and RJ Pavel as their children, Elly, Jo, and Tom. 

The DC Music Theatre Workshop's home is Lincoln Temple UCC, a beautiful church in the historic Logan Circle/Shaw neighborhood of Northwest Washington DC. Lincoln Temple has a strong musical history and has hosted such internationally important artists as Roland Hayes and Leontyne Price in recitals. We are so proud and honored to continue this tradition and bring high quality (and affordable) performances to the neighborhood.

All performances at the DC Music Theatre Workshop will be pay what you can. Your donations will help bring theatre to people who wouldn't normally be able to afford it.

There are many other interesting new works that we plan on bringing to DC, and your generous support will help us become a new voice in DC Theatre.

Thank you so much for your support,
Zach Roberts
Director of Family Portrait and founder of the DC Music Theatre Workshop

story:
HELP THIS SHOW GO ABROAD!

Hi Everybody!

I'm raising funds for my solo show which is headed to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in just over 1 week. I've raised about $3,000 on my own so far; however, there is still a lot more I need to cover so I need your help! This  campaign will run for just 2 weeks, so if you know you want to contribute, please consider donating sooner rather than later!

Reclaiming Vietnam is an auto-biographical solo piece for theater that I wrote and perform in. It's a 60-min show that interweaves themes of culture, identity, self-hatred and rejection of identity. This is a very personal story based on my own experience of childhood sexual abuse. Although the premise seems heavy, the play is rich with humor, joy and holds within it an enormous capacity for healing. I believe the show has the power to change a person's life and this is a big part of the reason why I believe exposure to an international audience is important. Over the last 2 years, Reclaiming Vietnam has been gaining momentum with performances in New York City and now, the show is ready to premier at the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland, where it has the opportunity to receive the attention it deserves.

“A knock out artistic achievement. The explosions of truth, pain, and redemption in Kim Chinh’s autobiographical Reclaiming Vietnam, are gracefully revealed with personal joy and ultimate empowerment. I was surprised each step of the way. After my outrage, tears, and laughter, I emerged, heart heavy and full of love and hope.”

– Alice Cox (NYC director and filmmaker)

SYNOPSIS

After rejecting her Vietnamese identity, a woman travels to her father's birthplace. As she discovers the beauty of her roots, she is forced to combat the demons of her past.

PRODUCTION BUDGET

I'll be presenting 2 weeks of performances in a 70-seat theatre at Greenside Venues in Edinburgh starting on August 17th, 2015 and ending August 29th, 2015. The budget of $10,000 covers the expenses of program fees, travel, space rental  & set, technical team, performer's insurance, rehearsals, photos, video recording, media relations consulting and printing services, as well as publicizing and mounting the 12-day engagement. The breakdown can be seen below:

 

MORE EXPOSURE!

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is not only the largest theatre festival in the world, it is also the longest-running theatre festival, begun in 1947. The Edinburgh Fringe draws audiences and press from all over the globe. Thus, a participant in the festival may receive reviews from a variety of sources, get exposure to international spectators and even be invited to perform at future venues who are looking for programming on a worldwide level. Reclaiming Vietnam has been in its infant stages, and is now ready for critics’ reviews and for its subject matter to hold the eye of the media. Your gift will insure that the 1st international production of Reclaiming Vietnam has the promotional support that it needs at this crucial stage of the play’s development. 

FISCAL SPONSOR - FRACTURED ATLAS

Reclaiming Vietnam is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non‐profit arts service organization through which we can accept grants and tax deductible donations.

Any amount you are able to give is deeply appreciated! And if you can forward, repost, retweet, etc, this campaign link, that would be of enormous help. Here is text to use if you want to simply cut and paste:

TEXT TO CUT & PASTE:

FACEBOOK: Reclaiming Vietnam is going to Edinburgh! Help this important show about healing one's past to have the best run possible! http://bit.ly/1DqoWaS

TWITTER: Help #ReclaimingVietnam get to Edinburgh! http://bit.ly/1DqoWaS

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can't contribute financially, there are plenty of other things you can do to move this project forward:

  • Come see the show, and bring friends! (Especially if you live in Scotland!)
  • Share the indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and by email!
  • Like Reclaiming Vietnam on Facebook!
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

Share the indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and by email!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
2015 marks the 7th anniversary of Hartel Dance Group in Oklahoma City, and Austin Hartel  is ready to fulfill the second of his two productions to celebrate this anniversary in our great city.  

Hartel Dance Group presents "Retrospective",  a compilation of works by artistic Director Austin Hartel, showing the development of his choreography over the years.   With a fresh group of dancers coming from Oklahoma, Brasil and Paraguay, we will have the chance to see some of the best pieces by Hartel. Also this Season will realize Austin's long time project of creating a documentary film of his dances and creative process. 

 In May, we were able to be a part of the Orlando International Fringe Festival, which is the oldest fringe festival in the United States, selected from a pool of over 200 national and international acts and won the  Audience Choice Award for BEST DANCE COMPANY OF THE FRINGE. This was a great opportunity to produce our show "What's Love got to Do with IT"  for national and international audiences, showing them  what the performing arts are all about in Oklahoma City. 


HDG has achieved it mission, providing accessible dance experiences nationally and internationally through the generosity of family, friends, and patrons.  Our company needs your support right to make this 2015 Season "Retrospective" possible. A tax-deductible donation of any amount will bring us closer to our goal!


HDG must raise $2,000 to cover operational costs associated with the production of this 2015 Season at Oklahoma Contemporary. (Studio Rentals, living  expenses for the guest artists, equipment rental and video production cost)

Austin Hartel has invited 4 dancers to be a part of this production, 2 from Brasil that attended the Seminario Internacional de Danza de Brasilia 2015 and and 2 from Paraguay that attended the Concurso Nacional de Danza, where Austin was part of the jury . These are young dancers  eager to learn and with so much to offer to the creative process. The language of dance is universal, knows no barriers and the opportunity to be a part of this production and this cultural exchange is a life changing event for these dancers, as well as giving our local dancers the chance of experience a culturally diverse working environment.

.  

Q: If you are selling tickets to the performance why do you need to raise money outside of the Box Office?

A: Ticket Sales typically cover a very small percentage of production costs for most performing arts organizations. HDG relies on contributions from private donors to be able to produce affordable performances for the public.


Q: How long does it take to create a performance like this?

A: For this season: Hartel Dance Group rehearses 8-12 hours a week for 5 weeks while learning the repertoire. Besides his job as an Associate Professor and Coordinator of Modern Dance at the University of Oklahoma, Austin Hartel also works independently with composers, designers and visual artists to integrate additional art mediums into his creations.


Help spread the word about Hartel Dance Group and our campaign on Facebook and/or email your friends. The bigger our reach, the bigger our impact.

story:
Short Summary

GUT REACTION (EXPERI - MENTAL THEATRE) Thanks you for your on-going support to the project! GUT REACTION is an English expression that indicates a reaction to a situation derived by a person's instinct and experience. MARCO RIVAGLI and GIULIA MANDELLI, both established professionals in their own artistic field, after many previous collaborations, give birth to the Gut Reaction at the beginning of 2015. The unique style that characterizes them, leads the audience on a journey into the most improbable imaginaries through an investigation where theatre, body movement, music and rhythm collide.

http://www.facebook.com/gutreactiontheatre

SHOW CURRENTLY ACTIVE:

4MOODS is a pièce inspired by the book “The Curious incident of the dog in the night time” written by Mark Haddon. 

The show is a personal interpretation of the story; the concepts led the duo in the composition of the scenes and the music dramaturgy.

The book is written from the perspective of a 14 year old boy with Asperger's syndrome (a form of autism) that, becoming a "detective" in the hunt for the murderer of a dog, is conducting an investigation in a personal growth and realization. The author doesn't focus on the problems of autism, but on the reality seen with those eyes. Likewise the Gut Reaction decided to live the stage. Using the expressive language of the body and rhythm,a series of seemingly disconnected situations are proposed with the aim to evoke the most varied, personal and unexpected images in the mind of the audience. The pièce is now often performed live also with the participation of Emanuel Victor (Argentinian) and the live painter Merav Leibkuechler (Israel/Germany). 

REFERENCES:

Portrait on RBB (TV – Berlin): http://goo.gl/EjngZv

First video of Gut Reaction: https://goo.gl/2X1GlI

Video interview for 12alle12: https://goo.gl/Nh2v1C

Article “La Voce” 1: https://goo.gl/40f2xo

Article “La Voce” 2: https://goo.gl/Nf59DT

Video interview on TV (Rete Canavese): https://goo.gl/UKJOdv

Article “La Sentinella”: http://goo.gl/I1T8dX

Article “Il Giornale Di Sicilia”: https://goo.gl/UQc23C

Article “Detto fra Noi”: http://goo.gl/1l2uSy

Interview “Il Mitte”: http://goo.gl/rsFLZM

Article “Il Nuovo Torrazzo”: https://goo.gl/pV5ZlO


What We Need & What You Get

The Universität der Künste Berlin, UdK (Berlin University of the Arts), situated in Berlin, Germany, is the largest art school in Europe. We have been invited to represent the arts of Germany in China through their long lasting partnership from Nov 26th until Dec 3rd in a very big cultural festival on the beautiful island of Hainan! Everything in China is covered, from hotels to local transport and exhibitions. What remains to make this fantastic opportunity come true is the coverage of the flights, Visa, rehearsal, costumes and instrumentation. The budget needed it's not huge and we are sure that with your precious support we can make this happen for real! Plus we have many many things planned for the future... and we would love you to be totally involved in them! We believe in the power of exchanging, where you and us work on a common goal. We are truly honored for the invitation already. Let's try to make it unforgettable, unique and REAL... GUT REACTION go international, thanks to you. Marco & Giulia 

Risks & Challenges

For what regard the China opportunity we are supported by U.D.K (http://www.udk-berlin.de/sites/content/themen/a...) through Fiake e.V. (http://www.fiake.org/). Everything is very well organized and luckily enough once the budget goal has been reached the project will become a reality. By funding this project, even in the remote possibility that China will not happen, you will always be sure the funds will allow the creation of something special, buying of instrumentation and tons of hours of research in the rehearsal space to donate you an always growing and unforgettable performance! Non mainstream projects like this need constant support to stay alive, research new ideas and tools of expression, pay collaborators and guests, and so forth. At the moment we are working on the creation of a new pièce called Whole-Blinded. We could have never made it without you and that is why our thank will never be enough! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any kind of support is truly appreciated! Word of mouth! x
story_txt:
Short Summary GUT REACTION (EXPERI - MENTAL THEATRE) Thanks you for your on-going support to the project! GUT REACTION is an English expression that indicates a reaction to a situation derived by a person's instinct and experience. MARCO RIVAGLI and GIULIA MANDELLI, both established professionals in their own artistic field, after many previous collaborations, give birth to the Gut Reaction at the beginning of 2015. The unique style that characterizes them, leads the audience on a journey into the most improbable imaginaries through an investigation where theatre, body movement, music and rhythm collide.
http://www.facebook.com/gutreactiontheatre

SHOW
CURRENTLY ACTIVE:

4MOODS is
a pièce inspired by the book “The Curious incident of the dog in
the night time” written by Mark Haddon. 

The
show is a personal interpretation of the story; the concepts led the
duo in the composition of the scenes and the music dramaturgy.



The
book is written from the perspective of a 14 year old boy with
Asperger's syndrome (a form of autism) that, becoming a "detective"
in the hunt for the murderer of a dog, is conducting an investigation
in a personal growth and realization. The author doesn't focus on the
problems of autism, but on the reality seen with those eyes. Likewise
the Gut Reaction decided to live the stage. Using the expressive
language of the body and rhythm,a series of seemingly disconnected
situations are proposed with the aim to evoke the most varied,
personal and unexpected images in the mind of the audience. The pièce
is now often performed live also with the participation of Emanuel
Victor (Argentinian) and the live painter Merav Leibkuechler
(Israel/Germany). 


REFERENCES:


Portrait
on RBB (TV – Berlin): http://goo.gl/EjngZv



First
video of Gut Reaction: https://goo.gl/2X1GlI



Video
interview for 12alle12: https://goo.gl/Nh2v1C

story:
A True Story of When Pigs Fly!

Welcome to the launching pad of our new musical - Oink!  After two years of collaboration and almost 20 years in the making, we are thrilled to be on the brink of bringing this brilliant, touching, clever musical to the stage!  

Here's a little background:

The book and lyrics for Oink! were written almost 20 years ago by Deb Hollander, along with another full musical and several children's books.  They were neatly tucked away and not brought out again until Deb, who by then had been diagnosed with a progressive disease, was too ill to keep working.   In 2013, she showed them to Jen Rodgers, who loved them immediately!  Jen brought the musical to her professional network, including dear friend and composer, Clif Hardin.  Clif was just as excited about the material and, besides, he had just had a conversation with his dog, Piper, wondering if he would ever have the chance to branch out into musical theater.  (Literally, a week before Jen showed up with the script!)

We three got to work.  Clif wrote a beautiful, intricate, exciting score, and we performed a staged reading of our first completed draft about a year ago.  It received a "leaping ovation" and we were off!  Over this past year the show developed in big leaps and bounds with some new songs and plot twists, a new name, and an insanely talented creative team that came on board with us. 

We've worked hard to have something to bring to the stage and to Deb, and we have done it!  Read on to learn what we plan to do and how this campaign will get us there!

Prepare for Take-off!

This Indie GoGo campaign is timed to culminate in three semi-staged performances of Oink!   They will take place at the Black Box Theatre of Silver Spring on October 17-18, and we hope you will come!

These performances are the pre-cursors to both taking the show to festival performances in 2016, and introducing it to theaters across the country, in the hopes of finding a company to fully conceive it.  We have thrown our hearts and talents into it full force and fronted the funding thus far, and now we need help to take it to these next levels.

To do all of this, we really need $15,000.  

$5,000 of that amount covers the development of the show thus far - our demo recordings, website and the expenses of the first staged reading.

$5,000 more covers the cost of the semi-staged production in October - the rental of a proper theater and the basic travel expenses of our actors (from New York and DC).

That makes up the $10,000 that is our funding goal for this campaign.  (Asking for the whole hog just felt a little too piggy!)  If we raise more than our goal, here's what happens:

$5,000 more allows us to fully produce the show for the 2016 Capital Fringe Festival including sets, costumes, props and the registration fee.

After that, your generous help allows us to cover the costs of getting this show in front of theater presenters across the country.

And finally, as we approach Pigs in Space levels of funding, we'll be able to dive into Deb's second musical, "Out of the Blue,"  which we love just as much!   

If we don't reach these funding goals, we'll keep going as any good starving artists do!  We'll sing and dance in front of any audience, put out the hat, and volunteer our time.  Every dollar you give will go towards making this dream and Deb's legacy come into being.

Pig Perks

We hope our Pig Perks pique your interest!  There are everything from OINKalades for your walls to singing Pig-a-Grams, reserved seats, private receptions, and even an opportunity to help steer this project to success.  Our favorite so far...the two $100 level "Miss Piggy Special" Perks.  Choose from heads or tails for a custom OINK hat or a pig-tail tumbler:

We're also working on the T-Shirt that has a pig-tail on the back.  

Remember that  the funds you give are going to a verified non-profit - that means they are tax deductible!  If there's a perk you'd like and don't see - let us know!  We'd like to make you as happy as a pig in clover!  So go ahead...dream pig!  And tell us about it!  

Pipe Dream or Pig Dream?

The world of theatre is full of dreamers - creators and performers who go all-in on stories that capture their hearts, and theater-goers who want their heart to be captured.  Yes, we have a story here that we believe is all-in worthy!  And, more than that, we have a team that can make it happen.  And that takes us from pipe dream to pig dream.  

All of us are not only seasoned musicians and actors with plenty of creds, we also have the behind-the-scenes skills and experience.  We have worked at the national level in our fields and we have created successful products with full marketing campaigns, fully-realized budgets and full houses.  We have managed fund-raising campaigns, conceived and directed productions with large casts and large technical requirements, started arts-based businesses, and have reputations that precede us.  We support each other, we move fast, and we tap our networks with great discretion.  We don't cry wolf!  (Well, there is plenty of crying wolf in this particular production...but it stays on stage!)

We only get serious when there is something to be serious about.  This little show is asking for all of the skills, heart, and experience we have.   We're sure it will challenge us for more as we go along.  And we are seriously ready to give!  

I Would Send the Pigs to the Moon, But...

Are you inspired but not as able to pig out on perks as you'd like?  We hear you!!  And if you've heard us - please make some noise for this little show.  Squeal about it to your friends, use your Facebook family, check out the Indiegogo share tools, and come see the show in October and beyond!   

 Learn more and follow our progress at www.oinkapigsical.com

story:
What’s The Deal?

Every year, Shakespeare-in-Hospitals tours to hospitals, community centres, shelters, and mental health facilities to perform scenes, monologues, and facilitate dialogue.  Featuring an ensemble of some of Toronto's hottest emerging talent, indie Shakespeare directors and producers our goal is to bring Shakespeare to the people who need it most, right by their bedside.

THAT SOUNDS AWESOME! WHAT CAN I DO?

For our tour to be a success we need your help!

1) Financial Assistance: We are fully committed to paying our actors, directors, and crew for their time, effort, and talent - every dollar you donate will go straight to the team!

2) Word of Mouth: Can't help out financially? No worries! Our unique program appeals to a whole variety of people, a bunch of whom we haven't even met yet!  Help us out by spreading the word about the project and the Indiegogo campaign.  You know an eccentric billionaire who likes to fund Shakespeare, Hospitals, and Tours?  Send her our way! (Unless it's Donald Trump.  You can keep him.)

If you're able to donate, we'll even kick in some crazy, one-of-a-kind performances for you. The more you donate, the more crazy stuff we will do to thank you! Get a home-made youtube sonnet, or go for the gusto with some of our sonnet bloopers! Check out the perks for more information.

Neat! Now tell me more about the Shakespeare-In-Hospitals Project!

The Shakespeare-In-Hospitals Project engages members of the health-care sector of Toronto who are in healing or transitional processes. It provides psychosocial support in health-care facilities and communities facing high turnover rates and isolation to increase flexible communication and seamless patient/client care. Classical and modern theatre practice is employed with discussion, interactive exploration, and performance as tools to break down physical, economic, and social barriers in these locales.

The SiH Project is founded off of 3 Principles:

Relief:

Often people in hospitals, retirement homes and hospices are restricted to a bed or a floor or a ward. We offer a distraction from their healing and transitional processes, to bring them out of their situation and into one that they can control and interact with by using clown-tactics in our interactive scenes and telling them stories and sonnets that they can either relate to or escape into.

Accessibility:

While most hospitals have recreational therapy programming, accessibility is always an issue, and the amount of interaction patients or clients can receive in these programs is constantly fluctuating based on their conditions. 

We provide scenes, monologues, and choral pieces for performances and interactions by performing in various mediums including: Private Room (or One-on-One) Format, Open-Space Format, and Staged Format. This allows us to tailor performances to any environment or location for any patient or client regardless of their condition. 

Community Engagement:

Communities exist in hospitals too! Whether it is among patients, their families, or the staff. It is easy to forget this when focusing on treatment, or transitioning back into everyday life. When patients engage with their hospital/health care facility’s community, they provide themselves with more opportunities to emotionally cope with the treatment they are receiving. SiH further supports this dynamic by giving a new and innovative way to interact and bond with their community, even if it is only for a short time and allow them to have a uniquley positive experience during their stay

This year we are also extending the artistic conversation to engage both members of the Health Care and Arts Sectors by showcasing the project at three different venues throughout the process. Throughout these showcases, we will be sharing our own stories and experiences, and facilitating a creative discussion among the involved communities to encourage further future interaction beyond the program.

Previous facilities have included:

CAMH

Toronto Western Hospital

Toronto General Hospital

Sunnybrook Health Centre

Tapestry at Village Gate West

Princess Margaret Hospital Lodge

Sick Kids Hospital

Lord Dufferin Senior’s Centre

Adelaide Women’s Resource Centre

Hospice Dufferin

Matthew’s House Hospice

Cedarbrook Lodge

Mt. Sinai Hospital

Previous units have included:

Pediatrics

Oncology

Acute Care

Geriatrics

Lobbies

Mental Health Inpatient

Mental Health Outpatient

Veteran’s Centres

Waiting Rooms

Cafeterias

Pre-Op

Post-Op

Front Foyers

You can learn more about the Shakespeare-In-Hospitals Project and the Spur-Of-The-Moment Shakespeare Collective at: 

www.spurofthemomentshakespeare.weebly.com

Can't donate through our Indiegogo? Still want to support? Check out:

1) Don't want to donate online? Email shakespur@gmail.com with "DONATION/SPONSORSHIP REQUEST" in the subject heading.

2) Share the campaign on your profile and join our facebook page! 

3) Tweet the campaign with the hashtag #ShakeHospitals and follow us on twitter!

4) In Toronto? Come to our end of year show in December!

5) Send this along to friends and family! 

6) Follow our blog or tweet our website!

And thanks for reading all the way to the bottom.  Simply by reading this text, you've committed your time and attention to our project and that matters a lot to us.  Thanks again for your time.  You look great today, by-the-way.

story:
Short Summary

TALOS will be the first annual Science Fiction Theatre Festival of the UK and the first such festival is taking place October 24-25 at Chelsea Theatre in London, UK. This year we're presenting 8 new science fiction plays by playwrights from all over the world, including US and Greece. You can check out our programme and buy tickets here: https://www.chelseatheatre.org.uk/project/talos...

We need your help to kickstart a series of science fiction fringe theatre festivals in London that will produce sci-fi plays by new playwrights. There is already a number of such festivals in the US but no other annual festival of this kind in Europe, so we're mostly aiming to give life to European science fiction on stage.



What We Need & What You Get

We need £1100 in order to pay a professional fee for the artists involved and to cover the costs of staging the 8 short plays. Approximately £900 of this money will go towards paying our artists and the rest will cover props, printing programmes and other relevant expenses.

We offer a number of rewards for writers, actors and aspiring producers, such as workshops on performing non-human characters and rehearsed readings of new sci-fi writing. Whether you're a theatremaker, performer or a geek who's into theatre, we have something for you.


The Impact

If successful, TALOS festival will grow each year and, from a two-day fringe theatre festival, will expand to include more new plays in 2016. A series of related events will follow, such as workshops on performing science fiction, sci-fi theatre conferences and seminars, and relevant publications. Science fiction theatre lacks a home in Europe but, with your help, this home could be London.


Who we are

We are a community of London-based artists, most of us Greeks, determined to not simply stage great sci-fi theatre but most importantly sci-fi theatre that is thought-provoking and challenging. More info about our team here:
 http://www.talosfest.com/p/about-talos.html

Risks & Challenges

The most important challenge for us is time. We have a list of wonderful plays and are building a team of enthusiastic artists involved as producers, actors and directors but are running a race against time since the festival is little less than a month away: 24-25 October 2015. We would therefore love your help; even simply by sharing our campaign and getting the word out. Help us give birth to this baby sci-fi theatre festival and we guarantee that many more will follow.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute, we'd still be grateful if you help us get the word out! The festival is on facebook and twitter, feel free to get in touch!

This year we're presenting 8 new science fiction plays by playwrights from all over the world, including US and Greece. You can check out our programme and buy tickets here: https://www.chelseatheatre.org.uk/project/talos...
We need your help to kickstart a series of science fiction fringe theatre festivals in London that will produce sci-fi plays by new playwrights. There is already a number of such festivals in the US but no other annual festival of this kind in Europe, so we're mostly aiming to give life to European science fiction on stage.


What We Need & What You Get
 
We need £1100 in order to pay a professional fee for the artists involved and to cover the costs of staging the 8 short plays. Approximately £900 of this money will go towards paying our artists and the rest will cover props, printing programmes and other relevant expenses.
We offer a number of rewards for writers, actors and aspiring producers, such as workshops on performing non-human characters and rehearsed readings of new sci-fi writing. Whether you're a theatremaker, performer or a geek who's into theatre, we have something for you.

    The Impact If successful, TALOS festival will grow each year and, from a two-day fringe theatre festival, will expand to include more new plays in 2016. A series of related events will follow, such as workshops on performing science fiction, sci-fi theatre conferences and seminars, and relevant publications. Science fiction theatre lacks a home in Europe but, with your help, this home could be London.




    
Who we are
We are a community of London-based artists, most of us Greeks, determined to not simply stage great sci-fi theatre but most importantly sci-fi theatre that is thought-provoking and challenging. More info about our team here:


 http://www.talosfest.com/p/about-talos.html


Risks & Challenges
The most important challenge for us is time. We have a list of wonderful plays and are building a team of enthusiastic artists involved as producers, actors and directors but are running a race against time since the festival is little less than a month away: 24-25 October 2015. We would therefore love your help; even simply by sharing our campaign and getting the word out. Help us give birth to this baby sci-fi theatre festival and we guarantee that many more will follow.
    Other Ways You Can Help 
If you can't contribute, we'd still be grateful if you help us get the word out! The festival is on facebook and twitter, feel free to get in touch!

story:
What is Greasy The Robber

Greasy The Robber is a book originally translated from Russian into German and then translated into English by Charles Lukesh a missionary to Chzechoslavakia, about a boy-robber who found hope and the true meaning of life in Jesus Christ through an amazing turn of events in his life.
Our plan is to take the book to a new level, producing a professional quality, audio drama story that will lead the lost to find the same hope and forgiveness that Greasy found in Jesus Christ, and inspire Christians to unashamedly share the gospel at all cost.
This is an amazing opportunity to reach those that may never hear the gospel otherwise and you can be a part by your donation of any size!

Who I Am

  • My name is Josiah Persinger. I am eighteen years old, and have just graduated high school. 
  • I have a great burden for a media ministry to Missionaries and Ministries.
  • I am trying to raise funds for the cost of this project. 

Endorsements 

"Greasy the Robber is an amazing story. It communicates that no matter how far a person descends into sin, there is always a way out. Set in the waning days of the Russian Empire, the heartfelt story of Pasha (Paul) Tikhomirov, reminds us that the Word of God is sharper than any two edged sword. No matter how many ways people devise to communicate the gospel, there is no substitute for the straight words of the Bible. This eternal truth has, and always will have, the power to change lives all over the world. In Pasha's case, death became life in an amazing way. 

We are so glad to be a part of this project and hope it will be an inspiration to many people."

-Duane Riffenburgh, Scriptwriter and Voice Actor

"When I first read the story of Greasy the Robber, I was impacted by the
amazing story of God's redemptive power. It is an incredible journey as we
follow the story of a young man's life that was thrust into pain from an
early age. However, God didn't leave him there. Through unbelievable twists,
trials, and victories, God brought this young man to Salvation, and to be a
blessing to others!

Josiah sent me the story to see what I thought about it as a basis for a
radio drama. I am convinced this will make a powerful audio adventure, and I
truly believe God will use it to change lives. So I encourage you to pray
about supporting this project!"

-Pat Roy, Creator of the Jonathan Park Audio Adventures

What We Need

  • We need funds to buy needed materials, pay scriptwriters, and voice actors.

The Impact

  • We pray that this project will be a blessing to all who hear it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, it doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Pray for the Lord's continued direction as we seek to follow Him.
  • Please share our project with your friends and family and on social media!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
***Veuillez prendre note que, dû à une erreur d'Indiegogo, la devise est présentement en dollars US. Veuillez donc faire votre don en prenant la devise US en compte. Merci de votre compréhension. ***

LE TOUTOU DE MON EX (QUE J'AIME ENCORE)

Mise en scène: Nicolas Guillemette
Texte: Mélodie Bujold et Nicolas Guillemette
Direction de production: Florence Cardinal Picard
Musique: Simon Malouin
Avec: Mélodie Bujold, Thomas Duret, Samuel Bleau et Adrien Lessard

À PROPOS DE NOUS

Nous sommes la Troupe Won-Ton, une jeune troupe de théâtre de la relève composée de deux étudiants de l'école supérieure de théâtre de l'UQÀM épaulés par un groupe de diplômés expérimentés. Nous avons consacré le temps que nous avions à notre disposition durant la grève pour écrire une pièce qui, à notre grand bonheur, s'est vue accepter au sein de la programmation annuelle de l'Espace La Risée cette saison-ci. Le toutou de mon ex (que j'aime encore) sera présentée cet hiver du 14 au 16 janvier et du 21 au 23 janvier 2016 à l'Espace La Risée. 

La troupe Won-Ton désire sortir des sentiers battus pour mettre de la lumière sur des thématiques trop souvent tues. Sexualité, surconsommation, objectification  de l'humain, égalité des sexes et idéaux de beauté ont tous ponctué nos écrits. Pour traiter de ceux-ci, une femme occupe la scène avec une centaine de peluches qui l'entourent et des amants qui la hantent. 

En vous remerciant de l'intérêt que vous portez à notre projet et de l'aide que vous nous apportez pour parvenir à le mener à terme.

CE QUE VOUS OBTENEZ

- Moins de 25$ = On vous aime beaucoup beaucoup

- 25 $ = Mention/ remerciement sur Facebook

- 50$ = Une paire de billets 

- 75$ = Une paire de billets VIP

- 100$ = Une paire de billets "Ultra VIP" (VIP + programme souvenir + photo avec l'équipe)

- 150$  = Une paire de billets ''Ultra VIP'' + peluche souvenir (Sûrement frenchée par Mélodie Bujold. On négocie encore pour ça.)

- 200$ = 4 billets VIP

- 250 $ =  4 billets ''Ultra VIP'' + peluche frenchée + mention dans le programme du spectacle

- 500 $ = Tout ce qui a été mentionné précédemment + On vous invite à souper chez nous pour Noël.

- 1000$ = T'es pas game.

Veuillez nous contacter personnellement suite à votre don pour réclamer vos prix! 


Le toutou de mon ex (que j'aime encore), du 14 au 16 janvier et du 21 au 23 janvier 2016 à l'Espace La Risée. Manquez pas ça.

story:
About Our Play

Kiss Me or Cut Off My Head is a collaboration between theatre artists Brooke M. Haney and Chris Carcione.

  • A beautiful play adapted from poetry about Medusa.
  • Confronts Rape Culture in America and Kenya.
  • Raises money and awareness for Margaret's Safe Place.

We believe in the power of theater to change the world and transform lives. We are producing this play to encourage a much needed conversation about rape culture, to make survivors of sexual assault feel less alone and to help friends and family of survivors feel more equipped to support their loved ones.


What We Need

$12,500 for performance space:

  • Our largest expense in NYC is paying for the performance space. $12,500 would cover the cost of one week of tech and a four week run.

Stretch Goals:

  • $15,500 would cover the cost of two additional weeks of rehearsal in a studio space.
  • $16,500 covers the cost of re-shooting some of the video of that we use in the show.
  • $19,600 allows for lights, sound, costumes and projections!
  • As we reach these, we'll start to list other stretch goals for you. 

Kiss Me or Cut Off My Head is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Kiss Me or Cut Off My Head must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The Impact

Kiss Me or Cut Off My Head is aimed at the following:

  • Using theater to foster a conversation about rape culture in America.
  • Helping survivors of sexual assault to feel less alone.
  • Equipping friends and families of survivors to better support their loved ones.
  • Raising money and awareness for Margaret's Safe Place. 

Photo: the girls of Margaret's Safe Place live with a social worker who cares for them, keeps them safe, and helps them reach their full potential.

Past Successes

We've been working together off and on for nearly 8 years. We started collaborating on Kiss Me or Cut Off My Head in 2012, and have work-shopped the play several times getting it ready for a NYC production. 

Timeline:

  • September 2012: Fully staged site-specific workshop of Kiss Me or Cut off My Head at Pristine Beach in Palawan, Philippines. The workshop was focused on creating a visual theatrical experience for viewers whose primary language was not English.
  • Spring and Summer 2014: Brooke interviewed survivors of rape in American and Kenya and wrote a new adaptation of the script, incorporating these interviews.
  • November 2014: Workshop of a new adaptation incorporating audio and video interviews with survivors of sexual assault in the US and Kenya. Presented at Sarah Lawrence College.
  • January 2015: Pittsburgh workshop performance of new adaptation in partnership with Chatham University at Most Wanted Fine Art. This workshop was free and open to the public. Donations were accepted for Margaret's Safe Place. The audience was packed, standing room only, and the response was very encouraging. 

Quotes from the workshops:

  • Sarah Lawrence Workshop: One of our goals is to educate about rape culture. After the workshop, a student came up to us and said, "I've been to four required seminars on sexual assault and I learned more today, watching this play, than I did in all of them put together."
  • Pittsburgh Workshop: Another goal is that survivors who see the show will feel less alone. After this workshop, a young man came up to me, in tears, and said, "I can't thank you enough for this play. I'm a survivor and it means so much to me."


Other Ways You Can Help

While money definitely does help us, there are other ways you can support us that we'd be very grateful for:

  • Like us on facebook for  behind-the-scenes updates.
  • Follow us on twitter to join the conversation. 
  • Share our project with someone you think might be passionate about the cause or interested to know about it.

One of our primary goals is to encourage the conversation about rape culture and to build awareness for Shining Hope for Communities. By connecting with us on social media and telling your friends and family about us, you help us begin to achieve these goals before rehearsals even start.

story:
About The ISO Project + Convergence

We are The ISO Project - a groundbreaking concept developed by dancers and supporters of the North Carolina dance community.

ISO: A camera’s sensitivity level to available light. We aim to shine light on our community and its emerging talent.

ISO: Short for “in search of”. We are continuously searching for ways to promote artistic innovation and build stronger bridges within the dance community.

ISO: In Support Of. The ISO Project was established in support of our local dance community, to propel dancers and choreographers to new levels of creativity and collaboration.

The ISO Project is excited to announce our premiere event: Convergence. 

Convergence will bring together dancers and choreographers of diverse training and backgrounds to create an unforgettable showcase in just forty-eight hours. We have invited six choreographers from across the country to create original works for this event, with the goal of building lasting, sustainable bridges throughout the dance community nationwide. Dancers of all genres and experience levels are invited to participate and will be guaranteed the opportunity to perform in the final showcase. 

What We Need & What You Get

We Need:

  • Choreographer Compensation: rate, travel, lodging, & per diem

  • Venue Rental: studio rehearsal space, performance venue, security deposits, technical fees, & insurance

  • Visual Documentation: photographer & videographer - professionally edited footage will be released after the showcase!

  • Materials & Supplies: marketing tools & initial cost of merchandise

Minimum Breakdown:


You Get:

  • A chance to build a novel community in North Carolina with opportunities to stretch beyond.
  • Look to the right to check out the perks of donating to The ISO Project + Convergence! We're giving away everything from handwritten cards to awesome apparel to free dancer registration!
The Impact

Why should you support Convergence? Because your donation will make a difference. Each and every person involved in this project has something unique to benefit from the experience. The ISO Project hopes to build a platform on which to raise our community, and Convergence will be our foundation. By connecting artists, empowering dancers, and inspiring patrons, Convergence will unite supporters of the art and encourage the creation of more opportunities by the community, for the community.

Risks & Challenges

Producing an event like Convergence requires the careful coordination of many different elements, some of which may not be completely within our control. From hosting choreographers to booking venues to providing support for our dancers, The ISO Project and its affiliates will operate with the utmost responsibility and professionalism. Have any additional questions about The ISO Project or Convergence? We'd love to hear from you! Please feel free to contact us at isoprojectnc@gmail.com

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Unable to contribute financially? MAKE SOME NOISE. Please use the Indiegogo share tools to let all your friends and family know about us! 
  • Do you have any resources or connections that could aid in the production of Convergence? Please let us know! We love networking!
