There you have it, join us on this quest for fun and laughter... and it will be an outrageous venture. Soon to be in a theater near you.
Thank you and I look forward to your participation in what I believe will be a very unique production, risque yes, humorous most certainly, and blessed with a great deal of laughter.
PLEASE donate and enjoy the gifts listed on the right of the page.
Many thanks.Peter Shillingford
My cohorts / sidekicks keeping me straight and on course are:
David Shillingford   Media Guru        Emma Chisit   Accountant                                                                        
 Joy Shillingford   Mother Ship         Peter Shillingford   Creator 
                                   
Reg Starkey  Legal Wrangler       Tom (John) Jones  Impersonator

story:
Let’s get this show on the road!

After nearly two decades of extensive research, reading letters and articles and conducting interviews with family members, Willie and Me: The Emmett Kelly Story, by Jonathan Cerullo & Stephen Woodburn is finally ready for an industry reading to potential investors and producers.

The man behind the sad-faced makeup was a father, a husband, an entertainer and one of the most recognized faces with Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus. But despite touching the hearts of children worldwide, Emmett and his own son, Junior, were estranged for decades and never reconciled. From humble Midwest beginnings to starring with the Greatest Show on Earth, Willie and Me: The Emmett Kelly Story paints a colorful portrait of life in the circus and a bygone era in American life.

Please consider following us on Facebook to stay up to date with our show and learn how you can help bring this story to life.

Willie and Me is being presented by Spotlight Communications, Inc.

____________________________________________

 

How is the funding being allocated?

Like the circus, this production has many moving parts and below is how your generously donated funds will be used:

  • 5 AEA Actors (fee including 4 day RT trans)
  • 1 Above title Actor
  • 1 Stage Manager
  • SDC Director (all inclusive of P&W and Health)
  • Crowd Funding Consultant
  • Casting Director
  • Assistant to Producer
  • Rehearsal Space (25hrs x 40per hr)
  • Lodging (3 person - 3 days 2 nights) The Emmett Kelly Family is being honored
  • Transportation - Roundtrip Airfare (for 4)
  • Ground Transportation
  • Marketing- Info Pkg
  • Merchandising (The Perks)
  • Art Work/Graphic Designer Fee
  • Facebook Boosting
  • Producer
  • Contingency
  • Out Of Pocket Expenses - Staff

____________________________________________

Wow, we are so humbled by the support and the generosity of the support for Willie and Me, which is a project that has meant so much to us.

Thank you who have contributed to this, please consider sharing this with five of your friends... and for those of you folks who would still like to do so, you can do so now!

During my research, I had the pleasure of meeting the lovely Mrs. Emmett Kelly - Lentz, who along with her daughters keep the legacy of Emmett alive.  I thought I'd share a picture of our visit.

 

Thank you, and may all your days be circus days!

____________________________________________

DREAMS DO COME TRUE

Steve Woodburn ~ Brandextender's Blog

My passion for close to 20 years has been writing a Broadway play about America’s most iconic clown, Emmett Kelly, Sr. He rose to fame in an era long before computers, the Internet, social media, and email, portraying a sad-faced hobo character he named Weary Willie.

His most famous routine was sweeping up a spotlight only to be startled by its reappearance, but eventually sweeping it into a smaller and smaller pool and putting it in his pocket or sweeping it under a rug.

I’ve shared my vision with friends over the years and am sure most began to think of me as a Don Quixote character, forever tilting my pen at windmills I had no chance of reaching. And there were the dream killers, telling me how impossible it is to get a show produced anywhere, much less on Broadway.

I persevered through it all and met a like-minded soul along the way named Jonathan Cerullo and together we’ve finally completed Willie and Me: The Emmett Kelly Story. We’re holding a reading this fall for a select group of producers and investors and if my dream finally comes to fruition, we’ll see our name in lights on Broadway.

We’re also running an IndiGoGo campaign to raise money to fund the reading and while I hate asking people for money, making your dream a reality sometimes means going outside your comfort zone.

I just posted a blog on this called "Dreams Do Come True" at https://brandextenders.com/2017/08/10/dreams-do-come-true/

​​

____________________________________________

~* 25% FUNDED *~

We hit a milestone today and are that much closer to our goal in

“Gettin' this show on the road!”

THANK YOU ~ OMG WE ARE OVERWHELMED!

We are one step closer to seeing this dream become a reality. 

I want to share this picture when Stephen and I were in Sarasota, Florida discussing and researching the play, and had a lovely site visit with our dear friend and circus scholar, Brian Liddicoat at the Ringling Museum and the Historic Also Theater. 

It has always been our dream to premiere this show here so…

SIDE SHOW BARKER

(Follow spot snaps onto SIDESHOW BARKER than shifts to each individual)

Ladies and Gentlemen, may I turn your attention to the following lovely contributors, for a heartfelt thank you shout out to Kyla, Ms. Judine, Dale, Carrie & Steve, Lee, Dulcie aka Kathleen, Wendy, Chip, Randall, Jack, Shari, Ellen, Adrian, Jim, Leslie (cough-cough), Diane, Paul & Sherry, Bruce Robert, and last, but certainly not least, mixlexia!

(Thunderous applause are heard throughout)

 

____________________________________________

Today is the day after the Eclipse and I am awed by this incredible event. While witnessing this communal experience I had a reflective moment and took a second to say thank you to Emmett Kelly whose memory and artistry we honor for “gifting” this to us.  I would like to follow-up this up with a thank you to our most recent contributors, Rosemarie, Cindy, Mel, Annie, Valerie, and Alex!

Did you know that circus is an ancient art and can be traced back to the Egyptians? Thank you for bringing one of the stories from this ancient art form to life with your generous contribution to our project.  This has helped us get one step closer to realizing this play and from the bottom of our hearts, we can’t thank you enough!

Jonathan & Stephen

Photos:

Eclipse 2017 By Jonathan Cerullo

Ceramic Acrobat 900 - 500 BCE - The Greatest Shows on Earth, Linda Simon  

____________________________________________

Jonathan Cerullo's Personal Pitch
 

____________________________________________

Stephen Woodburn's Personal Pitch

____________________________________________

We are very excited to share this with you!

PLAYBILL - ON - LINE

BRAD OSCAR

to star in World Premiere invited reading of

WILLIE AND ME: THE EMMETT KELLY STORY 

Spotlight Communications, Inc. presents Tony and Drama Desk Award nominee, BRAD OSCAR as Emmett Kelly in WILLIE AND ME: THE EMMETT KELLY STORY,

Brad Oscar, will be portraying Emmett Kelly and the world-famous clown Weary Willie, whose silence spoke to a nation! Brad is a two-time Tony Award nominee and Drama Desk nominee, and has appeared on Broadway in, Something Rotten! (Tony Award nomination), Big Fish, Nice Work If You Can Get It, The Producers, (Tony Award nomination), The Addams Family, Spamalot, Jekyll & Hyde, Aspects of Love.  National Tour: The Phantom of the Opera, Young Frankenstein, Jekyll & Hyde. West End: The Producers. Off Broadway: Sweeney Todd, Forbidden Broadway, The Body Beautiful, Encores! Annie Get Your Gun, Bells Are Ringing and Do Re Mi. Regional: Fiddler on the Roof (Barrington Stage), Barnum (Asolo Rep/Maltz Jupiter- Carbonell Award, Best Actor in a Musical), The Mystery of Irma Vep, Cabaret and Damn Yankees (Arena Stage), The First Wives Club (Old Globe). Film: Ghost Town, The Producers. Television: "Madam Secretary," "Smash," "The Good Wife" and three "Law & Orders."

Stephen Woodburn, Co-Author and President of Spotlight Communications majored in Theatre Arts in college then began a 20-year love affair on-air as a radio disc jockey, news anchor, traffic reporter and various management roles. In 1982 he landed in Atlanta, Georgia as General Manager and the on-air anchor of a syndicated traffic reporting company. Steve spent many years acting in college and local theatre productions including Night of the Iguana, The Fantasticks, Arsenic & Old Lace, The Six O’clock News, Stalag 17 and The 1940’s Radio Hour. Steve has also been featured in national TV commercials, industrial films, and print ads.

The reading will be directed by Cerullo, an award-winning theatre director. Cerullo has worked on or in the Broadway productions of, Band In Berlin, Legs Diamond, Anna Karenina, The Three Musketeers, Say, Goodnight Gracie, and appeared as Skimbleshanks in the National  Tour of CATS, Off-Bway:York Theatre Company, Primary Stages, Amas Music Theatre, and regionally at the Goodspeed Opera House, North Shore Music Theatre, Denver Center, and the Big Apple Circus at Lincoln Center, and in film, and television, Great Performances, Boston Pops. 

BRAD OSCAR

____________________________________________

Two time Lortel Award nominee and

Princess Grace Award winner,

Carson Elrod

joins our cast!

We are thrilled to announce Carson has agreed to portray Junior in our presentation and we couldn’t be more thrilled to welcome him to our family! 

Carson has a distinguished career on stage film and TV he has been represented on Broadway in Peter and the Starcatcher, Reckless, Noises Off. The Metropolitan Opera: The Merry Widow. Off-Broadway: The Liar, The Heir Apparent (CSC) Important Hats of the Twentieth Century, Explorer’s Club, House/Garden, (MTC). Lives of the Saints, All In The Timing (Primary Stages) Measure for Measure, All’s Well That End’s Well, The Tempest (The Public); Oliver Twist (TFNA) Regional: Yale Rep, A.R.T., Berkeley Rep, TCG, Bucks County Playhouse, Baltimore Center Stage, Williamstown Theatre Festival, La Jolla Playhouse, Westport Country Playhouse, Barrington Stage. Film: Wedding Crashers, Kissing Jessica Stein. TV: “Elementary,” “Person of Interest,” “30 Rock,” “Law & Order: CI”. Princess Grace Award. NYTW Usual Suspect. NYU Grad Acting. 

Please visit his website for more insight into his illustrious career. http://www.carsonelrod.com

Carson Elrod

____________________________________________

 

VERY EXCITED!

READINGS AND WORKSHOPS  

Karen Ziemba and Carson Elrod

Will Join Brad Oscar in Reading of 

Willie and Me: The Emmett Kelly Story

BY ANDREW GANS - SEP 06, 2017

The drama is written by Stephen Woodburn and Jonathan Cerullo.

Spotlight Communications, Inc. will present an invitation-only reading of the new bio-drama Willie and Me: The Emmett Kelly Story September 18 in Manhattan.

Tony nominee Brad Oscar (Something Rotten!, The Producers, Nice Work If You Can Get It), as previously reported, will star in the title role. Oscar will be joined by Tony winner Karen Ziemba—currently on Broadway in Prince of Broadway—as Evi Kelly, Emmett Kelly’s wife; and Carson Elrod (Peter and the Starcatcher, Reckless, Noises Off) as Junior, Emmett Kelly's son.

Read: BRAD OSCAR WILL STAR IN READING OF WILLIE AND ME

Willie and Me: The Emmett Kelly Story is co-written by Stephen Woodburn and Jonathan Cerullo and concerns the life and times of Emmett Kelly, Sr., known to millions of Americans as the sad-faced clown Weary Willie. His trademark routine was the sweeping up of a spotlight into his pocket. Despite touching the hearts of children worldwide, Emmett Kelly, Sr. and his oldest son, Junior, could never reconcile, and it broke the father's heart.

In addition to performing in a variety of circuses, including Ringling Brothers, Barnum and Bailey Circus for 14 years, Emmett Kelly performed on Broadway in Keep Off the Grass, a 1940 production starring Ray Bolger, Jimmy Durante, Jackie Gleason, and Jerome Robbins. He also appeared in Cecil B. DeMille’s 1952 Academy Award-winning film The Greatest Show on Earth.

The reading, which will be directed by Cerullo, will also feature Vanessa Wendt and David Ryan Smith, who will play a variety of roles.

To learn more about the play, visit WillieAndMe.com.

Karen Ziemba

David Ryan Smith

Vanessa Wendt

____________________________________________

 

Thank you, dear donors, we are simply gobsmacked by the generosity towards our play!  

Our play is about family and did you know we are honoring the Emmett Kelly Family at our presentation?  

I thought you might like to see this lovely family portrait!

 

1961 (L-R) Stasia, Emmett, Monika, Evi

 

____________________________________________

 

Wow, 24 hours to go and this has been an unbelievable journey - as we all know "it ain't over till it's over"... so if you have a friend or two you feel might want to contrite to this we still have some time!  

We start rehearsal tomorrow and we are just jumping out of our skin with excitement!  

Willie is so happy we made it this far and he can't thank you enough he is overjoyed!

story:
On behalf of the Park Performing Arts Center of Union City, NJ, we would like to take a

brief moment to extend an invitation for you to support the Arts in New Jersey. We

currently have a wildly successful original musical called ‘Something Like A Fairytale’

written and directed by a young and gifted Newark, NJ native, Lawrence Dandridge.

 

Breaking the boundaries of stereotypes, this show not only touches on universal

subjects like parental pressure, love triangles, domestic disputes, and divorce (to name

a few) but it also shines light on what it means to have a fairytale ending, specifically

from the African American perspective. Through music that is influenced by many

genres, this show takes us on a relatable journey that bridges the gap between the

version of love we all long for and the version of love most of us actually get.

This award winning musical was featured in The 2016 Hudson Guild Thespis Theater

Festival in New York City and won 6 out of the 7 award categories its was nominated for

including Best Original Play, Best Director, and Best Score. Heading into this summer,

we’ve been accepted into the 2017 National Black Theater Festival in Winston Salem,

North Carolina and we need your help!

 

Our production consists of 32 talented individuals from the greater NY/NJ area. In order

to bring this show to it’s next level of success, we aim to raise $8,000. This will cover

production costs extending from transportation to rehearsal space, set design, props,

and costume. So we're turning to the community in hopes that our local support systems

can have a hand into building this independent production. Monetary and service

contributions in any amount will help! In exchange, we're offering Advertisement space

on our website (www.somethinglikeafairytale.com) and video/photo services in the

equivalent donation amounts from our partners at INVISIONi Studios, LLC. Your

contribution will help us continue to highlight stories of unpublished African American

writers based out of NJ. Furthermore, it will help support the creative arts as well as

independent working artists/writers.

story:
Who’s Asking?

My name is Leslie Charipar, and I am a theatre artist in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

In 2001, I received an MFA in Acting at The Theatre School at DePaul University and spent the next few years working as an actor, director, and teacher in the Chicago area.

In 2003, I came home and started Urban Theater Project of Iowa.

We are a spry little theatre company that does edgy stuff in non-theatrical spaces: Rabbit Hole in the living room of a house for sale. It sold shortly after our production closed; True West in an empty storefront. A few months later that same space that sat empty for years, was rented and has been occupied ever since.

We are dedicated to doing theatre that is thoughtful and relevant, visceral and organic, truthful and messy.

 

Why Am I Asking?

Since I started Urban Theater Project, there has been an influx of new theatre companies in the area. As a result, we took a hiatus to re-evaluate the kind of work we do and our place in the community.

What we discovered is that it’s time for Leslie Charipar, seasoned theatre artist, and Urban Theater Project of Iowa, spry little theatre company that could, to focus on making new theatre.

 

Why Am I Asking Now?

On June 4, 2015, I was diagnosed with breast cancer and then lung cancer and then thyroid cancer.

In the last two years, I’ve had four surgeries, chemotherapy, radiation, radioactive iodine treatment, and blood clots in my brain. My two-year relationship disintegrated, menopause started early, Donald Trump was elected President, and I turned 50. 

In a relatively short amount of time, I have had some of the most difficult, painful experiences of my life. And lately, I’ve found myself wondering why the cancers didn’t just kill me. Why keep going? If the reward for living through cancer is losing the love of my life and watching a crazy man dismantle everything that I think is good about this country, what is the fucking point?

I am currently unable to answer that question, so I’m going to drive around the country and ask people who I know and people who I don’t know why they get up in the morning and feed themselves and pay their bills and water their plants and get married and have babies and make plans.

And then I’m going to write about it.

And then I'm going to perform it.

I might even make a book out of it.

I can't think of a better way to launch the newly refocused Urban Theater Project of Iowa than to premier my new performance piece, Reasons for Living.

 

What’s In It For Me?

I am asking for your help to raise $100,000 by August 3.

These funds will be used both for the immediate needs of Reasons for Living as well as looking toward Urban Theater Project of Iowa’s long-term sustainability.

The breakdown looks like this:

$15000 - purchase a new or used camper: Reasons for Living travel, future travel, temporary low-cost housing for local or visiting artists

$5000 - upgrade my vehicle to pull camper; assure that I/Urban Theater Project have reliable transportation for the long-term

$3000 - pay off medical bills

$4500 – pay mortgage ahead six months: ensure that my mortgage is paid during Reasons for Living travel and development; make it possible to keep my house so that I can continue to live and work as an artist in Cedar Rapids; provide temporary low-cost housing for local or visiting artists

$72500 – pay off my graduate student loans: to reduce my monthly bills and eliminate this obligation for my dad who co-signed on these loans; to take the pressure off of Reasons for Living and Urban Theater Project of Iowa to make money and pay my bills so that we can remain accessible to a wide variety of audiences; to contribute to the long-term financial health of Urban Theater Project so that we have to ask for money less and less.

 

What’s In It For You?

Here’s what you can get for your generous contribution:

$1-149                   

  • 1 ticket to the premiere of Reasons for Living

$150-499             

  • 2 tickets to the premiere of Reasons for Living

$500-999           

  • 4 tickets to the premiere of Reasons for Living

$1000-2499     

  • 8 tickets to the premiere of Reasons for Living

$2500-4999     

  • 10 tickets to the premiere of Reasons for Living

$5000-9999      

  • 2 VIP tickets to all Urban Theater Project of Iowa productions
  • a signed Reasons for Living poster
  • a hand-selected souvenir from the state of your choosing

$10,000 and up  

  • a private performance of Reasons for Living
  • a signed Reasons for Living show poster
  • 2 complimentary VIP tickets to all Urban Theater Project of Iowa productions
  • hand-selected souvenir from every state I visit August 1 -- November 1, 2017
story_txt:
Who’s Asking?My name is Leslie Charipar, and I am a theatre artist in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.In 2001, I received an MFA in Acting at The Theatre School at DePaul University and spent the next few years working as an actor, director, and teacher in the Chicago area.In 2003, I came home and started Urban Theater Project of Iowa.We are a spry little theatre company that does edgy stuff in non-theatrical spaces: Rabbit Hole in the living room of a house for sale. It sold shortly after our production closed; True West in an empty storefront. A few months later that same space that sat empty for years, was rented and has been occupied ever since.We are dedicated to doing theatre that is thoughtful and relevant, visceral and organic, truthful and messy. Why Am I Asking?Since I started Urban Theater Project, there has been an influx of new theatre companies in the area. As a result, we took a hiatus to re-evaluate the kind of work we do and our place in the community.What we discovered is that it’s time for Leslie Charipar, seasoned theatre artist, and Urban Theater Project of Iowa, spry little theatre company that could, to focus on making new theatre. Why Am I Asking Now?On June 4, 2015, I was diagnosed with breast cancer and then lung cancer and then thyroid cancer.In the last two years, I’ve had four surgeries, chemotherapy, radiation, radioactive iodine treatment, and blood clots in my brain. My two-year relationship disintegrated, menopause started early, Donald Trump was elected President, and I turned 50. In a relatively short amount of time, I have had some of the most difficult, painful experiences of my life. And lately, I’ve found myself wondering why the cancers didn’t just kill me. Why keep going? story:
Summary

The cost of bringing a show to the Fringe is a huge challenge for most theatre companies but for those of us who come from working class and/or BAME backgrounds, that mountain can be even steeper to climb. However, we truly believe in the importance of this show, the relevance and poignancy of the script and the talent of our director and performers. Showcasing this kind of work is not only crucial to creating a more diverse and representative Fringe Festival but also to ensuring that the UK is adequately reflected across the theatre industry as a whole.

 

Writer/Producer Karla talks representation on London Live...

 

What We Need & What You Get

We still need money to rent the space, print programmes, flyers and posters and cover the cost of our costumes and tech requirements.

Larger donations would see you truly investing in the future of this show. However, small contributions really do add up. The equivalent of what you might spend on a round of drinks on a night out could help pay for one of our actors costumes. And instead of a horrible hangover the next day, you'll be left with that warm fuzzy feeling that contributing to something good can often leave you with. 

It costs us £5 per show to have a technician run the stage lighting. So even giving a fiver will mean one of our shows is covered and all of those fivers add up!!

 

About the play...

There are a great many laughs in this play but, embedded in Rupture's intricate narrative, there are also some serious questions about how the decisions we make now could effect us in the future.

It tells the story of Jay Sharma, who has just started his dream job at a mysterious government agency. The year is 2107 and the planet has barely managed to rebuild itself after being brought to its knees by a catastrophic global event. It is in this broken world that Jay finds himself faced with a terrible decision and soon discovers his dream job has a dark side...

 

The Impact

Your contribution will really make a difference. Not just to us. Not even just to theatre and the arts as a whole. But also to a wonderful charity called Arts Emergency. 10% of all ticket profits will be going straight to this wonderful organisation who help young people from low income backgrounds gain access to the arts and humanities and forge careers in the creative industries. We'll be using the profits of this show to help pave the way for some of the BAME and working class theatremakers of the future, so the more successful it is, the bigger an impact we can have.

The play itself explores climate change and the consequences of bureaucracy in an unflinching yet accessible way that is sure to make audiences think and is intended to create a dialogue on the subjects. Rupture's unwavering look at the future of the world may even be a little controversial but we believe that healthy debate is more vital than ever in today's society and we look forward to having the opportunity to be a part of that conversation.

story:
Our Campaign

Green Room Theatre Camp is back and better than ever! We've been working hard to prepare for Season II, and we're finally ready to launch. If you know anything about GRTC, you know we're not in it for the money. Our business model is asinine: Nobody gets paid, we charge the campers a fraction of the actual value, and we give away half of our revenue. But y'know what? We sleep really, really well at night. (Because we're so tired from confronting teen angst every day). 

The campaign. The camp-payin'. We need your help. We literally can't run the program without you. We're happy to be the 'boots on the ground' and give these campers a safe place to explore their creativity and expand their skill sets, but we need your support. Check out our Perks and Shopping List to see how you can partner with us. You won't regret it, we promise!

 

Giving Back & Giving Forth

GRTC is a non-profit group that operates solely on your donations. And as you create this culture of giving, we are committed to perpetuating it. Every season, we donate 50% of our ticket sales to a charity of the campers' choosing. We believe that the leaders of tomorrow should get a chance to fight social inequality and see (firsthand) the effects of their time, energy and generosity.

 

Shopping List & Wish List

Our team may be small, but we dream big! Here is a list of what we need to run the camp, as well as a list of our long term goals. We would be honoured to partner with you in either category!

Shopping List

  • Foooood: If Jason had his way, every day would be Pizza Friday. However, that would shock and mortify the parents who have entrusted us with their children. If cooking for a dozen campers & volunteers is your passion, please drop us a line!
  • Costumes: What if you were watching Downton Abbey and all the characters were wearing sweatpants with "Class of 1912" written on the bums? Proper costumes are essential, but they don't come cheap. 
  • Set Materials: Our curriculum encourages our campers to design their very own set, so while they're busy dreaming of the endless possibilities, we are facing the harsh reality that building materials are incredibly costly. But hey, if Timmy wants a 30-foot fire-breathing dragon, we will do everything in our power, so be it. (If you happen to have a fire-breathing dragon of any size, please let us know. That sounds amazing).
  • Field Trips & Guest Lecturers: It's important for our campers to see that their artistic exploration doesn't have to end the day camp ends; there is a world of fine arts just waiting to greet them. It's a beautiful world, but it can be a tough one too. Not only do we take our campers on field trips that will inspire them, but we also introduce them to seasoned professionals who can illuminate them to the realities of the BC arts scene.
  • Promo & Printing: Anybody who performs for a living will agree on two things: (1) Promoting shows is time-consuming and costly, and (2) There is no feeling quite like the electricity of performing for a packed house. We want to give these campers an experience they will never forget.
  • Rehearsal Space: We have been extremely blessed to have a local church donate their rehearsal space to us this season, which will allow us to save up for our dream goal of eventually owning our own venue. Skip on down to our Wish List to learn more.
  • Venue Space: They say all the world's a stage... but we can't mount a show in "all the world." We need a proper venue. Our shows are polished and professional, and as such they require dedicated theatre spaces. White Rock Players Club has been gracious enough to offer us a discount for three shows, so we are raising funds to see if we can extend our run elsewhere.

Wish List

  • A truck or van: If you had to haul food, campers and sets across the city, would your first choice be a tiny '94 Jetta that collects puddles of rainwater and only starts when it feels good and ready? Me neither, yet here we are. If you have a hookup for a reliable van or pickup truck, please let us know!
  • Storage space: What do the Arts Club, the Orpheum and the Bell Centre all have in common? None of them have to store their sets, costumes, props, office supplies and legal documents in a single room of an East Van apartment. 
  • A permanent rehearsal (and/or performance) venue: As I mentioned earlier, we have been extremely blessed to have a rehearsal space donated to us this season. But our grand dream is to one day have a theatre space to call our own. A space where we can rig lights and run sound... where we can hang curtains build trapdoors... but most importantly, where youth can come and be weird. No judgment, only mentorship.

 

The Team

Jason Hawkins: High school teacher and aging wunderkind. 
Jacqui Janzen: Web specialist who lives off of salsa & chips (microchips, that is).
Chris Nash: Theatre director, producer and man who is shrinking every day.
Tia Glenn-Cooke: Half improv genius, half cosmic fool, all fun.
Nelson Bergen: Resident Videographer, King of Camps. Jack of all Trades. Ace in the hole.

 

Stories from Season I

During our first season, we gave the campers a simple assignment: Write a monologue about growing up. Should be easy, right? These are the types of responses we expected:

     "My parents are lame."

     "Yeah, I like him... but do I like-like him?"

     "Wake up, Netflix, McDonald's, Snapchat, go to sleep."

 

But these are the responses we got:

     "When I was young, I lived surrounded by many not-so-friendly people that had a collective grudge against the world. Before the age of 10, I had a drug dealer babysitter, I watched a near murder occur four feet in front of me, had to endure a police interrogation, and was privy to many cases of domestic abuse. But I'm still here. I'm doing fabulous, and I worked really hard towards that. Growing up may of been 'get up, fall down, get up, fall down, get up' but it's my childhood. I am the only person that has a say in how it affects me." 

     "Here I stand. Before you: the mirror. You watch my every single move. You see the face of a young person who  is bound to do great things. Mirror, mirror on the wall; Can't you see that I feel small? Can't you see that there's more to me? You've seen me physically evolve, but haven't seen that my ideals change. My priorities shift like any other person. I feel confined. I've been with myself for seventeen years, but I still don't know who I really am. So before you catch my reflection and enclose me once more, remember that seven billion mirrors in this world don't decide who I am. I do."

     "You know, moving sucks. I've lived in four different cities that I know of. I've gone to six different schools and until recently, never in the same one for more than two years. I've had to restart so many times. Moving so much has affected my social skills, too. I never even learned simple things, like how keep a conversation, let alone start one. I’ve been picked on for being myself, being poor, the one time my hair was green because I showered without dye-friendly conditioner. Everyone thought I was gay at one point, and it's not like that's bad; it just isn't me. Have you ever been the one kid who sits in the corner because he doesn't have any friends and doesn't know how to make them? Because I have. Too many times."

 

This generation is amazing. They have brilliant instincts and deserve a safe platform to explore and share them. Our calling is to mentor youth... to nurture creativity... to build community. If your calling happens to intersect with those ideals, let us know! We would love to partner with you.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I’m Erin Moughon, and I’m the playwright of Snow White Padded Room. I’ve had my short plays produced around the country (and in England and Australia) and many published, but it has been over five years since I’ve had a full-length play produced. I’m thrilled to share this play with you.

Snow White Padded Room: Adelaide is commited to a mental facility by her devoted husband Mark when she suffers severe memory loss and hallucinations due to a tragic car accident. Ten years of memory have been wiped away. As she works to recover what she’s lost, Mark isolates her further by keeping everyone else away, keeping a watchful eye on her through a two-way mirror. As her supposed delusions worsen, she tries to remember what caused the accident and who Mark really is. Can Adelaide escape from behind the magic mirror and emerge from her glass coffin by remembering the truth

https://14streety.secure.force.com/ticket#detai...

What We Need & What You Get

Putting on theatre costs money. All funds raised will go towards paying the cast, director, stage manager, and designers, buying set pieces, buying costumes, buying props, and publicity.  This is also the order in which we will be using the money (paying people for their time and talents is my first priority.)

Here’s what you can get!

  • Digital Thank You: I’ll thank you publically on social media so everyone will know how awesome you are!
  • Baked Goods on Demand: I love to bake, and I will share that love of sugar, flour, and butter with you!
  • IT Support: Get computer support instead of throwing it out the window!
  • Signed Script: Get a personalized signed script from me, the playwright.
  • Dinner with the Playwright: I will cook for you! And answer your questions about the play.
  • Reserved Seats!
  • AND MORE!

The Impact

A woman’s story written by a woman, starring strong women. It’s about getting unheard voices out there.  Help make that a reality!

Risks & Challenges

Putting on theatre is always risky. Will people like it? Will we sell those seats? What about the space?  However, we have an advantage! As part of the Broadway Bound Theatre Festival, we already have a beautiful space and support from professionals!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially? There are so many other ways to help!

  • Get the word out! Share this campaign!
  • Use the IndieGoGo share tools!
  • Come and see the play on August 1, 4, and 12!

IT Support: Get computer support instead of throwing it out the window!
Signed Script: Get a personalized signed script from me, the playwright.
Dinner with the Playwright: I will cook for you! And answer your questions about the play.
Reserved Seats!
AND MORE!
The ImpactA woman’s story written by a woman, starring strong women. It’s about getting unheard voices out there.  Help make that a reality!Risks & ChallengesPutting on theatre is always risky. Will people like it? Will we sell those seats? What about the space?  However, we have an advantage! As part of the Broadway Bound Theatre Festival, we already have a beautiful space and support from professionals!Other Ways You Can HelpCan’t contribute financially? There are so many other ways to help!
Get the word out! Share this campaign!
Use the IndieGoGo share tools!
Come and see the play on August 1, 4, and 12!

story:
The Creative Movement and Vaudeville Funk

Boston Mobile Dance Studio and the BeanTown Lockers are Boston’s leading vehicles of the Creative Locking Movement in New England. We are at the center of a revolution of creativity, expression, and freedom, and you can be part of it too!

 

On October 29th join us for “Vaudeville Funk” a funky celebration of Locking and its impact on dance culture.  You will be treated to dance, live music, a silent auction and one of this year’s hottest dance parties.  But the fun doesn’t stop there...

On October 30th, come attend a once-in-a-lifetime Creator’s Class, led by Vaudeville Funk special guest, Mr. Don “Campbellock” Campbell.  He and his son, Dennis Danehy, will teach you how you can be a creative force using one of the world’s funkiest street dances.

 

Mr. Don Campbell, a living legend of creative movement

Don " Campbellock" Campbell is the creator of the world’s first Street Dance, Locking. As a Co-Founder of the world renowned dance troupe “The Lockers” (aka The Campbellock Dancers), he launched a movement in the 70’s that changed the face of dance forever.  Mr. Campbell is encouraged by Boston’s Locking Movement and is excited to return to Boston for the first time in many years to help the movement grow further.  

 

We are honored to have his support.  Mr. Campbell will help us demonstrate that we must go beyond learning “just the steps” by adding expression, creativity and emotion to our movement. He and Dennis will provide you with endless Lock-spiration!

 

We have invited pioneers of this legendary dance to help us properly show the impact Locking has had on our culture, by inspiring Boston with the freedom of movement and expression of this dance.

 

We need your help to bring the Locking Revolution to life

Despite being one of the most entertaining dances to both watch and participate in, Locking has a limited following in New England.  In order to effectively lead our creative revolution, and spread the art form of Locking to this region, we need your help.

 

Help us fund our Indeigogo campaign to bring our vision of Vaudeville Funk & the Creator’s Class to life!  

Here's what the expenses will include:

 
  • Travel, Lodging and Financial support for Don Campbell and Dennis Danehy
  • Vaudeville Funk and Creator’s Class Venues
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Performer Stipends
  • Advertising Costs
  • Photography/Videography
  • Performer Costumes

Combining Vaudeville Funk with Mr. Campbell’s Creator’s Class is an ambitious project that will require significant funding, so any little bit helps!  Please donate, and then join us on October 29th and 30th for the Funkiest experience of 2016!

 

The Creative Movement Initiators

Boston Mobile Dance Studio’s motto is “We don’t just teach you to dance, we teach you to move creatively.”  This is the philosophy of BMDS Founder, and BeanTown Lockers director, Carl Alleyne, who aims to bring quality dance and movement to everyone he meets.

 

 

The BeanTown Lockers are New England’s premier Locking group. Always entertaining and engaging, BTL has helped spread the art form of Locking by delivering fast-paced, theatrical performances that always leave audiences wanting more.

 

There are Other Ways You Can Help Too

If you are not able to help us by funding this revolutionary event, there are other ways you can be a part of it too!

  • Help us by spreading the word on social media. Use the Social Media Share Icons to visit our pages and to share our campaign with your friends!
  • Follow our updates and share your thoughts on Social Media with the following tags: #Campbellocking #LockTheRevolution #BeanTownLockers #VaudevilleFunk.
  • Email this campaign to a friend who might also be interested.

The Vaudeville Funk Revolution is brought to you by the BeanTown Lockers and Boston Mobile Dance Studio. Street Dancing 0-90 MPH.

story:
Summary

   Ed Wood the Musical pulls back the tinsel town curtain of Ed Wood’s life and pays tribute to his legacy. Ed was a charismatic figure who created an ensemble of zany, lovable monsters, from    Bela Lugosi to Tor Johnson, Vampira and the amazing Criswell. His life exemplified irony: a marine, a husband, writer, director and transvestite in a time when that was fraught with danger. Rick Tell’s score evokes the popular musical styles, surf, rock and roll, jazz, Latin, all from the 50’s and 60’s, Ed’s golden era of filmmaking.  Through song, we discover the roots of his cross-dressing in “Glen or Glenda" and “Angora.” His frustration in “Hollywood Rat Race” and his girlfriend’s agony in “Bride of the Monster.” “Walk Like a Zombie” will have everyone on their feet and send you out humming. You could be sitting next to an alien or a zombie or even have flying saucers fly over your head. Ed Wood the Musical, is a fun journey through the ups and downs he endured with incredible perseverance. You’ll leave the theater believing “If Ed Wood could follow his dream, so can I.”

Michael Arabian (Director) has directed and produced numerous world, West Coast, Los Angeles and New York premieres, and his productions have garnered over 50 awards. Most recently, he directed dance icon Leslie Caron in Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks at the Laguna Playhouse; Staging the Unstageable (centennial of the Armenian Genocide) at the Kirk Douglas; Red, starring John Vickery, at San Diego Rep; and God of Carnage at La Mirada. His production of Waiting for Godot at the Mark Taper Forum was honored with five Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Awards including outstanding production and direction; was nominated for 10 Ovation Awards, (the West Coast Tony) winning five, including best production; and was cited as one of the ten most memorable productions of 2012 seen in either New York or L.A. by Los Angeles Times theater critic Charles McNulty. Other Taper productions directed by Michael include Beckett’s Krapps Last Tape, Albee’s The Sandbox, Pinter’s A Slight Ace and workshops of new works. His site-specific company, Theatre InSite, formed a partnership with CBS (Radford) Studios, a first for L.A. theater, to produce live TV pilots (with Third Rock from the Sun picked up) and inventive, large-scale productions such as an updated Romeo and Juliet where audiences followed scenes and car chases through the backlot’s suburban streets, and The Trojan Women, set during the Gulf War and staged in 400,000 gallons of water at the old Gilligan’s Island Lagoon. His film King of the Ants is distributed by Vanguard Cinema.

RICK TELL ( Music,Lyrics, Book)  
In the 1970’s Rick Tell studied music composition with Giampaolo Bracali (Manhattan School of Music) and with Lehman Engel at the B.M.I. Theatre Workshop.  In the 1980’s he was producer/arranger for RCA, MCA and Atlantic Records with “Love Insurance” RCA 1981 reaching Billboard # 5. He was music producer/ composer for over fifty television and radio commercials as well as music producer/ composer/sound designer of international corporate live shows and video for Chrysler, Apple, General Motors, Jeep, Kodak, A.T.& T., Hewlett Packard, etc.  He also composed music for Mice in the Theater (Off Broadway). In the 1990’s he was the recipient of the “Children’s Video Award” and a regional Emmy award for The Reppies children’s television show on P.B.S. Since 2000 he has composed and produced numerous tracks for Cablevision Sterling Productions and won first place for his track “Zombies are Cool” in the AudioNews international competition 2011.

  BILL CHOTT (Book)

Bill is best known as "Mr. Laritate" on Disney's Wizards of Waverly Place. He played "Thomas" in the Johnny Knoxvile film The Ringer.  At the INNY Awards, he was awarded "Best Improv Coach", and won "Best Featured Actor in a Musical" at the Broadway World Awards for his work as "Fred Mertz" in I Love Lucy Live on Stage. Bill studied with Stephen Colbert at The Second City, and later performed in that theater's touring company with Tina Fey and Amy Poehler. Then he later worked with Colbert, Steve Carell and Louis C.K. on The Dana Carvey Show. His sci-fi big screen debut was as a Questarian with Alan Rickman in Galaxy Quest. He voiced characters on SNL's “Ambiguously Gay Duo” and “X-Presidents” cartoons.  Look for him soon opposite Lauren Holly in the film Marshall the Miracle Dog.

JOE GIORDANO (Book)  is a Nashville resident, an author and playwright. He was playwright-in-residence for the Tennessee Repertory Theater during their 2010 season, writing under the mentorship of John Patrick Shanley.  His play Religion and Rubber Ducks was named Best Original Play for 2008 by The Nashville Scene. His play She's Dead was produced by MadLab Theater during their 2013-14 season. His other produced plays include The Bad Trip,  Love, Sex, and All That Other Crap, Ticket, and others. 

LINDA TOLIVER AND GARY GUIDINGER (Producers)

As Producing Directors of Los Angeles' Zephyr Theater for 25 years, until moving on as Independent Producers in 2010, Linda and Gary produced many award-winning shows including the world premieres of Justin Tanner's Voice Lessons, starring Laurie Metcalf, French Stewart and Maile Flanagan in Los Angeles and New York, and the subsequent productions at LA's Circle X, Sacred Fools, Whitefire, NYC's Theater Row, most recently at Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater.  Other Zephyr theatre productions include Del Shores’ Sordid Lives, Southern Baptist Sissies, The Trials and Tribulations of a Trailer Trash Housewife (Associate Producers). At the Odyssey Theatre, they produced Tanner's Day Drinkers, Procreation, and Elliot Shoenman’s Aftermath starring Annie Potts, as well as the world premiere of Assisted Living, written and performed by the author of Wicked, Winnie Holzman and her husband, actor Paul Dooley. Their most recent production at the Odyssey was Tennessee Williams’ Kingdom of Earth directed by Michael Arabian. Their original workshop productions of Jim Brochu's The Last Session and Steve Schalchlin's The Big Voice: God or Merman? were optioned and moved to Off-Broadway for extended award-winning runs.  Other productions in NYC include La Ronde (Associate Producers), and Ethel Sings (Soho Rep's Walkerspace). They are currently working on Daybreak, by Joyce Van Dyke, slated for production in 2017.

Reparata Mazzola (Campaign Manager/Social Media) is a seasoned professional in a range of capacities in television, music and film. She is a member of the Writers Guild of America and was a member of Barry Manilow’s backup trio, Lady Flash. Reparata is a certified Social Media Strategist. She has conceived and produced marketing campaigns, promotional material, vlogs, video presentations and posts on all social media outlets.

Richard Marshall (Video) is an L.A. based filmmaker who has worked behind the scenes on large studio films, directed commercials and music videos, created video games, shot and edited documentaries and short films, written scripts and played in a R&R cover band. Richard made a mockumentary feature with a bunch of famous comedian. He is currently prepping a couple of indie features and TV/web series for his company, Intelligent Pictures.

Our Impact

Ed Wood the Musical will help raise the visibility of transgender and gender non-conforming people, and the issues these communities face. Ed Wood produced and directed the first film with a cross-dressing character. Beyond that, he was a pioneer when he starred in Glen or Glenda and the Angora-clad “Shirley” emerged shining a spotlight on transvestism. The producers plan to donate a portion of the full theatrical production net proceeds to LGBT community causes.  Rick Tell’s personal goal is to honor Ed Wood by awarding him a posthumous star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. And just for a few hours, Ed Wood the Musical is a welcome respite from the stress of your fast-paced, social media crammed day as you journey into Ed’s magical world.

    What We Need…

The funding from the campaign will be used to produce the musical in an independent theater in Los Angeles. You’ve gone to see a play, but It takes more than a village to produce it! Here are some basic line items.

CREATIVES:  Composer, Writer, Producers, Director, Casting, Actors, Musicians 

DESIGNERS:  Set, Costume, Sound, Lighting, Choreography, Makeup, Graphic

CREW: Prop Master, Construction, Rigging, Electricians, Lighting, Stage Managers, Production Manager, Carpenters, Stage Hands, Wardrobe, Technical Directors, Production Assistants

RELATED  PRODUCTION COSTS: Set building materials, paint, lumber, Equipment, Furniture rental, Props, Alien/creature fabrication, Rehearsal Space, Theater Rental. House Manager, Photographer, Publicity/Marketing, Printing, Programs, Posters, Advertising, Social Media, Insurance, Administrative, Contingency.

  WHAT YOU GET

   RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Every theatrical project begins with the challenge of assembling an experienced team to produce a high quality, successful show.  We have already met that challenge. Our director, writers and producers are seasoned professionals with over 100 years of combined experience in theater. Collectively, they have surmounted the hurdles that a production can encounter. We also have included a contingency in the budget for any unforeseen costs. However, all our experts know that the biggest challenge is being underfunded. That’s why we are creating this Indiegogo campaign. You can be a part of making a musical history by helping fund a show that could run for years to come.  Again, think Rocky Horror Picture Show!

·  Contribute to the next steps of this journey.

·  Spread the word! Share our campaign with friends and family in person or on social media. There are icons next to the video on the page.

·  Follow us and share any our social media accounts to (Facebook, Twitter).

·  Come to the show!  You helped make it happen!

story:
THE PROJECT

This project started in New York City, talking about Black Lifes and the difference to Germany to the US. In Germany race and racism, has a different sound to it, a different horrible past. But the silence about racism, didn't destroy the discrimination of people in Germany, it made it more structural and subtle. Not just the politics have to face this issue, but the everyday people, parents, teachers, friends and all the people who represent others. We asked ourselves as Theaterartist, what can we do? How are we taking part in this stereotypical way of representing, of telling stories and repeating the habits of old traditions? We had to ask ourselves, had to look into the practice of theater in Germany and the US, we looked into media and representation in general and wanted to break those stereotypical ways of thinking. 

This is a process, we just started and we hope to win more and more people to share this reflection on ourselves and the human behavior of discrimination and judgment. How can we not fall into the trap of just traditional behavior, that sets us as humans apart and doesn't bring us together? We would love, to have you support us, with your insights, with your own perspective, with your hopes and dreams, with your critics and worries - we are looking for inclusion and a common community, where we will discover new ways of living together. 

Hedda Gabler, and many other 'classical' plays in German Theaters are cast White Actors only. The stereotypical idea, that these roles have to have a certain skin color is still strongly represented, but not talked about. We will cast this wonderful play of Henrik Ibsen (Set: Kristiania, Norway. 1870's) with an all Afro-German ensemble and want to change the closed up perspectives of an idea, that skin color detects the character. The character and soul is made out of other material than skin. But living in a world where race still matters, due that past and present of our behavior - we can't just ignore the fact, that racism isn't alive. It will grow underneath, if we don't take it by it's horn and ask ourselves, what is our common responsibility?! 

Please help us to bring awareness into the media world, of how powerful representation is, and how we form our thinking, with they way we tell stories.

 

 

How you can help?

As you might know, Theater and Performance is a fugitive moment, that you can not really take with you. The thing you will take with you, is the experience of that moment, that made you laugh, cry or be angry. It can be so powerful, that this moment could change your life, or will hit you like BAM - one day, suddenly and you still carry that magic this art form with you.

To do this work, we need money, to focus our time and craft on those issues, we want to reflect on. We need to space, to rehearse in. We need platforms to share it with a large audience. We need equipment to make it more powerful, if needed and we need you as the supporters to help us make this happen.  

 

The process

 In August 2016 we will hold an intense workshop in Berlin, to create the our own adaption of the play, we will read, talk and discuss the issues of the play and beyond. Then we will explore a sight specific blocking, where the lines between performer and audience is reduced and maybe even, at some moments removed. We will have after talks with the audience and will explore also in conversation, what is means to have an all Black Cast in an classical play in Germany. What perspectives will we discover there? You are invited to be part of this process and we hope to see you there!!

In 2017 we then continue our journey in co-production with a German Theater and will present Hedda Gabler in Berlin to a large audience. With luck and support, we might come along your town too! But maybe you would love to visit us in Berlin too.

To make this all happen, we need your support!!

Every cent is helpful and will support us in this journey! 

THANK YOU!!!!!

DANKE!!!!!!

 

WHO WE ARE?

Label Noir: 
The Afro-German artist collective label Noir was founded in Berlin in 2009, artistic directors are the actresses Lara-Sophie Milagro and Dela Dabulamanzi. Label Noir sees one of its main tasks, to create an artistic space where skin color and/or origin of Black Actors, are not limited to generate strangeness and exoticism, while the skin color and/or origin White Actors has universal significance. Behind this is the desire for a theater where the Actor may not embody their skin color, but their humanity. Playing theater is a privilege, a powerful activity that we want to use to reveal new perspectives. We believe that a change of perspective on stage can cause a change of perspective in real life. A look at the history of theater - the latest example is in Germany in 2011 for the first time made publicly, critically discussed blackface uf our stages - nourishes this faith.
www.labelnoir.net

​The Private Theatre:
The Private Theatre is a not-for-profit group of Artists committed to raw, intimate and startling productions of classical, contemporary and devised work. They believe that authorial initiative in the theater can emerge from any theatrical discipline; that deeper collaborations create better theater; and that those collaborations may be forged across cultures, aesthetics and disciplines. In common with all the arts, theater should aspire to work that affects its audiences deeply, engaging them in encounters that make a profound and ensuring impression. They embrace this mission, and devote themselves to finding the texts, stagecraft and collaborators to support them in its pursuit.
www.theprivatetheatre.org

Label Gray: 
Label Gray was founded in 2011 as The Shades Of Gray by Heidi Mueller-Smith and Miriam Ibrahim, who met during the production Escape From Happiness, in which Heidi was directing and Miriam was acting. Both became dear Friends and shared the vision to create a space where people and their issues aren't labeled as black or white, where diversity and complexity is celebrated. A platform where we could go on the hunt for the truth which lies in the gray - an area where the lines and borders are blurry, that blurriness we want not to become straightened and 'normal' we want to see with it and grow beyond borders.
www.labelgray.org
 

The Director:

John Gould Rubin is a founding member of The Private Theatre for which he currently serves as Artistic Director. Recent projects for the company include a radically explicit deconstruction of Strindberg’s one-act Playing with Fire, staged at The Box (the notorious sexual night club) and the 2010 site-specific production of Ibsen’s Hedda Gabler staged in a 19th c townhouse for 25 people per night. This season he presented and directed Turn Me Loose, a presentation of the comedy, activism and life of Dick Gregory with Joe Morton starring as the legendary black comedian.  He recently staged Outside Mullingar for the Dorset Theatre Festival and the premiere of Michael Ricigliano’s Queen For A Day off Broadway and an environmental production of The Cherry Orchard for The Actors Studio with Ellen Burstyn in which he surrounded the audience with the action of the play. He is in development with I, Peer, a re-imagining of Ibsen’s Peer Gynt which he workshopped at the International Ibsen Festival at The National Theatre of Norway and at The Old Vic in London; Electra Despierta/Awakes, by renowned Mexican playwright Ximena Escalante, developed in a bi-lingual version through CalArts. He commissioned a new translation of Brecht’s second play, Drums in the Night, which he has been developing with Classical Theater of Harlem and LAByrinth Theater Company. John served as Co-Artistic (with John Ortiz and Philip Seymour Hoffman) and Executive Director of LAByrinth, for which he directed the premieres of Philip Roth in Khartoum and Penalties & Interest (both as part of Public/LAB at The Public Theater); STopless; The Trail of Her Inner Thigh by Erin Cressida Wilson; John Patrick Shanley's A Winter Party; and co-created and directed two devised pieces: Dreaming in Tongues; and Mémoire. Other projects co-created or directed include The Erotica Project for The Public Theatre; Trial By Water for Ma-Yi; A Taste of Honey at Playwrights Horizons; Blood in the Sink at Urban Stages; both A Matter Of Choice and NAMI for Partial Comfort; Rinne Groff’s The Ruby Sunrise, Dark of the Moon, Rebecca Gilman’s The Land of Little Horses; Frank McGuiness’ Factory Girls; Timberlake Wertenbaker’s Three Birds Alighting on a Field, Ivanov, The Crucible, Richard Nelson’s Franny’s Way, David Mamet’s Boston Marriage, Picnic, Israel Horvitz’ North Shore Fish, Reza de Wet’s Three Sisters, Two and Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead for the Stella Adler Conservatory; a radical Hamlet with 7 Hamlets for Columbia’s MFA Program, and he has directed for both EST’s and Naked Angel’s Marathons. This season he will direct an environmental production of Mother Courage for The Harold Clurman Lab which also produced his two-theater production of “The Seagull,” and he recently directed a multi-media, stage adaptation of “Double Indemnity” for The Old Globe in San Diego; Riding the Midnight Express, Billy Hayes’ personal tale of imprisonment and escape in Turkey (memorialized in the film Midnight Express,) at the Edinburgh Festival, off-Broadway and at the Soho Theater in London; the Off-Broadway production of The Fartiste, a musical he also premiered for The Private Theatre in 2006 at the New York International Fringe Festival (winner of Outstanding Musical award); Jack's Back, a new musical about Jack the Ripper; Open Marriage (a site-specific, one-woman show about Elsie Clews Parsons at Venfort Hall, in Lenox, Mass., in co-production with Shakespeare & Co.); Little Doc at Rattlestick, The Importance of Being Ernest for Twin Tiers Theatre; and In the Daylight at the McGinn-Cazale. He wrote (and played Ivan Boesky in) The Predators' Ball (collaborating with Karole Armitage and David Salle) for the Teatro Comunale in Florence, Italy, and at BAM's Next Wave Festival.  Mr. Rubin is in development of three unique devised theater pieces, one about Sargent Shriver and the development of The Peace Corps; another about the political polarization of America based upon the consciousness philosophy of Bernard Lonergan and a third on the iconoclastic life of Erik Satie. He directed his first film, Almost Home, for Trigger Street Independent, which was presented at The Berkshire Film Festival.

 

The Ensemble:

Lara-Sophie Milagro as Hedda Gabler

Tyron Rickets as Commissioner Brack

Asad Schwarz-Msesilamba as Eilert Løvborg

Dela Dabulamansi as Juliane Tesman

Miriam Ibrahim as Thea Elvsted

Maya Alban-Zapata as Berte
story_txt:
THE PROJECT
This project started in New York City, talking about Black Lifes and the difference to Germany to the US. In Germany race and racism, has a different sound to it, a different horrible past. But the silence about racism, didn't destroy the discrimination of people in Germany, it made it more structural and subtle. Not just the politics have to face this issue, but the everyday people, parents, teachers, friends and all the people who represent others. We asked ourselves as Theaterartist, what can we do? How are we taking part in this stereotypical way of representing, of telling stories and repeating the habits of old traditions? We had to ask ourselves, had to look into the practice of theater in Germany and the US, we looked into media and representation in general and wanted to break those stereotypical ways of thinking. 
This is a process, we just started and we hope to win more and more people to share this reflection on ourselves and the human behavior of discrimination and judgment. How can we not fall into the trap of just traditional behavior, that sets us as humans apart and doesn't bring us together? We would love, to have you support us, with your insights, with your own perspective, with your hopes and dreams, with your critics and worries - we are looking for inclusion and a common community, where we will discover new ways of living together. 
Hedda Gabler, and many other 'classical' plays in German Theaters are cast White Actors only. The stereotypical idea, that these roles have to have a certain skin color is still strongly represented, but not talked about. We will cast this wonderful play of Henrik Ibsen (Set: Kristiania, Norway. 1870's) with an all Afro-German ensemble and want to change the closed up perspectives of an idea, that skin color detects the character. The character and soul is made out of other material than skin. But living in a world where race still matters, due that past and present of our behavior - we can't just ignore the fact, that racism isn't alive. It will grow underneath, if we don't take it by it's horn and ask ourselves, what is our common responsibility?! 
Please help us to bring awareness into the media world, of how powerful representation is, and how we form our thinking, with they way we tell stories.
  How you can help?
As you might know, Theater and Performance is a fugitive moment, that you can not really take with you. The thing you will take with you, is the experience of that moment, that made you laugh, cry or be angry. It can be so powerful, that this moment could change your life, or will hit you like BAM - one day, suddenly and you still carry that magic this art form with you.
To do this work, we need money, to focus our time and craft on those issues, we want to reflect on. We need to space, to rehearse in. We need platforms to share it with a large audience. We need equipment to make it more powerful, if needed and we need you as the supporters to help us make this happen.  
 

The process
 In August 2016 we will hold an intense workshop in Berlin, to create the our own adaption of the play, we will read, talk and discuss the issues of the play and beyond. Then we will explore a sight specific blocking, where the lines between performer and audience is reduced and maybe even, at some moments removed. We will have after talks with the audience and will explore also in conversation, what is means to have an all Black Cast in an classical play in Germany. What perspectives will we discover there? You are invited to be part of this process and we hope to see you there!!
In 2017 we then continue our journey in co-production with a German Theater and will present Hedda Gabler in Berlin to a large audience. With luck and support, we might come along your town too! But maybe you would love to visit us in Berlin too.
To make this all happen, we need your support!!
Every cent is helpful and will support us in this journey! 
THANK YOU!!!!!
DANKE!!!!!!

story:
Revel’s End is a mashup of Shakespeare’s last play with original R&B/pop music and collaboratively devised contemporary dance. Set in a Brooklyn night club, Revel’s End is neither musical nor play-with- music, but a new hybrid style: part concert, part play, and part dance party. The weekend of October 20th, we’ll be staging the party to end all parties—and you're invited.

If you can find the entrance to Williamsburg’s Standard Toy Kraft, an unmarked door in the side of a warehouse, you’ll weave your way up several dark and graffiti-ed staircases before entering the dimly-lit hall where Jared Arnold DJs his brand new album, written for Revel’s End and never performed before. You’ll sip drinks and disappear into the blissful anonymity of the dance floor—but, before you know it, the spirit Ariel appears as if (or maybe actually!) by magic, and interrupts the party with a literal storm of light, magic, music, and glitter—whisking you away to the paradise of Prospero’s enchanted island.


Producing theater is New York is exciting, empowering—and expensive!

This is my first production in New York City. I’m starting from nothing, but trying to make something totally new that’s bold and exciting—and accessible to a wide and diverse group of people. Absolutely anything you can give, no matter how big or small, helps immensely and I would greatly appreciate your support.

Your donation will:
1) give us a place to rehearse and perform, 2) help us create a unique and captivating setup that will bring the magic of this play to life, 3) pay our talented performers and crew, and 4) help us market ourselves to a broad audience, and let as many people experience our dance party as possible.

Your generosity will enable us to create work that pushes boundaries and asks important questions. We eagerly invite you to join us, to take part in these conversations and become our long-term collaborator. We have put together some great perks—from signed posters to tickets and free drinks, and even a special, exclusive performance—to say thank you for joining us on this exciting journey. Can I count you in?


Here in the United States in 2016, we’re living in a fragile and potentially perilous political time. We live in a country made up entirely of immigrants and refugees, whether we got here yesterday or two hundred years ago. Great people of power come to the United States for safety or the freedom to speak their minds, and find themselves oppressed and discriminated against. We are at a moment when the lives and livelihoods of the very people who’ve made up our country and our history are threatened.

In the original text of The Tempest, Prospero, the reluctant ruler of Milan, is exiled from his home and finds himself in paradise—trapped on an island with no earthly responsibilities. Revel’s End is that paradise—the party we all look for when reality seems unbearable. Prospero’s island is fraught, as he enslaves and terrorizes the island’s inhabitants—and our reality today is fraught, too, with our own nation’s inhabitants faced with imminent oppression and violence. 

Revel’s End will offer audiences an escape from a tumultuous reality, and then ask that they consider the question: freedom from reality, or freedom in reality? 

Your support will allow us to provoke, explore, and question. We are looking for a voice—and we are asking to hear your voices. It's with enthusiasm, gratitude, and curiosity that we invite you to join in our conversation. 


Grace Herman-Holland, Director
Grace is a new NYC-based director. She is focused on interdisciplinary performances that bend genres and blend cultures. She studies and performs nihonbuyo dance, the style of which heavily influences her productions. She recently graduated from Wesleyan University.

Jared Arnold, Composer
Jared is a composer and sound designer based in Brooklyn, New York. Originally a French horn player, he now performs on a wide range of instruments. Jared studied music at Brown University's Computer Music & Multimedia program, and his compositions seamlessly merge classical training with electronic experimentation.

Bereket Mengistu - Prospero
Bereket is originally from Ethiopia. He got his certificate from Ethiopian National Theater in musical Theater. Recent roles include Bill Sykes in Oliver, Marcel (ensemble) in South Pacific, Matey in Dear Brutus and Oedipus in Oedipus the King.

Brinda Dixit - Ariel 
Brinda is an actress and Bharatanatyam dancer in NYC. Favorite performance venues include the Gym at Judson, Access Theatre, City Hall, Villa La Pietra in Florence, Italy, and a small village near Chennai, India. She has a B.F.A in Drama from NYU Tisch. 

Will Van Moss - Ferdinand
Will has most recently been seen in Kiss It, Make It Better at The New Ohio Theatre and previously also performed in New York as Jigger in the musical Carousel at the John Cullum Theatre. He also performed in London (UK) as Francis Flute in the Avenue House's production of A Midsummer Night's Dream and The Bloomsbury Theatre's production of Romeo and Juliet as Peter. Will has performed all over Europe and in NYC and cannot wait to be part of this incredibly innovative and exciting production.

Kanae Miyahara - Miranda
Kanae is from Japan, and recently graduated from SUNY Purchase College and where she received a B.A.  in Theatre and Performance. She previously performed in her senior project Water Girls, and made a short film and a stage production. This is going to be her first performance after graduation. she is thrilled to be part of this exciting production. 

Jaz Zepatos - Caliban/Alonso
Jaz is an actress/singer/improviser from the sunshine state, and is wickedly excited to rock out as Caliban. Some of her favorite roles include Natalie in Next to Normal, Gloria in Boeing Boeing, and Lauren in Circle Mirror Transformation.  She can hoola-hoop for days.

Meghan Crosby - Antonio/Stephano
With an MFA in Playwriting from the University of Glasgow, Meghan wears many hats in the theatre world. She writes, acts, and choreographs often for the American Renaissance Theatre Company, for whom she is a board member. Performance highlights include Line Open Next (NYC), The Beeping (NYC), As Soon as I Knew (NYC), Spelling Bee (Glasgow), and Eurydice (Boston). In 2013, she wrote, directed, and choreographed the movement theatre production Sleeping Soldiers, which received four stars at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and was a finalist for Amnesty International’s Freedom of Expression Award.

Elisha Mudly - Sebastian/Trinculo
Elisha hails from South Africa and is a trained actress, singer, dancer and musician. She graduated with full colours from a post graduate degree at Rhodes University; has performed alongside Physical Theatre King, Andrew Buckland and has made an appearance on Homeland. She plays Daisy, the sassy fashionista, in the Motion Capture animation series, Silly Seasons and has high hopes for her new venture in New York City.


Every one of the artists who's dedicated their time, energy, and heart to this production is young, brave, innovative, and willing to take some serious risks. We are building the world of this play almost entirely from scratch, blending forms of dance to create a brand new and specific form of movement. We are not falling back on processes that are familiar, but instead are working in collaboration to devise a new way of working that is honest and surprising, serious and joyful.

We are working in a city that's filled with ambitious, driven people of all backgrounds. It's harder to put up work here than almost anyplace else, because of limited resources, money, time, and space—and it's a highly competitive city, full of different voices. But that is the very reason we've chosen to create this work here in New York City. Where else better represents the immense diversity of the American people? Where else can we open up our conversation to such a wide range of other voices? It is here, in the cultural capital of our nation, that we want our voices to be heard.

We invite the challenges of new beginnings, of time and place. We readily invite you to join us in combatting our obstacles with passion, experimentation, and creativity.


We want you to join our dance party!

You can:

  • Check out our website, and join our email list to sign up for updates and media!
  • Follow us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and join the Revel’s End conversation.
  • Share this campaign using the Indigogo share tools below.
  • Spread the word!
  • Come see Revel’s End at Standard Toy Kraft, October 20th-23rd!

Thank you so much in advance! We can’t wait to see you there!

She graduated with full colours from a post graduate degree at Rhodes University; has performed alongside Physical Theatre King, Andrew Buckland and has made an appearance on Homeland. She plays Daisy, the sassy fashionista, in the Motion Capture animation series, Silly Seasons and has high hopes for her new venture in New York City.







Every one of the artists who's dedicated their time, energy, and heart to this production is young, brave, innovative, and willing to take some serious risks. We are building the world of this play almost entirely from scratch, blending forms of dance to create a brand new and specific form of movement. We are not falling back on processes that are familiar, but instead are working in collaboration to devise a new way of working that is honest and surprising, serious and joyful.We are working in a city that's filled with ambitious, driven people of all backgrounds. It's harder to put up work here than almost anyplace else, because of limited resources, money, time, and space—and it's a highly competitive city, full of different voices. But that is the very reason we've chosen to create this work here in New York City. Where else better represents the immense diversity of the American people? Where else can we open up our conversation to such a wide range of other voices? It is here, in the cultural capital of our nation, that we want our voices to be heard.
We invite the challenges of new beginnings, of time and place. We readily invite you to join us in combatting our obstacles with passion, experimentation, and creativity.



 
We want you to join our dance party!You can:

Check out our website, and join our email list to sign up for updates and media!


Follow us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and join the Revel’s End conversation.

Share this campaign using the Indigogo share tools below.

Spread the word!


Come see Revel’s End at Standard Toy Kraft, October 20th-23rd!

Thank you so much in advance! We can’t wait to see you there!

story:
MARILYNMACHINE

MARILYNMACHINE creates work for the theatre that is a reflection of our times.

We need to raise £700 to register our company with the Government (Limited by Guarantee) with a view to becoming a Registered Charity. This process will be managed by the reputable accountancy firm MacIntyre Hudson. Any funds raised above this amount will contribute towards other administration costs such as a website and ITC membership.

We plan to take 'Have You Eyes?' to Innsbruck, Austria in March 17. In addition to this, we plan a major project in Liverpool for 2017. Your support will enable the company to generate funding from major sponsors. 

Any contribution, no matter how humble, will be gratefully received.
