story:
Last Dance is a new play, combining theater, projection, dance and music that details one angel's complicated and liberating transference into human form occurring in real time over the course of an evening.

Last Dance explores some of the great questions we face as living beings including suicide, spiritual purpose and the importance of living a life with meaning. The characters journey invites the audience to ponder what really happens on the “other side” of life after death or before birth.  The question of "how precious life really is" is woven throughout the thought process of this once divine being incarnating in order to feel human love. The guardian angel that warned her not to take that leap is in tow, by turns vicariously living through her charge and also protecting and attempting to bring her back. Last Dance is transformative theatrical experience, which in the end encourages the audience to take hold of their own choices, suspend their beliefs and disbeliefs and live their lives to the fullest, trusting the divine wisdom in each and every heartbeat.

This project premieres now fully produced and beautifully designed as a new play in the artists hometown of Portland, Oregon and as a curated selection in the Fertile Ground Festival. The play opens on January 19th 2017 and will have 8 performances. Our Festival Dates: Jan 19, 21, 27 @ 9:30; Jan 20, 26, 28 @ 7:30; Jan 22, 29 @ 4pm

Last Dance already has an international life, begun with winning a playwrighting contest in Scotland, re-imagined as the umbrella piece for a theater fest in Australia, to the 2015 preview in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico.  The acclaim and community reaction in San Miguel sparked the vision for this Portland Premiere with a fully realized design and performance elements in place.  It extends to the desire to tour, and bring this powerful work to communities and people across the US and beyond in the near future.

Who We Are

Last Dance was written by Sky Yeager - a playwright who lives in the “now”.   His energy is infectious, compelling; his focus riveting, complete.

Jaime Lee Christiana and Kat Macmillan are the plays performers.

Kat Macmillan is a dancer and performer with a deep commitment to transformational experience in life and work.  She has performed extensively as a Butoh artist, both solo and as part of the Vangeline Theater, a NewYork City Dance company led by Butoh artist Vangeline.  Kat’s passion includes her continued work in experimental physical theater as well as vocal composition and performance.

Jaime Lee Christiana's wide range artistic career spans from her life events to pop-culture. Christiana, has formed a body of work through a range of media, including dance, theater, video, acting, sculpture and painting.

Jonathan Walters (the play’s director) founded Hand2Mouth theatre in 2000 and has since than premiered 18 major new works, as well as site-specific and commissioned short pieces in the Portland area, and toured these works regionally, nationally and abroad, presenting at today's leading venues for contemporary theatre performance.

“Free Will was a gift, from the Grace of God. You and you alone were given this. You were not created to feel small and worthless, depressed or ashamed. You were made to be victorious, the ones who could choose to revel in the celebration of life. We were more than a little jealous... there was some murmuring in the ranks to be sure.”–the Angel Zephon in Last Dance

Audience Impact

“What an amazing experience tonight to see "Last Dance", it brought out raw emotions in all of us, joy, excitement, passion, despair, feeling of life, it brought tears to our eyes. I was so moved to see how my daughters were brought to tears as they were passionately inspired by this amazing play. I hope that it touches you and your family as it touched me and my family. “–Rachelle, San Miguel de Allende

“It was the ultimate existential dialogue about true spirituality, the psychology of human existence, and the paradox of life and death.”–Bill, San Miguel de Allende

Jaime Lee’s engagement with the audience was nothing short of fantastic! She was at once, erotic, beautiful, contained, and huge. Her dynamic range was something to behold. Kat simply flowed. I couldn't take my eyes off her, a wonder to behold. My wife and I were in rapture from the first word to the last. –Chuck, San Miguel de Allende

One of the best productions I’ve seen. The profoundly beautiful script, stunning visuals and the great talent on stage kept me immersed in the story. A beautiful ode to life. I laughed. I cried. My 17 year old loved it. I am taking the 13 year old this weekend to see it. I am not exaggerating: DON´T MISS IT! –Vicky, San Miguel de Allende

Last Dance is more than a play. It’s a spiritual experience. I was crying throughout the play, I was moved, inspired, awakened. Last Dance cracked open my heart, and made me laugh. Last Dance is definitely the most moving performance I have ever witnessed. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone - both adults and children alike. My 7-year old step-daughter went to both performances with me, fell in love with the actresses and, I believe that she somehow received the beauty of the play on a deeper, more emotional level.–Brandon, San Miguel de Allende

We are grateful to be offering art to the world in these trying times of political / environmental / racial unrest. The change is painful, yet necessary. We are here because we believe that art can help! Last Dance is an original multimedia play that raises important questions and asks the audience to consider deep issues of our present time; the role of spirituality vs. organized religion, the impact of suicide and questions about the value of life. Our goal is to bring those topics deeply into the audience's mind and heart via a rich work of performance. That’s what art does. That’s what we want to create. Hope. Endurance. Depth. Courage.

What We Need and What You Get

All funds raised during out Indiegogo campaign will help us complete the final costs for the premiere of Last Dance in Portland, which are;

  • Scenic design and materials with the show intended for future touring.
  • Rental of well-respected dance center Headwaters for two weeks of performances.
  • Final portion of Actor and technician pay; to give a fair and just wage for artistic efforts and hours.

Perks for donating range from big hugs of gratitude to personalized concerts just for you!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially. But you can still help us by sharing this page with your people.

Also, if you live in the Portland Metro area and would like to become a volunteer for the show and festival than email us at lastdance2017@gmail.com

story:
Cuando varios artistas se juntan para crear un sueño, algo llamado magia sucede. A si ha sucedido con este proyecto llamado Pop-Up Theater.

En el 2007, después de una visita a la ciudad de Madrid, donde viví la  experiencia de Teatro Breve por primera vez, se me metió en la cabeza que esta sería una gran idea para la ciudad de Los Ángeles. Desde entonces, Teatro Breve ha sido un éxito en España, México, Venezuela, Argentina, Colombia, Perú; y en Estados Unidos tiene ya varios años sucediendo en la ciudad de Miami, confirmándome así que yo estaba en lo cierto. Por varios años, conversé y conversé al respecto con mucha gente, hasta que finalmente entusiasmé a un grupito a que creyera en esto tanto como yo, y así llegamos hoy a trabajar juntos para traer Teatro Breve a la meca del cine.

 Justamente,  en una ciudad donde la competencia en todos los oficios relacionados con storytelling y el entretenimiento, es desafiante, sabemos por experiencia adquirida en otros países, que el formato de Teatro Breve ha sido una respuesta para muchos artistas que no desean esperar inertes por una “oportunidad”, sino quieren ser el motor generador de su propia suerte. Estamos seguros este gran concepto de arte, entretenimiento y networking,  será muy bien acogido por su comunidad creativa; y  sin duda le abrirá una puerta mas al talento latinoamericano en todas las diferentes disciplinas artísticas para darse a conocer en Hollywood.

Es por ello, que estamos organizando la primera y segunda edición de Teatro Breve en Los Ángeles, y lo llamaremos POP-UP Theater. Estas dos primeras ediciones contarán con 6 piezas de 15 minutos cada una, sucediendo simultáneamente, y hasta 6 funciones por pieza cada noche. Su variada temática le dará cabida al disfrute del gusto de todos, con risas, llantos, suspiros, suspenso y hasta música en vivo. Sin olvidarnos de los aperitivos y las risas con los amigos en el bello patio central de Lilith’s Corner en Dowtown LA, el espacio anfitrión de esta gran aventura.

Cada mes le traeremos al público una nueva temporada de espectáculos, durante  dos fines de semana consecutivos, completamente bilingüe, y hasta trilingüe, con obras nuevas y shows, tanto de escritores, directores y actores locales como de talento hispano de exportación. 

Será una ventana de exposición, de intercambio cultural, de teatro, arte y entretenimiento. Un espacio para mostrar el talento de guionistas, directores, actores, comediantes, cantantes y bailarines, de nuestros países latinos, a la vez que nos damos la mano con los representantes del arte y la cultura del país anfitrión.  Una manera diferente y entretenida de vivir el teatro y espectáculos en vivo.

Es un sueño delicioso… y ambicioso, y nos hemos puesto la tarea de hacerlo realidad! Pero nos falta un ingrediente fundamental para materializarlo… Tu apoyo!!… 

Y no el de “adelante amigo tu puedes” sino uno un poco mas pro-activo… Patrocinio!

Pop-Up Theater @Lilith’s Corner, será un espacio generoso, divertido, creativo y gran generador de oportunidades de trabajo para nuestros artistas, pero para hacerlo posible necesitamos tu aporte.

No tiene que ser mucho lo que pongas, si logramos ser muchos los que pongamos, así que no te preocupes si piensas que tu contribución es pequeña, porque cada dollar cuenta!

Y por favor ayúdanos a regar la voz, porque no hay tiempo que perder, la primera edición ya esta en camino!

Ayúdanos a apoyar al arte y nuestro talento!

Ayúdanos a expandir nuestra cultura y la proyección de nuestros artistas en USA!

Los artistas involucrados en esta primera edición somos muchos.

  • Ileanna Simancas: Organizadora del evento (actriz, productora, escritora y ahora directora de una de las piezas) Venezuela
  • Prakriti Maduro: Organizadora del evento (actriz, productora, escritora y directora de una de las piezas) Venezuela
  • Orlette Ruiz: Consultora, y directora de una de las piezas. México
  • Jesus M. Rodriguez: Director, actor y escritor de una de las piezas. Venezuela
  • Actores: Eloisa Maturén, Maria Elena Heredia, Maria Elena Laas, Eddi Martinez, Alex Ruiz, Ilza Rosario, Salvador Chacon, Alex Ruiz, Ellie Araiza, Ernie G, Andrea Cortes, Nina Cortes.

story:
It's kind of a funny story...

After our smash Hollywood Fringe Festival hit (as called out by Time Out LA), it's time for BAE Theatre's next production to make its mark. And we need YOUR help. 

  • Emily Keaney and Isabella Petrini, lifelong college friends and theatre compatriots, founded BAE Theatre in early 2015 on the principal to instigate and generate change in audiences, the community and the world. 
  • Now, BAE Theatre is ready for its next exciting venture, the 2001 New York Fringe Festival hit, "Matt & Ben" by comedy genius Mindy Kaling and her equally hilarious bestie, Brenda Withers. This one hour comedy follows the beautiful friendship between young Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and what happens when the mysterious original script of "Good Will Hunting" drops down from the ceiling into the middle of Ben's apartment. Hilarity erupts; chaos ensues. 
  • Since this is our first time producing a published work, there are additional expenses to be covered, especially as we continue to elevate our production quality in a raised effort to bring exceptional theatre to our community. We are counting our amazing supporters to help bring this beyond hilarious commentary on privilege to the stage, give women a chance to tell this story, and show the community a glimpse inside the friendship of these fascinating people and writers. 

What We Need & What You Get

This project means more than we can express. If you can help us, we want to reward you:

  • In comparison to our last production, we are dealing with more costs that are necessary in making "Matt & Ben" even better. Some of these costs include production rights, venue, insurance, design, construction, costumes, rehearsal space, ticketing services, maintenance and eventually additional entry and venue costs as we move the show to the 2016 Hollywood Fringe Festival. It's nearly overwhelming, but we know with your help, we can bring this show to life! 
  • Isabella and Emily have style. We also love free things. So, we're using the golden rule mentality to treat our supporters the way we want to be treated: with lots of amazing goodies and perks. From some of our favorite stationery treats, to VIP advanced tickets to our play, and other fabulous shows about town, check out our perks to see what fabulous goodies could be traveling to a mailbox near you. Plus, in keeping with the theme of the show, we are inducing some 90s themed incentives in this campaign!
  • Every bit of money raised will be put towards the show. We have a lot of expenses, so even if we don't reach our goal, we will be putting all funds towards the show no matter what! Our fate is in your hands. But seriously. 

The "Why Now"

You might be wondering why we want to put on a play about the world's most-loved Matt and Ben:

  • We spent a lot of time researching what we wanted to put up as our next production. As a result of our search, we were found a show that we loved (and still want to produce), but shortly after stumbled upon the script for "Matt & Ben." We fell in love with the play and knew in an instant that our pretentious, hipster, film-culture-loving LA audience would not be able to pass up it up. However, the show speaks to a wide demographic. Fans of "The Mindy Project," will be surprised and delighted to see a theatrical work co-written by the hilarious, talented Mindy Kaling. It's amazing and inspiring to see how both she and the title characters have risen to the levels of fame and "success" mentioned in the play. 
  • We are excited to present this play with an exceptional creative team. Although the play focuses on two of the world's most successful male actors, the script is very clear that they be played by two women. This production is directed, acted and produced by women. The whole team is thrilled to bring this kind of story to an LA audience and we can't wait to see what happens when we do.
  • Our journey with "Matt and Ben" begins this May at the Attic Theatre in Mid City, but we are hoping it continues at the Hollywood Fringe Festival in June. With your help, we can bring another hit production to the Fringe audience! We're putting every ounce of energy we have into making this show the best it can be. It's not going to be easy, but it will be fun! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't help financially. Money is rough and we know that first hand. But, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Sharing is caring. Please share this campaign with anyone remotely interested in Matt Damon or Ben Affleck--or Mindy Kaling or Brenda Withers. Share it with anyone that loves theatre. Share it with anyone that has money. You never know who's out there that might want to see this show. Repost the link to our campaign on Facebook. Email it to someone over age forty-five. Text them to check their email. Text them to go have a power lunch and then tell them about the show. 
  • We're always on the lookout for other goods and services we can use to make the show better and better. We need resources for set building: materials and builders. It's always good to have a backup rehearsal space. Own a restaurant or bar and either want to feed a production team or partner with us for a fundraising event? We want to talk. We may be looking for some specific props in the near future as well, and borrowing costs less than renting or buying. Plus, your couch could be famous.
  • Come support us at the show! We know it's not until the spring, but we'll be working on it with everything we've got until then, and we can't wait to see you there. Of course you'll be getting all kinds of social media reminders, but mark your calendar now and be sure to buy tickets as soon as they go live! Take someone on a date to the show. This is going to be a great date night show.

There's more to friendship than "Good Will." And with your help, we can make it possible.

This one hour comedy follows the beautiful friendship between young Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and what happens when the mysterious original script of "Good Will Hunting" drops down from the ceiling into the middle of Ben's apartment. Hilarity erupts; chaos ensues.  Since this is our first time producing a published work, there are additional expenses to be covered, especially as we continue to elevate our production quality in a raised effort to bring exceptional theatre to our community. We are counting our amazing supporters to help bring this beyond hilarious commentary on privilege to the stage, give women a chance to tell this story, and show the community a glimpse inside the friendship of these fascinating people and writers. 
   What We Need & What You Get This project means more than we can express. If you can help us, we want to reward you:  In comparison to our last production, we are dealing with more costs that are necessary in making "Matt & Ben" even better. Some of these costs include production rights, venue, insurance, design, construction, costumes, rehearsal space, ticketing services, maintenance and eventually additional entry and venue costs as we move the show to the 2016 Hollywood Fringe Festival. It's nearly overwhelming, but we know with your help, we can bring this show to life!  Isabella and Emily have style. We also love free things. So, we're using the golden rule mentality to treat our supporters the way we want to be treated: with lots of amazing goodies and perks. From some of our favorite stationery treats, to VIP advanced tickets to our play, and other fabulous shows about town, check out our perks to see what fabulous goodies could be traveling to a mailbox near you. Plus, in keeping with the theme of the show, we are inducing some 90s themed incentives in this campaign! Every bit of money raised will be put towards the show. We have a lot of expenses, so even if we don't reach our goal, we will be putting all funds towards the show no matter what! Our fate is in your hands. But seriously.     The "Why Now" You might be wondering why we want to put on a play about the world's most-loved Matt and Ben:  We spent a lot of time researching what we wanted to put up as our next production. As a result of our search, we were found a show that we loved (and still want to produce), but shortly after stumbled upon the script for "Matt & Ben." We fell in love with the play and knew in an instant that our pretentious, hipster, film-culture-loving LA audience would not be able to pass up it up. However, the show speaks to a wide demographic. Fans of "The Mindy Project," will be surprised and delighted to see a theatrical work co-written by the hilarious, talented Mindy Kaling. It's amazing and inspiring to see how both she and the title characters have risen to the levels of fame and "success" mentioned in the play.  We are excited to present this play with an exceptional creative team. Although the play focuses on two of the world's most successful male actors, the script is very clear that they be played by two women. This production is directed, acted and produced by women. The whole team is thrilled to bring this kind of story to an LA audience and we can't wait to see what happens when we do. Our journey with "Matt and Ben" begins this May at the Attic Theatre in Mid City, but we are hoping it continues at the Hollywood Fringe Festival in June. With your help, we can bring another hit production to the Fringe audience! We're putting every ounce of energy we have into making this show the best it can be. It's not going to be easy, but it will be fun! 


    Other Ways You Can Help Maybe you can't help financially. Money is rough and we know that first hand. But, that doesn't mean you can't help:  Sharing is caring. Please share this campaign with anyone remotely interested in Matt Damon or Ben Affleck--or Mindy Kaling or Brenda Withers. Share it with anyone that loves theatre. Share it with anyone that has money. You never know who's out there that might want to see this show. Repost the link to our campaign on Facebook. Email it to someone over age forty-five. Text them to check their email. Text them to go have a power lunch and then tell them about the show. 
We're always on the lookout for other goods and services we can use to make the show better and better. We need resources for set building: materials and builders. It's always good to have a backup rehearsal space. Own a restaurant or bar and either want to feed a production team or partner with us for a fundraising event? We want to talk. We may be looking for some specific props in the near future as well, and borrowing costs less than renting or buying. Plus, your couch could be famous.
Come support us at the show! We know it's not until the spring, but we'll be working on it with everything we've got until then, and we can't wait to see you there. Of course you'll be getting all kinds of social media reminders, but mark your calendar now and be sure to buy tickets as soon as they go live! Take someone on a date to the show. This is going to be a great date night show.   There's more to friendship than "Good Will." And with your help, we can make it possible.

story:
DONATE AND/OR SHARE!!


THIS SUMMER San Juan Island will DO IT ALL! All 37 plays (well sorta) of our beloved playwright William Shakespeare - FREE OF CHARGE! Join us and laugh until your belly hurts with this madcap romp through the canon. Three actors attempt all his plays in 97 minutes. Whether you're a Shakespeare pro, or first time visitor to the theatre- THIS SHOW IS FOR YOU! Bring your whole family, blankets, lawn chairs and picnic with us under the stars, for the perfect summer outing!


Photo: "The Complete Works" - 2015, Post5 Theatre. Chip Sherman and Ty Boice in performance Juliet and the Nurse.


“Stupendous, anchorless joy!” The London Times

“Wildly funny. Masterful!” Los Angeles Times

“The funniest show you are likely to see in your entire lifetime.” Montreal Gazette


Photo: "The Complete Works" Directed by Ty Boice in 2013.


“Pithier than Python. Irresistible.” New York Times

“A madcap condensation that features non-stop laughs. Done at a whirlwind pace and with great delight, they are sure to win over even the most skeptical. And there is no doubt that William Shakespeare himself… would approve.” Daily Variety

“If you like Shakespeare, you’ll like this show. If you hate Shakespeare, you’ll love this show!” The Today Show


Photo: Audience at "The Complete Works" on tour,  in 2015.


We’re bringing an all-star comedic cast and creative team! We are bringing you talents from Seattle and Portland, here on your favorite little Island to tickle your funny bone!!


KYLE HENICK: Kyle is making his San Juan Island debut this summer and he couldn't be more excited to be a part of this experience. Kyle has been performing theatre up and down the I-5 corridor for the last six years.  Some favorite roles include, Jamie in "The Last Five Years", Clive/Cathy in "Cloud 9", Brandon in "Bordersongs", and Oberon in "A Midsummer Night's Dream".  He is also a singer/songwriter and frontman/lyricist for the group Area of Defect.. He would like to thank Ty for offering him this great opportunity, The cast and crew of R&J and Complete Works for their amazing work, his mom for her eternal love and support, and you guys, the audience, for being awesome and coming to see us. Enjoy the show!


ALEX MATHEWS: Alex is a proud founding member of The Satori Group in Seattle. He also recently became a member of the Seagull Project where he was just seen at ACT in their production of "The Three Sisters". He played Willem in New Century Theatre Company's production of Franz Kafka's "The Trial". He led the workshops for the generation of new Satori play "Returning to Albert Joseph" written by Spike Freidman. He was just seen at Seattle Repertory Theater in "Luna Gale" followed by the world premiere of "Sherlock Holmes and The American Problem". He is honored to be performing in his first season in Friday Harbor.


CHIP SHERMAN: Chip is elated to make his San Juan Island premiere in two of his favorite plays on love and laughter. He has recently relocated up north from Portland, OR where he enjoyed playing roles such as, Ted in "Peter and the Starcatcher", Julian in "How We Got On", Claudio in "Much Ado About Nothing", Antipholus of Syracuse in "Comedy of Errors", and Olivia in "Twelfth Night". He is a proud company member of Portland based 11: Dance Co. He would like to thank Ty and Cass for their support and loyalty, his mother for her acceptance of his artistic lifestyle, his Beau for taking a leap of faith (for this he will always be grateful), and you for your support of live theater. "To live will be an awfully big adventure."



AND DIRECTED BY TY BOICE: 

AS A DIRECTOR: 

“It’s a riotous romp that will leave your face red with laughter.” - Portland Stage Reviews, The Complete Works of William Shakespeare [abridged], 2013

“perfectly staged and brilliantly performed.” - Broadway World,

The Complete Works of William Shakespeare [abridged]

“His presentation should stand as a classic as to how to present Shakespearean comedy.  He has pulled ever nuance, sight gag, and comedy bits or pratfalls out of the bag and had the audience in almost constant laughter.” - Dennis Sparks, As You Like It, 2014

“You don’t have to give Macbeth a lightsaber, turn Rosencrantz and Guildenstern into Mafiosos or set Twelfth Night at an office party in Tigard to reimagine Shakespeare. Making the Bard accessible is largely a matter of carefully breaking up the language and using blocking to reinforce its meaning. . . . . that’s exactly what director Ty Boice does, to fantastic result.” - Willamette Week - As You Like It, 2014

“Ty Boice’s spirited direction successfully updates this classic” - Willamette Week, The Comedy of Errors, 2015

“Director Ty Boice takes the flattest of characters in The Comedy of Errors and matches them with their modern descendants roaming our city blocks. A farce becomes a farce of a farce as the overgrown subcultures of the last 20 years mix and meet and mistake identities.” Oregon Arts Watch, The Comedy of Errors 2015

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


Walk off the Ferry, out of the restaurant, Bed & Breakfast and STRAIGHT INTO THE LAUGHS!!

OUR BEAUTIFUL VENUES: FRIDAY  and ROCHE HARBOR!!


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *

This production is absolutely FREE for the public, however the request for “pass the hat” donations will not likely cover the budget.

Break it down for folks in more detail:

BUDGET:

Costumes - $300

Props - $300

Set - $600

Rights to perform - $1,000

Publicity - $400

Performers - $3,000


Total: $5,600


Please consider helping us get a fraction of our way to this incredible goal!


By donating and/or sharing this campaign you will play a essential part in bringing free summer theatre for an entire community . In a time when we desperately seek connection and putting aside our electronics that tether us to our busy lives. This is a unique experience that can bring  together friends, families, denizens and visitors!


WAYS YOU CAN HELP: PLEASE DONATE!!

AND/OR

Share this campaign on your twitter, facebook, email or social media platform!!

story:
"SHOCK OPERA: The Alice Cooper Story" is written and directed by Dylan Hillerman and produced by Julia Reodica. GuignolFest Productions, their multimedia group produces live theatre, video, art work, and the annual 72-Hour Horror Movie Contest in Portland. 

Dylan Hillerman is no stranger to theatre. He has performed in live theatre for over 30 years which includes writing, producing, and directing in productions on the West Coast. His passion for the Alice Cooper band and the man started back in the 1970's and has culminated into the current production of SHOCK OPERA, which first came out in 2016, in Oregon. Julia Reodica is an international interdisciplinary artist with over 25 years of performance art, installation art, and studio/talent management. Together, they bring non-traditional productions to Portland audiences.

For Dylan and Julia, Alice Cooper made a huge, early impact on their approach to showmanship and storytelling. "SHOCK OPERA: The Alice Cooper Story" is many things because Alice reinvented himself throughout his career. As individuals, Dylan and Julia had each evolved as artists in novel ways to make their creations engaging for the audience. Encouraging youth to learn about musical arts is important to all of us as it helps build confidence and critical thinking. Therefore, a portion of ticket sales for "SHOCK OPERA" will go to the Artist Mentorship Program (AMP) of Portland and Alice Cooper's Solid Rock of Phoenix.

SHOCK OPERA is a mirror, a hologram, a dark comedy-- it's a play about the guys who invented the rock show. This play is important to continue as an annual event because Alice Cooper fans, old and new, can relate to the many faces of the rock performer and as a person who experienced glorious highs and tragic low times. Alice Cooper as a band helped shaped the rock and roll world as we know it. Look around at the way their contemporaries in the 1970's followed suit with bringing theater to the rock show. David Bowie, Elton John, KISS, and various punk bands to name a few, followed the wave of what it meant to use all the senses to experience the music. Alice Cooper was a sensation to be felt first hand. 

SHOCK OPERA is the first musical/multimedia play in the world to cover the Alice Cooper story. It does more than play the favorite hits, performed on stage with acting, dancing, and singing-- it also presents the band's history and stories many have never heard. The play was based on multiple sources, especially from Dennis Dunaway's book, "Snakes! Guillotines! Electric Chairs!" Alice Cooper's book, "Golf Monster," and "Supermensch" a documentary about Alice's lifelong manager, Shep Gordon. After meeting Alice Cooper, the legend himself, he encouraged the troupe to keep going with the play and wants to see how it evolves and to get the show to his Cooper'sTown venue, in Phoenix, Arizona . This play is intended to develop into a feature movie as well. SHOCK OPERA is a living history experience, and the story continues!

Those who contribute to the SHOCK OPERA campaign are not just supporting the cast and crew in traveling to Seattle, but are helping keep alive, the rock history and influences that Alice Cooper has on contemporary culture. Rock icons are often seen as untouchable, perhaps almost mystical. SHOCK OPERA shows that Alice Cooper was a man who also had challenges facing his mortality, celebrity status, and personal values. Many of his experiences, as extreme as they were, still resonate with every one who sees the play because we all struggle with similar concepts of identity and survival.

For SHOCK OPERA's Seattle production, a campaign to raise $2000 has been started. These funds go to travel expenses, video production costs, cast and crew stipends, equipment rental, and venue costs. Our 15-person cast and crew work hard to get this type of multimedia experience to a wide audience. 

Contributors get perks! Each funding level will receive:

- $10 Gutter Cat:
Show postcard and 2 Alice Cooper Spike Eyes sticker

- $20 Department of Youth:
Archival show poster (11" x 17"), 2 Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Stickers

- $30 Special Forces:
Archival show poster (11" x 17"), 2 Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Stickers, a SHOCK OPERA: Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Panty (think about the School's Out album, wink!)

- $50 Mr. Nice Guy:
Archival show poster (11" x 17"), 4 Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Stickers, a SHOCK OPERA: Alice Cooper Eyes Panty, a Beverage Coozy

- $75 Billion Dollar Baby:
2 Archival show posters (11" x 17"), 4 Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Stickers, 2 SHOCK OPERA: Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Panties, 2 Beverage Coozies

- $100 Super-Duper-Alice-Cooper-Mensch:
2 Archival show posters (11" x 17"), 1 Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Stickers, 2 SHOCK OPERA: Alice Cooper Spike Eyes Panties, 4 Beverage Coozies, and archival photos of the cast and show scenes

Whatever funds are raised for the campaign will be prioritized for actor payment, travel expenses and venue costs at the very least. Any contribution is helpful in keeping the show alive!

Contributors support the continuance of SHOCK OPERA for another year and supports the Seattle show. The show troupe would like to expand the audience base by making SHOCK OPERA an annual event, so that the Alice Cooper story can continue to develop as a performance and multimedia production. Contributors also get show related items that were created to reflect the aesthetics and spirit of the Alice Cooper band.

Dylan Hillerman as a director, has entertained Portland with wild and weird productions such as Bikini Creature Beach Feature (campy play were beach teens meet a greaser gang), Reservoir Dolls, (all-female cast performing Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs), and Headless Body in Topless Bar (a murder noir play, based on a true crime), and Terror At Angel's Horn (a sci-fi, psychedelic play about time travel, gangsters, and alien cats). Audience responses have ranged from cry-laughing to gasping in horror. In 2016, SHOCK OPERA had sold-out shows in Portland-- entertaining veteran Alice Cooper fans and gaining new ones. Portland never knows what to expect year-to-year with GuignolFest Productions!

The biggest challenge for SHOCK OPERA, is the traveling show aspect. Therefore, housing the cast and crew is a big expense. GuignolFest Productions has successfully managed diverse budget requirements dealing with the creation of videos, theater shows, and events. For a musical production as this, a live band was a challenge in terms of funding. To accommodate this, the music was pre-recorded in the studio and singers then perform the songs live, on stage.

In this early phase of SHOCK OPERA becoming an annual traveling show, cast members play multiple roles in the Alice Cooper story. The music remains an integral part of the show as pre-recorded instrumentals for the singers to perform.

Getting the word out is easy! SHOCK OPERA, the trailer video, is available to share widely from the Vimeo channel hosted by GuignolFest Productions. The play's Facebook page and event page are other great ways to tell your friends about the world's first musical based on Alice Cooper. Of course, using Indigogo sharing tools is the first step to getting the word out!

story:
DIXON PLACE          07.26.17

Buy Tickets Here

Some cerebral constructs ossify into ironclad closed loops of logical thinking. They demand to be “the one and only,” and consequently, we all practice daily meditations on the reasons why we are right. One new answer must kill the old one. Facts become “alternative facts.” Truisms become Trumpisms.

In AUTOPORTRAIT, stories gain sentience and have the unsettling power to unseat truth. A Congressional 9/11 hearing becomes a witch hunt for Condoleezza Rice, and then the setting for her gruesome (if fictitious?) childhood memories. The East Village’s happenings become nothings, sites of the quotidian that bloom into utopian possibilities just upon the horizon. Freddy Herko appears and dances out the window to his death. Or was it to space? Our queer horizon is a place where new truth doesn’t kill consensus, but conversely where consensus holds new truth.

Trusting in the agency of stories to mold reality, lies can result in a spectrum of results between narrow demagoguery and the sublime beauty of choice. Queerness represents such choice, the perpetuity and potentiality of the alternative. Gesturing to this path, AUTOPORTRAIT will help its audience rebel against society’s closed loops, marshaling a new era of creative expression and individual power.

Zachary Small (Playwright) is a New York-based theater maker who has premiered work at venues including Dixon Place and Irondale Theater. Previously, he dramaturged Mabou Mines' "Imagining the Imaginary Invalid" at La MaMa ETC (NYTimes Critics' Pick). As an an actor, he has performed in the lead role of "Ziegfeld's Midnight Frolic" (Off-Broadway) and as Mephistopheles in "Faust 2.0" (Mabou Mines). He is also an art critic for various publications, including Artsy, Art in America Magazine, Art21 Magazine, BOMB Magazine, Hyperallergic, and American Theatre Magazine. Graduate of Columbia University (Art History and Political Science).

Alex Hare (Director) recently conceived and directed the song cycle Chains Don’t Rattle Themselves, pairing singer/songwriters with formerly incarcerated writers to create songs based on true stories of youth incarceration. Alex is also part of the team behind the new Corkscrew Theater Festival, presenting ten original plays this August. He has developed and premiered work at HERE, Cherry Lane, Dramatists Guild, NYCFringe, Dixon Place, and Feinstein's/54 Below. Assistant credits: School of Rock, Side Show, and 2017’s Beauty and the Beast film remake. Alex studied English Literature and American Studies at Columbia University.

Allison Benko (Assistant Director/Dramaturg) is a theatre artist based in New York. Directing: A Doll's House: A New Opera (Central Square Theatre; The Tank NYC), Secret Death of Puppets (New York Public Library; Standard ToyKraft), Every Christmas Story (Gloucester Stage), Twelfth Night (Powderhouse Park), and She Loves Me (Tufts University). Writing: The Arthur Miller Centennial (Gloucester Stage) and contributed lyrics to A Doll's House: A New Opera. Assistant direction: Oslo (Lincoln Center, dir. Bartlett Sher), Sabina (the cell, dir. Kira Simring) and numerous productions at Gloucester Stage. Puppetry: Tholpavakoothu Centre in Kerala, India. Education: Lincoln Center Director's Lab 2017, Tufts University 2015, BADA 2013.

Cast: C Bain, Matthew Brown, Kristin Fulton, Tommy Heleringer, & Cristina Pitter

Creative: You-Shin Chen (Set Designer), Iliana Paris (Costume Designer), Marc Stuart Jablonski (Sound Designer), & Erin Jones (Lighting Designer)

AUTOPORTRAIT started as an earnest investigation into how the stories we tell ourselves construct identity, routine, and consensus reality. In September 2016, research began into theories of queerness, drag, and parafiction, noting how these ideologies attempt to produce skepticism in ultimatums, if also, oddly, belief. 

The 2016 presidential election in November changed the course of AUTOPORTRAIT, widening the play’s scope as an incisive dive into the post-truth world of “alternative facts” and “fake news.” In consultation with director Alex Hare, Zachary Small wrote a new draft of the piece that incorporated examples of dogmatic political fiction. These authoritarian visions challenge the play’s creation of queer utopia, a non-space whose falseness engenders adept choice-making and flux that does not, and may never, exist in society. 

Act Two of AUTOPORTRAIT received a staged performance at Irondale Theatre’s Not Normal Festival in March 2017. We are now pleased to present a performance of the full piece at Dixon Place during the venue’s HOT! Festival on July 26th.

This project was made possible, in part, thanks to the Leslie-Lohman Museum Space Grant for Performance Art and Experimental Theatre. AUTOPORTRAIT is the museum's first Space Grant recipient.

Accordingly, we see AUTOPORTRAIT as an investment in the future of queer art. We intend to put future queer leaders in the performing arts in conversation with their visual arts counterparts, creating a more substantial network of support and engagement.​

AUTOPORTRAIT is so close to becoming a reality!

This play is a unique project, and it's one of the first theatrical productions to take a serious, measured approach to queering the methodology of our new political landscape. For years, queer theory has communicated a desire to create new societies of equality and vision; we intend to actualize those theories through performance. This is theatre as political process.

Accordingly, we have strived to fund AUTOPORTRAIT ourselves through local collaboration. Our residency at the Leslie-Lohman Museum provides us with rehearsal space, but does not provide us with any stipend for the production costs or actors. We have also applied for an FCA Emergency Grant that, if we should acquire it, will provide extra relief.

Where do your funds go?

  • Performer Stipends – $750
  • Designer Stipends – $700
  • Marketing & Insurance – $300
  • Rehearsal Space – $276
  • Set, Costumes, Props – $400
  • Video Footage – $50

We are looking to our community for help. Donations to AUTOPORTRAIT go directly to paying the actors, renting rehearsal space, and buying costumes, makeups, props, and set pieces. We truly believe in AUTOPORTRAIT as a good investment in the future of experimental and queer theatre.

With professional backgrounds in downtown theatre and Broadway alike, we have the ability to give this play life and the maturity to see it through. What ultimately unites us is a shared passion. We want to reenergize New York's political theatre scene through the dynamics of queer life.

Visit Our Website and Join Our Mailing List: https://zsmall93.wixsite.com/autoportrait

story:
Summary

    Andrew Allen and Michelle Donkin established CAST IRON THEATRE in 2014. 

    Andrew is a writer, director and Brighton Fringe award winning actor.  He runs improvisation workshops and his Brighton Fringe 2016 play Year Without Summer  was Highly Recommended by Fringe Review. 

    Michelle is an MA Screenwriting graduate of the National Film and Television School. Her short play writing credits include Impact Statement @ NVT, Talking Dirty @ Theatre  503 Rapid Response, Projection @ Cockpit Theatre and  a collection of her work Donkin's Demi-Dozen @ Sweet Dukebox,.  Her first full length play, Model Organisms debuted at this year's Brighton Fringe and was awarded four stars from Fringe Guru.

    Heather is a performer and comedian.  This Brighton Fringe she performed at The Warren in    Am I F#*kable?  the devised show from Pop Heart Productions,  She's also a member of comedy troupe the Fannytasticals.   

    CACOPHONY is CAST IRON THEATRE'S first devised physical theatre production.  A solo show, it takes its inspiration from anything from Jacques Tati to Looney Tunes.

    In a world full of sound and fury, one woman is ready to listen! Cutting through the confusion, this vital and dynamic show proves we can say exactly what we mean when we shut the hell up. Physical theatre is blended with a dry wit, steely determination and a shockingly limited vocabulary.

    CAST IRON THEATRE is passionate about new writing, bold performances, and memorable experiences. We're excited and giddy to be performing at the EDINBURGH FRINGE this year - and we need your help to get there!

     

    What We Need & What You Get

    We'll be staging CACOPHONY at SWEET VENUES HOLYROOD and while we're a pretty low cost production there are still some things we need a little help with, including, but not limited to:  

    • Accommodation £2,000
    • Posters and Publicity  £500
    • Travel £300

    We're also seeking to purchase a few more props and costumes after we have successfully sourced free or donated items.  Our wish list of items comes in at around £200. 

    The Impact

    Look, we know it's embarrassing.  All your performer and artsy friends are asking for a bit of cash for their shows.  They tell you it's 'just the price of a coffee' and add four exclamation marks at the end of their plea.  We'd like to say we're different. 

    That would be a lie.

    Look, it's just the price of a coffee  Plus you'd get to help us artsy theatre types who happen to be your friends, make a magnificent solo show IN EDINBURGH!!!...!

    We really do value any contribution you might be able to make.  We're actually very proud of CACOPHONY and our aim for the show is to tour.  Getting to Edinburgh is the first step towards this and we're offering lots of nice perks for you, our contributors, as a way to thank you for supporting and believing in us. 

    Risks & Challenges

    We're sure you know how risky making theatre can be.  It's a costly career we've chosen and we know that we'd be incredibly successful just to break even.  Any shortfall will come directly out of our pockets and that's fine.  Again, we've chosen this!

    We believe in CACOPHONY and we're passionate about taking it to Edinburgh and giving it the best chance to continue onwards from there.

    We've got form in creating fabulous and challenging new work on a shoestring and we're never going to let a thing like money stand in our way. 

    We know that we'll be in Edinburgh in August, so with your help, you can make our stay that bit more successful.  Plus we've got some great rewards that we're sure you'll love!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Not everyone will be ale to contribute financially and we completely understand.   

    However, if you could share our little plea across your social media platforms that would be amazing.

    Thanks so much from Andrew, Michelle & Heather!

We know that we'll be in Edinburgh in August, so with your help, you can make our stay that bit more successful.  Plus we've got some great rewards that we're sure you'll love!

Not everyone will be ale to contribute financially and we completely understand.   
However, if you could share our little plea across your social media platforms that would be amazing.
Thanks so much from Andrew, Michelle & Heather!

story:
Kaley Pruitt Dance is having its NYC Season July 27, 28, & 29 at Triskelion Arts.  We are sharing two NYC premieres and one world premiere this year, and hope you can be a part of making it happen!  After a sold out 2016 Season, we are excited to be adding a 3rd night of performances.

My name is Kaley Pruitt Ozminkowski, and I am the Artistic Director of Kaley Pruitt Dance.  We are a modern dance company based in New York City.  Originally from Ketchum, Idaho, I have taken my dance work to Idaho, California, Massachusetts, Florida, New York, and Illinois.  I now travel between Illinois and New York teaching and creating work on students at Illinois State University, then working with the professional company in New York City. 

The Project

This summer I am restaging and reimaging two of my works, Critical Mass and Room for Elephants, and setting them on KPD.  Both works have been in the creative process this year and developed on students at Illinois State University.  I am excited to premiere these works in New York City, and to see how they are grow and transform with the company.

Critical Mass revolves around the powerful force of being anonymous, and what the urban landscape allows of the human expressive condition.  It is an incredibly physical, athletic, and high energy group work to music by Too Many Zooz, Steve Reich, and World Saxophone Quartet.

Room for Elephants is a nostalgic, playful, and otherworldly quartet about how we retain structures and physical places that held our sense of “home” at one time or another.  The work looks at memory, and how we keep and re-live those spaces we cannot revisit.  The piece is set to several selections by Tin Hat Trio.

I will also be creating a new work over the summer to also premiere in July.  I’m thrilled to be working with company dancers Megan Wubbenhorst, Cassandra Bowser, Ashley Ervin, as well as guest artist, Robert Perales. 

Funding Goals

Kaley Pruitt Dance is looking to raise $4,750 through this campaign to fund the dancers’ rehearsal and performance pay, space rental, and costumes.  I am as committed to our artistic vision as I am about paying our dancers fairly for their professional work.  Here is a breakdown of our July season budget:

  • $1,000 – Space Rental for 10 weeks of rehearsal
  • $2,900 – Hourly Rehearsal Pay for 4 dancers for 10 weeks of rehearsal
  • $600 – Dancer Performance Pay for 4 dancers for 3 shows
  • $250 – Costumes for 5 dancers for the new work

Know that no donation amount is too small!  Contributions of any amount are incredibly helpful to furthering our work.  Your dollars will go directly towards the dancers pay first and foremost, and then to the other budget items as we approach our funding goal.  If we exceed our fundraising goal, the KPD dancers get a well-deserved raise!  If you want to help but just can't donate, please share our campaign and show information with everyone you know.

Perks

  • Donate $10 - Be on a VIP list for 1 free beer or wine, when you attend the performance
  • Donate $30 - Receive 1 complimentary ticket to the performance of your choice
  • Donate $50 - Receive 2 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice
  • Donate $75 - Receive 2 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice and 2 VIP free drinks at the show
  • Donate $150 - KPD Backstage Pass: Receive 2 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice, plus join the dancers in a rehearsal (watch or participate) and access to our Tech/Dress rehearsal to see how the whole show comes together
  • Donate $300 or more - KPD Receive 4 complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice plus dinner and drinks out with the whole company (during June or July), Backstage Pass to our Tech/Dress rehearsal, plus 8x10 printed photo of KPD in performance signed by the whole company

Special Out of Towner’s Perks

  • Donate $20 - Receive a 5x7 printed KPD performance photo, signed by the whole company
  • Donate $50 – Receive a KPD T-shirt and a 5x7 printed KPD performance photo, signed by the whole company
  • Donate $100 - Receive a DVD of the show, a KPD T-shirt and an 8x10 printed KPD performance photo, signed by the whole company

Thank you in advance.  We can’t wait to share this work with you July 27-29 at Triskelion Arts!

Kaley Pruitt Ozminkowksi of Kaley Pruitt Dance

Get more information on KPD's work and the upcoming July shows below!

www.KaleyPruittDance.com

www.Triskelionarts.org/kaley-pruitt-dance

Donations are not tax-deductible

story:
Short Summary

Dietrich Rides Again was written by Oliver Conant and Justyna Kostek, who are both members of the non-profit Medicine Show Theatre Ensemble--one of the oldest experimental theatres in New York City. Dietrich Rides Again will be produced as a workshop production there in September. It also got accepted to Midtown International Theatre Festival for the summer and fall this year. Our goal in bringing Dietrich Rides Again  to NYC audiences is to provide them with an experience of what made Marlene Dietrich unique:  her powerful sexuality (attracting both men and women),  earthy humor, sophistication, irony, the strength of her beliefs, elegance, glamour.

Your donations will fund:

Having a General Manager on board - oh yes, we need one!

Transportation of the cast and equipment

Compensation for the actors, director, musical director, musicans, lighting designer and costumer (artists often get asked to work for free - would anyone ask a plumber or a doctor to work for free?)

Equipment rentals

Props and set pieces

Costumes for the actors

Publicist for securing review attention

Marketing

Cost of the use of venues (yes, we want to not only do it at MST and MITF but also other places!)

An exciting, thought provoking ride into the heart and soul of the queen of the Golden Age of Hollywood!

THE TEAM

Artistic, Experimental and Fearless.

That's our Director and Writer... Oliver Conant!

Oliver Conant serves as Director of Dietrich Rides Again and he has also co-written this musical. He is a very experienced Director in the non commercial theatre of NYC. His credits include readings, fully staged plays both classics and contemporary for such companies as Nicu's Spoon, Queen's Shakespeare, North East Stage, Medicine Show Theatre Ensemble. As a child he was introduced to Greta Garbo by Salka Viertel and has always felt somehow connected to the extraordinary congregation of talent in the Berlin emigre community in Hollywood. Oliver is also a former Hollywood movie actor who appeared in the Warner Brother's movies "Summer of 42" and "Class of 44."

 

Thinker, Imaginer and Creative Soul

That's our Lead Actress and... Justyna Kostek

Justyna Kostek is an actor and director from Poland who serves as a lead actress playing Marlene Dietrich and also a co-writer of Dietrich Rides Again. Justyna hasbeen acting since she was 7 years old! She had her own theatre company established in Denmark that she performed with all over Europe (Atelier Teatral). Since she arrived in NYC she has directed and starred in comedy musical Helen of Troy, NY; starred and directed in Women of History Fashion Show and played a lead actress in the musical comedy Bound to Rise at Medicine Show Theatre. Many of her qualities are similar to Dietrich's: her work ethic, for one. . Just like Marlene Dietrich, who by all accounts took over the directing of Stage Fright from the notoriously standoffish Alfred Hitchcock, Justyna loves both acting and directing

 

Versatile, Brilliant and Methodical.

That's our Music Director... Jono Mainelli!

Mr. Mainelli has written, arranged, and/or tinkled the ivories for such wonderful talents as Patti Lupone, Jo Anne Worley, Charles Busch, Liliane Montevecchi, Lee Roy Reams, Marilyn Michael, Maximillian Schell, John Byner, Ernie and David Sabella, Varla Jean Merman, Jackie Hoffman, Brent Barrett, Jana Robbins, Annie Golden, Cynthia Nixon, and Celeste Holm, to name a few.  He was assistant to the legendary Stan Freeman on A Helluva Town! The Leonard Bernstein Revue at Rainbow & Stars.  He has played Joe’s Pub and every New York cabaret room, and arranged and played at the Williamstown Theater Festival Cabaret.

Jono’s musical The Glass House was produced at Lost Nation Theater, Montpelier, Vermont, and further developed at Stephen Schwartz’ ASCAP Musical Theater Workshop.  His one man show, Sixteen Bars: Notes From An Audition Pianist enjoyed an extended run at The Triad Theatre. During the January “audition season” for college programs, Jono has been thrilled to be the main pianist and on the Auditions Committee for all the NYU Tisch appointments, for the last 9 years. Jono attended The Bronx High of Science, Brown University, and The Manhattan School of Music.

What We Need and What You Get

This IndieGoGo campaign is founded on one goal: making an industry standard musical despite struggling non-profit theatre standard resources. We've set a $15,000 Flexible Goal that will run for 60 days. This means that everything contributed will be received by us, even if we do not reach our goal. 

Taking into consideration some of the resources that our theatre supporters has provided us, the budget for Dietrich Rides Again is $3,102.05. We've collectively contributed $2001.03 to this project out of pocket but we need your help for the remaining $15,000 to bring the rest of the production to life.

Here is a breakdown showing you exactly how the total production budget is being spent:

Projected Budget

Personnel

Actors (8 @ $1,000)                          8,000

Director                                                 2,000

Musical Director                                2,000

Lighting Designer                                  500

Set Designer                                          500

Costume Designer                                 500

Set Builder                                               400

TOTAL PERSONNEL                                                          13,900

 

Occupancy Expenses

            8 weeks rehearsal, 2 weeks performance                                  2,500

 

Advertising and Marketing

            Publicist                                                 1,500

            Posters, cards, ads                                 1,000

            TOTAL ADV. & MKTG.                                                        2,500

 

Production Expenses

            Set materials                                             500

            Costume materials                                   200

            Costume rental                                         500

            Lighting, special effects                            350

            TOTAL PROD. EXPENSES                                      1,550

 

TOTAL PROJECTED EXPENSES                                            21,350

 

We would like to sincerely thank everyone for their attention and consideration. Any contribution, big or small, brings us one step closer to the August premiere of our musical. Finance aside, spreading our message on social media helps us out immeasurably, doesn't cost anything, and only takes a few minutes of your time. You can hit the buttons in the top right to check out our pages and help share our musical with your communities. Once again, thank you so much for supporting us and the story of Marlene Dietrich!
story_txt: Short SummaryDietrich Rides Again was written by Oliver Conant and Justyna Kostek, who are both members of the non-profit Medicine Show Theatre Ensemble--one of the oldest experimental theatres in New York City. Dietrich Rides Again will be produced as a workshop production there in September. It also got accepted to Midtown International Theatre Festival for the summer and fall this year. Our goal in bringing Dietrich Rides Again  to NYC audiences is to provide them with an experience of what made Marlene Dietrich unique:  her powerful sexuality (attracting both men and women),  earthy humor, sophistication, irony, the strength of her beliefs, elegance, glamour.Your donations will fund:Having a General Manager on board - oh yes, we need one!Transportation of the cast and equipmentCompensation for the actors, director, musical director, musicans, lighting designer and costumer (artists often get asked to work for free - would anyone ask a plumber or a doctor to work for free?)Equipment rentalsProps and set piecesCostumes for the actorsPublicist for securing review attentionMarketingCost of the use of venues (yes, we want to not only do it at MST and MITF but also other places!)An exciting, thought provoking ride into the heart and soul of the queen of the Golden Age of Hollywood!THE TEAMArtistic, Experimental and Fearless.That's our Director and Writer... Oliver Conant!Oliver Conant serves as Director of Dietrich Rides Again and he has also co-written this musical. He is a very experienced Director in the non commercial theatre of NYC. His credits include readings, fully staged plays both classics and contemporary for such companies as Nicu's Spoon, Queen's Shakespeare, North East Stage, Medicine Show Theatre Ensemble. As a child he was introduced to Greta Garbo by Salka Viertel and has always felt somehow connected to the extraordinary congregation of talent in the Berlin emigre community in Hollywood. Oliver is also a former Hollywood movie actor who appeared in the Warner Brother's movies "Summer of 42" and "Class of 44." Thinker, Imaginer and Creative SoulThat's our Lead Actress and... Justyna KostekJustyna Kostek is an actor and director from Poland who serves as a lead actress playing Marlene Dietrich and also a co-writer of Dietrich Rides Again. Justyna hasbeen acting since she was 7 years old! She had her own theatre company established in Denmark that she performed with all over Europe (Atelier Teatral). Since she arrived in NYC she has directed and starred in comedy musical Helen of Troy, NY; starred and directed in Women of History Fashion Show and played a lead actress in the musical comedy Bound to Rise at Medicine Show Theatre. Many of her qualities are similar to Dietrich's: her work ethic, for one. . story:
A Letter from the Creator

“I've always thought the journey of an artist was very similar to that of a butterfly. It starts as an egg, a thought, an idea and pops out like the very hungry caterpillar waiting to feed on exotic foods and knowledge. Soon it’s mind and body expands into a fully realized creature. The caterpillar seems to have it all, but a primordial instinct pushes it past the horizon. The caterpillar locks itself away in a stain glass chrysalis and perfects it's craft. Once the butterfly emerges, artistry pours out of every fiber of its being and manifests as wings. Something so beautiful that not even the president of the United States can take it away. The butterfly's wings expand over miles of space and time, and even when it is lost the memories of what was created continues to inspire others. See, First there is a discovery of self. Then, there is a discovery of art. Chrysalis is a multimedia immersive event designed to reflect life and its many mysterious twist and turns metaphorically through the lifecycle of a butterfly. It's a choose your own adventure focused on love, artistry, and awareness of the world around you. The show features the underground theater world’s up and coming vocalists, writers, dancers, musicians, actors, visual artists and more!” -Kodi Lynn (writer/composer/director of Chrysalis) 

An introduction to the Creator/Project

Hello Indie world! My name is Kodi Lynn, a Nebraska born artist based in Brooklyn. I graduated from the New York Film Academy's 2 yr musical theater conservatory last year. There I participated in several readings, shows, developmental labs, and short films, including Mary & Max, the musical adaptation of the claymation film by Bobby Cronin, and the short film "Seeking Alice" that recently won best musical at the 2017 NOVA film festival. Recently I have been working to put up my original show Chrysalis! Now that I have found a producing team in THE CREATORS COLLECTIVE, I am ready to start fundraising! This is where you come in!  This show acts as a platform for not only me but the LGBTQ community, feminists, environmental activists, and struggling artists. The immersive story follows woman 1, as she struggles with sexuality, self respect, peer pressure, demons, love, and loss. This project is set to be August 5, 2017 at a new space on 100 Bogart st.. This project means the world to me, and I give my personal thanks to anyone who decides to donate.

What We Need & What You Get

To get this show on its feet we need $1500. This money will be used to pay for rehearsal space, a production packet, set and light design, costumes, hair, makeup, marketing, promotional items, musicians, refreshments, and art supplies. I give my personal guarentee that the money raised will directly benefit the show and those involved. We are also striving to use recycled materials in all aspects of the show to reduce our impact on the planet! 

For our generous supporters, we will be offering perks to reward monetary based donations. To find our more about these perks you can go the items/perks section of our campaign. The following are our perks available to claim:

- Donate $10 and you will receive a personalized shout out and sketch from the fine artist of the show, Kodi Lynn and Emily Carroo! 

- Donate $20 and you will receive 2 tickets to an upcoming event (including Chrysalis) produced by THE CREATORS COLLECTIVE! 

- Donate $40 and you will receive a membership to all events produced by THE CREATORS COLLECTIVE! http://www.thecreatorscollective.org/membership

- Donate $50 and you will receive the Chrysalis starter pack! This package includes a promotional sticker, a personalized shout out, a package of seeds to plant, and more! 

- Donate $75 to purchase a VIP Ticket Package, which includes: 2 tickets to Chrysalis (August 5, 2017), 2 drink tickets, and a Chrysalis Starter Pack (see $50 perk)!

- Donate $100 and I, Kodi Lynn Milburn, will write a personalized song just for you!!! 

- Donate $250 and all the previous perks are yours! 

The Impact

When I graduated from NYFA I began to audition for shows. I quickly found that the world I was apart of wasn't what I had dreamed. I hated it, and I began to hate myself in the process. I quickly grew tired of the type casting and wondered if I was the only one fed up with the industry. I asked my respected peers their opinion, and the results were shocking. Dancers experienced body shaming and struggled with eating disorders. Singers had been lined up by spectrum of blackness and eliminated before they even sang a note. Women told countless stories of inappropriate advances being forced upon them by casting directors, agents, and fellow actors. I was enraged. These people were some of the most talented and dedicated human beings I had ever met yet they weren't booking fulfilling work. I decided that I was going to write a show for those people. The result is an insane cast of actors, singers, musicians, artists, and dancers that have something to prove. I am asking you to donate to support these people. Thank you for your continued support. -Kodi Lynn 

Risks & Challenges

This show so far has been pretty smooth sailing, but putting up a show in NYC is hard. The ever changing city makes it hard to solidify any dates and/or spaces. To combat this struggle I am doing my best to be flexible and to react with calm and swift solutions.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to donate monetarily, never fear. There are still ways to contribute to our cause! Word of mouth is everything. You can share our story on all social media platforms and at your local grocery store! You can also check out our YouTube videos (https://m.youtube.com/channel/UC_9n9K3VSVKSZjZN... (http://www.thecreatorscollective.org/chrysalis)... give us a thumbs up! All contributions are welcomed and deeply appreciated!

story:
MadMPower Theatre is dedicated to the promotion of an adjustment of the image and treatment of psychiatric survivors.  We believe that all members of society need, as healthy human beings to work on their mental health, well-being and happiness.  Some have specific diagnosed mental health issues and must be, to be fair and equitable, integrated with all levels of society. Integration is the surest way to eradicate stigma.

Co-founder - Miles Cohen is a psychiatric survivor with 40 years of performing and directing experience. A graduate of the Canadian Mime School and Playhouse Acting School and has a B.A. in Drama from Bishop’s University. An alumnus of The Second City Touring Company, a founding member and teacher at  Kytes youth theatre for street youth. He studied Mindfulness based Stress Reduction at St. Joseph's Hospital,  studied relaxation techniques at Dorothy Madget Centre and taught "Living Meditation" at Ralph Thornton Centre. Miles currently teaches at “Learn” a CAMH day program as well as “Encore” a CAMH pilot program for patients on the ward and is currently a member of Workman Arts; a CAMH based arts organization and served for 6 years on their Board of Directors. 

Message from Miles Cohen - MadPower  Productions is  about the three Rs as it were for psychiatric survivors – Respect, Recovery, and Rights – civil rights. I would like to focus on recovery, because without it nothing else is possible. First of all, I would like to acknowledge Dr. Ashok Bhattacharya, my wife Janet, and Nurse-Psycho-Therapist Elisabeth Krieger, as the holy trinity that engineered my recovery.  Twenty-five years ago, I jumped off a bridge, and sustained an injury primarily of three exploded vertebrae in my spine.  I ended up in a wheelchair in the backroom of a group home.  My family and friends virtually gave up all hope of me having any kind of fulfilling life.  In fact, they were considering a nursing home to take care of me for the rest of my days. In a last ditch effort, Janet (then my friend) piled me and my wheelchair into a cab to see “the wizard of Oakville”, Dr. Bhattacharya.  You could say I was the scarecrow, tin man and cowardly lion all in one fractured psyche and body. Dr. Bhattacharya interviewed me for 30 minutes and then without reservation declared “This man can heal totally”. 

Like Captain Picard on Star Trek he turned to Janet and said “make it so”. 

Baffled and terrified herself, Janet rolled up her sleeves and did everything she could think of to accomplish this end,  with guidance and wisdom obtained in regular visits  to Oakville. Elisabeth Krieger, then a homecare nurse with training in psycho-therapy, now in private practice, became my advisor, ear, and amazing spiritual counselor.  She happened to be well versed in almost all “New Age” philosophy and spirituality, which I relied on  for inspiration and understanding. Our adult nephew Jamie, wise beyond his years, lived with us for awhile and his loving presence completed a kind of makeshift family compact. ( And I must mention Kazoo the Hamilton Tiger Cat my trusty and loyal feline friend, do not underestimate the power of a loyal cat. )

After ten years insightful patience and observation  by my exceptional  trinity (masterminded by the good doctor ) an Occupational Therapist suggested that I join Workman Arts, a CAMH –based arts organization developed by Lisa Brown, a former psychiatric nurse.  I had extensive theatre training and performance experience ,before I jumped, but afterwards I no more expected to act again onstage than “fly to the moon”.   ( I guess now I am waiting for NASA to call me). 

Workman right away entrusted me with lead roles in productions, gave me excellent classes, and the privilege of studying Improv with Kate Ashby, who like myself. was a Second City alumnus,  and literally  the most amazing teacher I have ever worked with. I had had many superlative instructors in my youth. After a few years, and way before I thought I was able, she asked me to teach when she had time conflicts in her schedule.  I had taught extensively before, but of course did not dream that I ever would do that again, and certainly not that soon. Looking back I think it showed she had remarkable insight and intuition. Lisa had the brilliance to put me on the Board of Directors.  The Board reawakened and helped re-develope my organizational mind (I had run companies before ) with  kindness patience and respect.  Who would think someone could be so  gently nurtured and developed, in so many ways?

They say “it takes a village to raise a child”.  It takes a community to heal someone.  I live in Leslieville.  When I started to walk again, furniture stores would literally put out chairs so I could rest and then keep going.  People I didn’t really know would stop and say “You’re doing better today aren’t you?”  The Tango Palace Coffee shop across the street was my community centre.  I was treated with love and fun even when I was hypo-manic and crazier than a loon.  Stratenger’s Bar and Restaurant, our local “Cheers” where everyone knows our names, would be a respite for Janet and I now and then.  She would have a glass of wine, and I an iced tea, and we would with the help of friends, pretend everything was almost bearable for an hour or so.

Now it is no longer just bearable but fun and rewarding.  I am happily married to Janet and have my teaching and writing and performing chops back.  And as you see my life long friend and colleague Stephen LaFrenie and I are starting a company.  I don’t just “survive” I honestly feel that I thrive. No one heals alone in a room staring at the ceiling, yet that is the fate of many survivors.   I know the terrifying price of that condition.  Steve and I are starting MadPower to do our bit to see that someday no survivor is ever cast in that reality again. 

You could say “We have a dream”.

Listen to Miles talking about MadMPower -

 

What we need.

We are raising $15,000.00 to help cover the cost of the production, the vast majority of which will pay the actors and crew, in other words, the artists themselves. The play opens August 23, 2017 in Toronto at the Palmerston Library Theatre.  Rehearsals begin on July 24th.  

The Impact

The dream is to create a company that will integrate professional artists who are psychiatric survivors with other professionals.  Many doors can close when someone is diagnosed with a psychiatric illness or during the time of their recovery.  This recovery time and diagnosis should never prevent someone from fulfilling their dream in life.  Sometimes it does. MadMPower seeks to create a safe harbour for people preparing to return to, or begin, their professional career on the stage or as an artist.  This includes those dedicated professionals who work behind the scenes to make a production come to life. You can help us create this safe environment and by doing so reveal a world of wonderful artists who have important things to say and share with all of us.  Integration is the surest way to eradicate stigma. We ask you to help us achieve this goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us by telling people about us.  Share this campaign with as many people as you can by using the Indiegogo share tools or email the link.  Come to the play in August this summer and meet us.  You can volunteer on the production, help us with research into other means of funding, follow us and share our twitter and facebook pages.  Volunteer on the production, help us research and organize future events.
