story:
Hello and thank you for taking the time to engage with our exciting campaign!


Crying in the Wilderness Productions is a bespoke theatre company which thrives on creating ambitious theatrical experiences that are immersive, enthralling and unique. 

The company is led by the producing team of Paul Anthony Morris and Sarah Louise Nunn who have over ten years experience in producing, directing and developing new plays. Our objective is to inspire through the high quality of our productions conversations with our audience that are lively, exacting and urgent.


  Creative Director                                 Creative Producer


WHAT IS SARAI?

Sarai is a provocative drama about a woman with ambitions to become the founder of a new nation. 

But this quest is no simple adventure into the unknown, neither is it a journey for the faint hearted as we observe Sarai grappling with the formidable forces of famine, disease, persecution and civil war in order to realise her vision. 

Written in consultation with a diverse group of professional women, this epic journey of undeniable heroism also lifts the lid on our own secret desires and ambitions. 

  

 Paul Anthony Morris - Winner of the First Adopt A Playwright Award!

Award received from International Award-Winning Actress Lindsay Duncan and Sofie Mason, Founder of OffWestEnd.com


WHAT DO PEOPLE THINK ABOUT SARAI? 

Following our one-week research and development (R&D) process at the Arcola Theatre in 2014, Sarai was critiqued by an audience of directors, producers, theatre programmers, journalists, executives, artists and members of the public at a one-off showcase.



FEEDBACK FROM THE R&D SHOWCASE AUDIENCE 


THE COMPANY


SO WHY IS SARAI IMPORTANT TO US?

The production of our play Sarai is also an integral part of the company’s ongoing initiative to address gender inequality on the British stage. 

In a survey conducted by Loughborough University, women accounted for only 38% per cent of the artists employed in the theatre industry whilst accounting for 68% of audience attendance. 

The alarming disparity between the statics has served to reinforce our resolve as a diverse company, which also promotes theatre for social change, to assist in the transformation of our industry by advocating, through our work, the equality of opportunity for all female artists. 


WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION HELP US TO ACHIEVE?

By contributing to our initiative to produce Sarai you will enable our company to impact the industry with a heroic vision of women on stage with a new Art of Humanity that will be thrilling and empowering for both our artists and our audience. 



Your contribution will also create a number of fantastic opportunities for our company 

  1. TO BRING TOGETHER a world class team of award-winning artists for our production. 
  2. TO ENABLE US TO USE the three-week run at the Arcola Theatre to attract international companies and partnerships so that Sarai can be performed to a wider global audience. 
  3. TO CREATE A LEGACY for the project through film documentation
  4. TO ENHANCE the profile of our company and highlight the issues for gender equality through the mainstream media.



WHAT DO WE NEED THE FUNDS FOR?

Crying in the Wilderness Productions (CITWP) is a company limited by guaranteed. Your donations will go directly towards the expenditure for the following areas: 


            

WHAT WILL BE THE IMPACT OF BRINGING SARAI TO THE STAGE?

As a company, which believes in the power of the arts to promote social change, our aim is to produce high quality plays that will inspire our audience to make a difference.

Your contribution in bringing Sarai to the stage will be of immense value also to women who are being supported by charitable organisations within the probation services, domestic violence agencies and refugee organisations.

In order to increase the opportunities of women supported by these charities to engage with our project we will schedule certain performances at an easily affordable concessionary rate and designate them as female only performances, if it is deemed necessary to protect the identity of the vulnerable young girls and women who rely on these services.  

In addition the shows will be accompanied by post show discussions with prominent women leading the debate on the urgency for gender equality to promote personal well being. 

Your contribution will also enable us to offer workshops to these agencies to help support the personal transformation that young girls and women in these organisations are striving to achieve.



WHAT IS OUR TRACK RECORD?

Over the past nine years our company has developed a proven track record for producing  plays that have captured the imagination of critics and the general public.

  • 35 cents enjoyed critical success and was published by Oberon publishers
  • Identity (renamed Aftermath) won the Adopt A Playwright Award and was also published by Oberon publishers
  • The Seer was recognised as one of the top three plays for production, out of a  submission of over 1500 plays, by West Yorkshire Playhouse one of the UK’s  largest main house theatres
  • And Gifted  was awarded the Peggy Ramsay Award
  • We have also produced to critical success: The Meeting, Click!, Invisible Man and Choices. 


WHY SHOULD YOU TRUST US?

One of our objectives is to make our process as inclusive as possible  by:

  • CAPTURING our process on film and sharing the experiences with our contributors  
  • CELEBRATING our outcomes and milestones with our contributors 
  • DISCLOSING a detailed show report and financial report to our contributors concerning the income and expenditure of our project. 

Our goal is to develop with our contributors a community. This can only materialise if we as a company are transparent and make ourselves accountable to you. This we believe is the necessary criteria for developing mutual trust and genuine appreciation for the future.




WHAT ARE THE RISKS AND CHALLENGES?

The risk factors relating to the production of a new play and how it will potentially capture the imagination of the general public was successfully tested in  a one off showcase of Sarai following our research & development of the project last year. 

Having turned the creative risks into massive critical gains our next challenge will be to build and sustain high levels of audience attendance for our production.

In conjunction with the Arcola Theatre our marketing team and campaign will be spearheaded by a multi media approach which will involve the press, radio, TV and online media. 

Influential figures working in the media will also be enlisted to publicly advocate for our production through various online networks. 

Listings & advertising will be placed on some of the large subscription theatre and music sites amongst a whole host of other conventional strategies already planned to attract a large audience for our production.



OTHER WAYS THAT YOU CAN HELP TO MAKE A REAL DIFFERENCE...



We are aware that some people might not be in the position to contribute financially to our project but would still like to be part of the community that makes this project happen. 


You can play a very important role in helping us to achieve our objectives by: 


  • SHARING our crowd funding campaign with colleagues, friends, family and networks 
  • SPREADING the word about our production to as many people you know by word of mouth, retweeting using #CITWPSarai, emails and Facebook 
  • GO to our Facebook page and LIKE us! 
  • STAY in touch with the company through email 
  • AND USE THE INDIEGOGO SHARE TOOLS BELOW!

THANK YOU FOR TAKING THE TIME TO  ENGAGE WITH OUR CAMPAIGN AND FOR BEING THE PERSON THAT MAKES A DIFFERENCE! 



HERE IS AN AUDIO EXTRACT OF SARAI FROM OUR R&D SHOWCASE AT THE ARCOLA THEATRE LAST YEAR

HERE IS AN AUDIO EXTRACT OF SARAI FROM OUR R&D SHOWCASE AT THE ARCOLA THEATRE LAST YEAR

story:
WHAT THE WORLD NEEDS NOW IS LOVE. ONE LOVE.

We are thrilled to announce the premiere of a new play by Peter Zachari called ONE LOVE! Opening in May 2016, Mr. Zachari returns to THEATER FOR THE NEW CITY after his successful runs of UNDER THE KNIFE: A FARCE (2015), PARKER & DIZZY'S FABULOUS JOURNEY TO THE END OF THE RAINBOW (2014) and FAT ASSES: THE MUSICAL (2013).  The show runs May 5th-May 22nd, 2016. 

ABOUT THE PLAY

Meet Hunter, a down-on-his-luck man who can no longer fall in love. So deep in dysfunction he refuses to allow intimacy even in his fantasies with the "Milkman" and the "Stockboy." An impromptu dinner with his over-the-top drag queen roommate, a former gay stripper-turned-Republican Catholic and an annoying acquaintance with a lazy eye make for one very uncomfortable evening. Only when a sexy stranger arrives from Pocatello, Idaho and a magical big-hearted spirit named Afrodite enter his life does he have the courage to face his past demons, with a tangled history that unravels in front of the audience.

BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP TO MAKE IT HAPPEN!

We need to mount a production of this complete with costume, sound, props, musicians, publicity, the works. Your donation to this project will help make this dream of ours a reality. By contributing money to this project, you are helping the artists associated with this project to see an original production come to fruition. OUR GOAL IS $10,000 and we must meet this goal to make this production happen. Every cent raised on this site will absolutely go to the funding of this production. Please spread the word! Tell your friends about us.  And please, above all else, come and see the show! We would love to see everyone there.

The Players

PETER ZACHARI (Director/Playwright) wrote, produced and directed Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow for the New York International Fringe Festival. He has also written Under the Knife: A Farce, Fat Asses: The Musical, The 3rd Gender, Lighten Up!, which was produced off-off-Broadway, as well as Loosen Up!, Shake It Up!, Live It Up!, and One Love. His ten-minute play, I Am Seventy Going on Eighteen was selected for production at the Boston Theatre Marathon VII.  Mr. Zachari’s directing credits include Into the Woods, Footloose, Rumors, Grease, They’re Playing Our Song, Return to the Forbidden Planet and Moon Over Buffalo (Summer Theatre at Salem) as well asWest Side Story (Marblehead High School.)  For several years, Mr. Zachari taught Acting and Directing for the Department of Theatre at Salem State University.  He received his Master of Fine Arts from the University of Florida and his Bachelor of Fine Arts from Salem State University.  Peter is forever grateful to every individual who contributed to this production.  Follow Peter @PeterZachari on Twitter.

story:
Our Studio

Shen Wei Dance Arts is thrilled to announce a new space for dance in our welcoming studio in the landmark West Park Presbyterian Church on 165 West 86th St (near Amsterdam) on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. We love the sun-filled studio’s 50’ by 30’ sprung, wooden dance floor and soaring rafters—an inspiring atmosphere for creativity.

The New York dance community is famously vibrant, yet there is a real shortage of affordable, large studio space for performing artists to create their work. Shen Wei Dance Arts is committed to expanding the presence of dance in the city and are excited for you to join us in this effort. Your contributions will directly support the equipment, materials and renovations needed to transform our new studio into a well-equipped, versatile and commodious space for the dance community – a space for dance rehearsals, classes, and informal showings as well as an intimate performance venue – and for Shen Wei Dance Arts’ expanded programming for artists and audiences. 

Here's a sneak peek of the programs we envision:

For Artists

Workshops and Intensives for Dancers

Dive into Shen Wei’s movement with technique and repertory workshops and now biannual intensives.

Choreographic Residencies 

A curated rehearsal space program that will grant up to 200 hours of free studio space to a group of compelling choreographers each year...It could be YOU!

Rehearsal and Performance Space

A venue where artists can show their work affordably. Reduced rental rates for non-profit rehearsals, showings, and classes.

For Audiences and the Community 

Feet and Frames: A Dance Film Festival

For dance aficionados and newcomers alike, Feet and Frames, will screen the very best of dance films. From the classic to the cutting edge, films will be selected by a panel of invited choreographers, filmmakers and dance historians. Each screening will be followed by a panel of  artists and historians, to lend insight into the films presented. If we can get this festival up and running, tickets will cost just $5.

In/Sight Showings

We’ll offer informal performances of Shen Wei’s work, followed by meet and greet events with Shen Wei and the dancers—all free of charge.

Salon Events

Free panels and talks on contemporary and traditional Chinese art, music and movement.

Youthful Exuberance

Special afterschool showings and experiential programs for students in the neighborhood. Students will get a chance to explore movement and have their curiosity satisfied by the artists themselves.  

Make Our Home Your Home

Beyond these plans, we welcome your input and ideas as we strive to make our new home a community space. Finding rehearsal studios for dance or any creative endeavor is always a challenge in New York City.  We welcome artists to make our space their home for rehearsals, classes, showings or performances.

Living the Dream

Help make our dreams come true! Your contribution of any amount can go a long way in making our new space a functional home for the arts community and you!

$10: Hand sanitizer for a week - every little bit helps!

$25: A gallon of paint to beautify our walls

$50: Coat hooks

$100: A DVD player for renter use during rehearsals 

$250: An industrial vacuum cleaner to keep our home clean for everyone to use

$1000: Black draperies to cover studio mirrors

$1500: A projection screen for community film screenings

$2000:  A full wall of mirrors

$7,000: - A light Board for studio showings

About the Rewards
Limited Edition Graphic T-shirts and Totes with Shen Wei's design elements from the backdrop of Map (2005).

A large format, print of Shen Wei Dance Arts in Re-II performed at Teatro Reggio, in Parma, Italy in 2010. Photographer: Roberto Ricci Controluce 
18" x 30". Limited Edition, archival quality, digital C-print. Matted and Framed. 

Everything is Connected; the Art of Shen Wei  is a retrospective look at the choreographic and visual artistry of Shen Wei. With essays by renowned New York Times dance critic Anna Kisselgoff and Asia Society Museum Director Dr. Melissa Chiu, this magnificent 337-page art book is replete with beautiful full-color, large-scale images of Shen Wei's dances, paintings, and photography unveiling the trajectory of his work. The book sheds light on his work process, with preparatory sketches and drawings of dances and paintings, notes and inspiring artifacts.  

A One-of-a-kind Painted Canvas: Jackson Pollack proved you didn’t need a paint brush to make great work. Shen Wei takes it one step further, with dancers painting with their entire body, capturing the momentum of their movement in swirls of paint. As they dance, the performers leave traces of their movement—creating an artifact of their temporal performance. 


Thank you for helping us make a new home for dance. We look forward to seeing you on the Upper West Side! Please help us spread the world!

*Please note that while we would like as many people as possible to visit our new home, the studio is currently on the 4th floor of a building with no elevator access.

story:
About Us

Home Theatre Productions wants to make the theatre feel like home! Fans of popular culture, we draw our inspiration from sources such as TV, trashy movies, video games, horror, fantasy, science fiction, comic books, and cartoons. We want to make sure that audiences feel like they belong, creating an atmosphere that encourages community, sincerity, and openness.

Grab a bucket of popcorn, throw on your favourite graphic tee and settle in. Or grab a bottle of wine, throw on your cha-cha heels and settle in. Whatever you grab, and whatever you throw on, make yourself feel at home, because Home Theatre is all about making theatre a space where you feel comfortable being you! Working to create a space focused on openness and accessibility, Home Theatre celebrates the rowdy, the pulpy, the fun, and the wonderful beauty of the “lowbrow.”

What We Need 

Putting on a show is expensive! As a group of new artists, the upfront costs are being covered out of our own pockets, and we want to be able to pay each artist working on our project and equal share of the profits. In order to pay our artists a reasonable fee, we aim to cover our costs through fundraising efforts so 100% of the show's profits go to the artists. 

Fundraising income goes toward:

  • The costs of renting the Minimain Studio at Mainline Theatre
  • The rights to [title of show], which are paid to The Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization
  • Prop costs
  • Costume costs
  • Set costs
  • Investment in future shows

Our two largest costs are the rental of the Minimain Studio at Mainline Theatre and the rights paid to Rodgers & Hammerstein. We are minimizing the costs of props, costumes and set to maximize revenue for our artists, while not compromising on the quality of our production.

What You Get

Perks:

Bronze Sponsor ($5): You will be listed in the program and on our social media page as a bronze sponsor!

Silver Sponsor ($20): You will get a program  and website shout-out, as well as three free raffle tickets when you attend the show! The cast will also include you in a thank-you video to our sponsors!

Gold Sponsor ($50): Gold Sponsors will receive: a shout-out in our program and on our website, a thank you video from the cast, a signed program, 3 free raffle tickets to be awarded when you attend the show, rice krispy treats made by our very own director and brought to the show you will be attending. As a bonus perk, you will get to experience Tulita Pepsi. Not sure what that means? Become a sponsor to find out!!

Platinum Sponsor ($75): Shout-outs, a signed program, a signed prop, a 1 minute acapella song dedicated to you in a genre of your choosing, and a PDF guide to help rid yourself of vampires!

Diamond Sponsor ($100): YOU ARE A DIAMOND! This perk gives you everything included in the platinum perk, plus a Limited Edition Lucas Amato Toy Creation!

The Impact

Artists deserve to be paid for their work, it is as simple as that. Your generous donations will allow us to pay our artists fairly for the work they are putting in to the project. We are all either still students, or recently graduated, and so have also incurred the costs of higher education. Your contributions are helping us take our future into our own hands!

You are not only helping our artists, but also the English theatre scene in the Montreal community. As mentioned above, we seek to make theatre accessible to people who may not normally be able to access theatrical performances. As part of this project, we are committed to keeping ticket prices as low as possible. Fundraising efforts such as this campaign help us do that. 

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a show is always a challenge! However, we are taking several steps to ensure the success of our organization:

  1. In addition to regular theatre-going people, we seek to reach people that do not normally go to the theatre. This increases our target demographic.
  2. While [title of show] is a Broadway musical, Home Theatre Productions will not only be doing Broadway musicals. Our mandate allows us to pick shows that reach people interested in all facets of popular culture, whether it be already performed plays or musicals, or new works! 
  3. Our diverse and multitalented team are committed to going the distance, whatever hardships we may face. We have worked together before in some capacity, and we know that we are strong not only as individual artists, but as a collective. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to our project financially, that's okay! Here's some things everyone can do to help us out:

  • Like our page at www.facebook.com/hometheatreproductions
  • Follow us on instagram @hometheatreproductions
  • Use the Indiegogo sharing tools to share our campaign!
  • Come see [title of show] when it goes up at Mainline Theatre September 12-15! 

Thank you for all of your support, we couldn't do this without you!

story:
Short Summary

GBworks is Gianna Burright and Gwynne Bilski in collaboration with a series of artists, invited to make work on and/or with them.  Gwynne and Gianna are both choreographers with their own respective practices, each making movement-based work deeply rooted in autobiographical experience. Together they create and/or curate work through a feminist lens, engaged in conversations that prioritize collaboration, equality, and openness. The formation of GBworks was instigated by Gianna and Gwynne's desire to create ongoing platforms to showcase their own work while also supporting and presenting the work of other female, female identifying, and non-binary emerging artists.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Currently we are asking for £5,000

This money will be going towards: the venue, venue hire, technician, travel, accommodation, print & marketing materials, studio hire, costuming, and photography/videography (to document the work for archival purposes and to have footage with which we can apply for funding and artist residencies).

In establishing our new collective, GBworks, one of our primary goals is to be able to support our own work, while always striving to support the work of other emerging voices, so it will always be important for us to be able to pay ourselves, as well as our collaborators (other choreographers, artists, composers/musicians, costume designers, lighting designers etc). Anything we make above and beyond out initial target will be going towards future projects and all of the associated expenses that contribute to the value of the platforms we are creating.

As an example; immediately following our run at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, we will be producing a show in London (on August 31st at Rosemary Branch Theatre – follow our social media for more updates) where we will be inviting four other emerging female artists (including singer/songwriter and other dance artists and choreographers) and giving them a platform to share their work.

 

The Impact

Our Campaign is important to us because we feel now, more than ever it’s important to be creating platforms for emerging female and non-binary voices. Our contributors will help us achieve international conversations and collaborations that open minds and eyes to the beautiful differences we all share which will be disseminated through curated shows and evenings of performance. 

Over our many coffees and cross-Atlantic facetime calls, we asked ourselves and each other about the kinds of support and opportunities we are looking for and what would be useful to our careers at this stage. Ultimately, what we are searching for are opportunities that will allow us to present our work, and connect with other artists - so instead of waiting around for those to present themselves, we decided to establish a collective with an express goal of creating those opportunities for ourselves and others. We don’t want to wait until we feel more established to offer these kinds of opportunities to others; we want to plant seeds now towards an ever growing community of artists that will bud and bloom alongside us.

 

Risks & Challenges

Every creative venture presents its challenges, and this new venture we are undertaking is no different.

We are working tirelessly to be able to bring I’m Still Here to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, and while we are incredibly happy to be able to invest ourselves, any donation you can support us with will help us greatly. Beyond the financial challenges inherent of bringing a show to life including venue hire, travel, accommodation, rehearsal related costs, marketing, etc., we are in a the unique position of collaborating internationally to establish this new collective, and get our first show onstage all simultaneously! A daunting task? Perhaps- but we are passionate about every bit of what we are doing, and confident that with your help we will find success this summer, and ultimately be able to continue working together to present our own work, and the work of other emerging artists.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that it’s not always possible to contribute financially, but there are plenty of other ways you can support us! The first of which is helping us spread the word – about our show, about this campaign, and about our new collective!

 Of course if you’re in Edinburgh this summer you can support us by coming to see out show (bring some friends along too!). Tickets are on sale now, and you can get yours here: https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/i-m-still... 

Finally, whether or not you are able to attend our show, or contribute to our fundraising campaign, please follow us on social media! We promise fun-filled posts, where you’ll be able to see what were up to, and every follow, every like, every comment, and every share helps us enormously!

Find us on Instagram: @_gbworks_ and share what we’re up to! And use indiegogo sharing tools to help support us!

Perhaps- but we are passionate about every bit of what we are doing, and confident that with your help we will find success this summer, and ultimately be able to continue working together to present our own work, and the work of other emerging artists. Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that it’s not always possible to contribute financially, but there are plenty of other ways you can support us! The first of which is helping us spread the word – about our show, about this campaign, and about our new collective! Of course if you’re in Edinburgh this summer you can support us by coming to see out show (bring some friends along too!). Tickets are on sale now, and you can get yours here: https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/i-m-still... Finally, whether or not you are able to attend our show, or contribute to our fundraising campaign, please follow us on social media! We promise fun-filled posts, where you’ll be able to see what were up to, and every follow, every like, every comment, and every share helps us enormously!Find us on Instagram: @_gbworks_ and share what we’re up to! And use indiegogo sharing tools to help support us!

story:
Our Why 

Dancers Unlimited (DU) is a bi-coastal professional dance company based in NYC and Hawaii. DU creates authentic movement narratives for the advancement of our communities through creative collaboration, performances, and community engagement projects.

In 2020, DU needs a total of $20,000 in annual operating funds as we continue cultivating individual growth through dance and elevating the strength that resides within the artistic community (yes, YOU reading, you’re included!). We hope to have YOUR help in raising $12,000 to kickstart our efforts towards three major initiatives in 2020:

  1. Growing MoveMEANT for Every Body, DU’s new community program that comprises of movement workshops, discussions, and space for expression, reflection, and deep transformation. 
  2. Providing consistent part-time salaries for at least three company dancers to honor and deepen their capacity for creative exploration within DU and expand community engagement in NYC, Hawaii and beyond
  3. Increasing administrative support including hiring a dedicated development director towards greater financial stability and consultants to revamp our digital media library and resources.

DU is at a pivotal point of growth, and we are ready to sail to new horizons!  Your generous support will help us build on this year’s success and embark on another decade of dance-making and global community building.

***All contributions are tax-deductible! Tax-deductible receipts will be issued by Foundation for Independent Artists (FIA), our fiscal sponsor The Foundation for Independent Artists (FIA) is a NY Non-profit organization administered by Pentacle (DanceWorks, Inc.).

The Impact

Last year, with over $10K in individual donors’ support, we were able to bring our Hawaii and NYC chapters together and direct more resources towards developing our community programs. We have grown immensely in this past year, and some of our accomplishments include:

  • Debuted new touring repertoire, CYPHER: Homecoming at two sold-out shows at Oahu Fringe Festival in January and NYC in March
  • Presented and introduced 2 public MoveMEANT programs at Honolulu Biennial 
  • Offered 10 free open rehearsals for NYC dancers to further professional training in contemporary and street dance styles
  • Expanded administrative capacity and stability by joining Pentacle’s administrative and fiscal service programs
  • Became a Boutique Roster artist with Jodi Kaplan & Associates 

With your continued support this year, we are confident that we will continue to elevate!

Every dollar goes a long way...

$15 - goes towards an hour of admin support
$25 - pays for an hour of digital content editing
$50 - subsidizes a day of rehearsal space
$250 - pays for costume designs 
$500 - subsidizes additional creative talent fees (besides dancers) including original music, Production support
$1000 - supports a week of rehearsal and precious development time with dancers 
$1500 - Week-long MoveMEANT workshop materials, production fees, and labor fees

Urgency of Our Work

DU was born out of a commitment to community and responded to provide dance classes to Honolulu’s youth on Furlough Fridays when public schools were closed due to budget cut. We are proud to say that our work remains rooted in community service and a deep sense of KULEANA (responsibility) - values that are held dear in Hawai’i.   

Our creative process builds an ohana that is all about living aloha and honoring our island heritage. Our process thus models the way we wish to relate to one another: with openness, a desire to collaborate, embracing our vulnerabilities as strengths, celebrating WINS and shortcomings. The stories we tell aren’t just about “someone over there” – we stay grounded in our stories, our experiences, and the issues that affect us and our communities. In addition, our development period often includes contributions from non-company members and “non-dancers”. 

With I’mMigration, we hosted 3 immigration meetups around heritage, personal stories and challenges of immigration. Together, everyone in the room built movement phrases based on our individual journeys as well as our relationship to movement. In 2020, we will be in residency at Brooklyn International High School where we will continue to develop movement creation around I'mMigration, while providing a creative platform for the students' personal and family experiences to be examined and shared.

We hope to continue developing more programs like these with community partners. These programs illuminates and communicates all aspects of HUEman experience through exploring our unique individual movement. It is our privilege to honor the past, to honor people, and to use our platform to support connection and healing. 

These are some questions we hold with us in our work and we invite you to reflect on these as well:

  • Who are immigrants? How do/should we re-examine the definition of an immigrant?
  • As settlers  to this aina (land), what is our kuleana (responsibility) to the indigenous people and place?
  • How are our individual migrational stories related to current events and social challenges?

Say YES to a connected and responsible world through dance! Please consider contributing (all donations are tax-deductible) your weight because with your YES, DU's work is making its way to you.

Can't contribute financially at this point of time? Please SHARE our campaign on social media (follow us on facebook and instagram) using #DU2020 and tell your friends, your aunties and uncles, your co-workers and bosses... and tell them what it means to DO YOU and invite them to move with you. 

Credits
DU Co-Founders: Linda Kuo & Emily Hackworth
DU Director: Linda Kuo
DU Company Members: Keala Fung, Mandy Harpstrite, Britnee Hay, Gabriela Messina, Nathaniel Whittaker, Sammi Tai, Candice Taylor, Marmara Tobal, Rikita Turner, Kareem Woods, Hara Zi.  
Guest Artists: Klassic Carella, Eugene “Bboy Spyderman” Jordan IV, Eddy Lathan IV, Jessica Orfe, Kaleo Ten, Nicole Woo
DU Board of Advisors: Auli’i Aweau, Sekou Heru, Jermaine Fletcher, Tania Rudnitsky Hogg, Nikki Roco, Tamara Shaffer
Administrative Assistants: Anya Kress (NYC) & Ariana Masuoka (HI)
Administrative Interns: Lucy Rice (Summer 2019) & Lian Kizner (Fall 2019)
Indiegogo Campaign Manager: Denise Shu Mei 
Dance Ancestors: Kid Dynamo, Marjory Smarth, and Voodoo Ray.  THANK YOU for your support, inspiration and legacy. 

Our deepest gratitude to all the current and past volunteers, artists and collaborators who have blessed us with your time, talent, and faith.  We are here because of you.


Video credits
Music credit: Trade Winds (House Groove Version) by Maineframe 
Filming by: Lian Kizner
Editing by: Kareem Woods 
Storyboard: Denise Shu Mei

story:
What is Watchlist?

Watchlist has been in development for over SEVEN YEARS! After innumerable rewrites, two trips to Berlin, table reads, and a staged reading, this team is thrilled to bring a full production of Lindsay Hope Simon's Watchlist to The Tank in 2020.

Our team believes in paying artists for their work. Theatre is currently more valuable than ever as a means to hold up a mirror to society and process, as a community, the lives we lead and what gives them meaning. Watchlist presents audiences with the opportunity to consider what we fight for and what we take for granted in the information age. 

What We Need & What You Get

The Tank is an incredible venue that provides a lot of administrative and production support to artists so that they can focus on creating. But it takes more than just a space and selling tickets to make a show. Funds from this campaign will contribute to:

  • Stipends to pay every member of the team - actors, designers, director, stage manager, etc
  • A budget for a set to bring this play to life
  • A costume budget, given that Lindsay set half of this play in the 70s
  • Promotional materials like postcards and posters to get people to come see the show!
  • Incidentals like script printing and renting rehearsal space

Perks as expressions of our gratitude will include:

  • Social media shout outs
  • Hand-written thank you notes (from millennials!)
  • Complimentary tickets to the show!
  • Producing credit
  • Nerdy deep dive research collections from Lindsay

The Impact

In addition to your perks, you'll have the knowledge that your contribution will help to fund a fully-realized, brand new theatrical production that can take pride in compensating its creators. You will be supporting an intentionally diverse team of folks including women, LGBTQ folks, and people of color.

Watchlist is about the world we live in now and how we face the real challenges of being alive in society. How we handle feeling small when the world feels so big. How we fight for what we believe in and never give up hope. Our team believes that's a message the world needs right now, and we want to share it fully with our audiences in the most professional way possible.

Creating meaningful theatre is challenging enough. Finding the money to produce it is a whole other hurdle. We choose to fund on indiegogo because we'll receive our money even if we don't reach our ambitious goal - and even that goal is based on a modest budget. During and after the holidays is a difficult time to raise money as folks are focused on family gift-giving and end-of-year charitable donations. We hope if you value live theatre you'll consider including us in your generosity.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign on social media! Follow us on instagram @watchlistplay! Buy a ticket to the show! Bring a friend!

story:
What's the Deal?

TJ Loves Sally 4 Ever, written by Philly-based playwright James Ijames, is having its world premiere at the newly renovated performance space JACK this February, and we need your support to bring this play to life! In order to take this play from the page to the stage we need to raise $6,500 by December 16th and with your generosity we know we can do it.

What's the play about?

At a southern university established by a founding father, TJ is a university dean and Sally his work-study student. But TJ’s power has limits and Sally knows it. In TJ Loves Sally 4 Ever, playwright James Ijames hotwires a ride that leaves history’s burdens in the dust and off-roads a trail for the future. In short, imagine if Thomas Jefferson was a University Dean and Sally Hemings was his work-study student. Isuncomfortable

 

A CALL TO ACTION! (WHAT YOUR $$$ GOES TOWARDS)

Communities of color need access to more stories where they see themselves triumph without the presence of violence. Directed by JACK’s Co-Director Jordana De La Cruz, TJ Loves Sally 4 Ever asks us to examine what we brought into this world and what we leave behind and how we move forward together despite our legacies.

This play has had readings at Play Penn in Philadelphia, Playwrights Horizons in New York City and received the 2019 Relentless Award Honorable Mention but has yet to be produced, UNTIL NOW!

Help us in our mission to Prioritize People First!

  • Subsidized tickets for young people of color and local senior centers
  • Guaranteed fees for our incredible DESIGNERS and CREATIVE TEAM
  • Guaranteed fees for CAST and CREW
     

 Who is leading this Call To Action? 

 

James Ijames is a Philadelphia based performer and playwright. James’ plays have been produced by Flashpoint Theater Company, Orbiter 3, Theatre Horizon (Philadelphia, PA), The National Black Theatre (NYC), Ally Theatre (Washington DC) and have received development with PlayPenn New Play Conference, The Lark, Playwright's Horizon, Clubbed Thumb, Villanova Theater, Headlands Art Center, and Victory Garden. James is the 2011 F. Otto Haas Award for an Emerging Artist recipient, a 2011 Independence Foundation Fellow, a 2015 Pew Fellow for Playwriting, the 2015 winner of the Terrance McNally New Play Award for WHITE, the 2015 Kesselring Honorable Mention Prize winner for ....Miz Martha the 2018 Kesselring Prize Winner for Kill Move Paradise and a 2017 recipient of the Whiting Award.  James is a founding member of Orbiter 3, Philadelphia’s first playwright producing collective. James is an Assistant Professor of Theatre at Villanova University and resides in South Philadelphia. “His plays take historical artifact and current event and turn them upside down in a series of comedic surprises — but all the humor lies on the edge of horror.”

Jordana De La Cruz is a theater maker and Co-Director of JACK, an Obie-Award winning performance venue meets civic space in Brooklyn, New York. She creates performances, gatherings, and public programs that question what it means to be free and more urgently, how we are helping each other achieve this freedom. Her practice sparks cross-cultural dialogue and expands the concept of community. Before joining JACK, as Program Manager at Park Avenue Armory Jordana was instrumental in the creation of the institution’s Public Programs Series. Jordana is a proud member of Theatre Communications Group’s Rising Leaders of Color Program.

Chris Ignacio is a Filipino-American theatre artist, musician, puppeteer, producer and educator who has worked nationally and abroad since graduating from The Boston Conservatory at Berklee. He is a Culture Push Fellow for Utopian Practice, and Queens Council on the Arts: Community Engagement Commissioning grantee for his self-produced project Co-written, which involves collaborative songwriting with young people of color. Chris served as Associate Producer for the Obie Award Winning Ma-Yi Theater (KPOP), and currently works at La MaMa ETC.

Gerardo Díaz Sánchez is a NYC-based scenic designer from Guayama, Puerto Rico. His most recent theater credits include: Pride and Prejudice (upcoming at Long Wharf Theatre),  For Carmen in San Sebastián (Merry-Go-Round Theatre), El Huracán (Yale Repertory Theater), Tent Revival and Romeo and Juliet (Yale School of Drama). Gerardo received his MFA from the Yale School of Drama, and his BA from the School of Architecture at the University of Puerto Rico.

Megan Lang is a New York based lighting designer who has designed at BAM, La Mama, Abrons Arts Center, EST, Under St. Mark's, the Wild Project, Dixon Place, 59E59, JACK, Atlantic Stage 2, among others. Recent designs include JACK & (BAM Next Wave and US tour, dir. Kaneza Schaal), Riot Antigone (La Mama, dir. Seonjae Kim), and Oye! For My Dear Brooklyn(Abrons Arts Center and UTR, dir. Artem Yatsunov). She is the resident lighting designer for the Ubumuntu Arts Festival in Rwanda.

Kathy Ruvuna is New York based sound designer and composer originally from San Antonio, Texas. She is a recent graduate of the Yale School of Drama, where her credits include Tent Revival, Pentecost, and Much Ado About Nothing. Her work has also been heard in Good Faith (Yale Repertory Theatre), Fireflies, Taking Warsan Shire Out of Context on the Eve of the Great Storm, It’s Not About My Mother, the feels… (KMS), among others.

Candace L. Taylor is a performer, choreographer, and entrepreneur.   She has worked as a choreographic associate for If Pretty Hurts Ugly Must Be a Muhfucka (Playwrights Horizons), and A Strange Loop (Playwrights Horizons) with Raja Feather Kelly. Candace has most notably featured her own choreographic work at the National Theatre of Nicaragua in the completion of a dance anthropology Fulbright research grant. Candace finds her purpose in bringing movement to the masses, highlighting its power to transform lives and spread joy to all who are willing to engage.

Nissy Aya is a Black girl from the Bronx. She is a writer, educator, and cultural worker who believes in the transformative nature of storytelling and sees theatre as a tool to create social change by empowering disenfranchised communities to unapologetically portray their whole selves on stage. As an artist, her work centers the voices of Black women, explores the lines between history and memory, details both the presence and absence of love and recounts extremely tall tales.

story:
Short Summary

Geeksdanz returns to scare the pants off our audiences with Manifestations III: Nightmare Hauntings! Two performances of the (PG-13) show, on Sunday October 27th at 6:30 and 9:00 pm at the Glitter Box Theater, comprise the third year of Geeksdanz's collaboration between dance and storytelling. Featuring a whole new selection of ghost stories told live by our featured storyteller Lisa Hollingsworth-Segedy, Manifestations III melds dance, music and story to create an intensely atmospheric performance that will chill your blood and make your skin crawl. Is that a witch at the window, or a fox at the foot of your bed? An awl-fingered shapeshifter, or a zombie in search of his head? The theater fills with sound and movement as the dancers weave through Lisa's words, urging you not to trust the beings who appear at the height of your nightmares. Tickets $15 at the door.
 

What We Need & What You Get

Most of the funding for this project goes towards paying the artists.  We can't put on this show without our dancers and our spectacular storyteller, and we can't pay them without you!

Some of the funding will go towards promotional materials such as posters, flyers, etc.  We need your help to get the word out and fill the seats!

And some of the funding will go towards covering our production costs - sourcing costumes, paying for rehearsal space, and general overhead.  We need you to keep the company going!

If we surpass our goal, our artists will receive a larger, more appropriate stipend, and we as a company will be better able to continue creating and presenting even more new works!

In return, you get to choose from a host of goodies.  From a coffee date with the artistic director or the storyteller to a poster signed by the whole cast, there's sure to be something you'd like in the list over there.  Go ahead, take your pick!

 

The Impact

Geeksdanz’s mission is to introduce dance to audiences that would not normally be drawn to it, and to illustrate the universality of dance as a means of emotional expression. Geeksdanz achieves this by systematically applying the context of dance to an enormous variety of topics and interests, and targeting performances towards the specific audiences who share those interests.

In April of 2013, we presented Challenge Mode, a concert about video games, to an audience comprised of both dance patrons and gamers.  As part of our mission, we presented an excerpt of Challenge Mode at Tekkoshocon X-2, a Japanese Pop Culture convention, and Artistic Director Ellen Deutsch led a discussion panel titled "An Artist's Views on the Games-As-Art Debate." Through these events, we encouraged attendees to think critically about the difficulty of defining art, and where and how video games might fit into the art world.  Ellen's panels have since become a fixture of Tekkoshocon, engaging attendees every year in thinking of games and anime as art forms in their own right.

We presented the first edition of "Manifestations" in 2013, after showing an excerpt at the Three Rivers Storytelling Festival.  Our second feature work, "Up to Chance," was a real-time dance interpretation of a live Dungeons and Dragons game, which we presented at the Pittsburgh Fringe Festival in May.  The following fall we presented "Manifestations II" and introduced dance to even more storytelling fans.  In August of 2015 we took on the work of young adult author John Green with "Finding Margo, Losing Gus," which we presented at several libraries around Pittsburgh.  Each of these works continued our ongoing mission to introduce dance to other audiences.

Your contributions will help us broaden our audience yet again with this third installment in the Manifestations series, and encourage even more people to consider dance as an exciting evening's entertainment.  Plus, you get to help us scare the pants off of our audiences!  What could be better?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, don't sweat it!  Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word on facebook, twitter, etc. and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Tell all your friends, especially those who live in Pittsburgh, and encourage them to come see the show!
  • Come to the show yourself!  Let us invade your dreams!

story:
Our Story - who are we?

  • We are Theatre 6 and Tales Retold. Two successful touring companies coming together to create a radical new adaptation of Charles Dickens' 'Great Expectations'.

  • This show is a dynamic new version of a classic novel, performed by three actor musicians and featuring an original score by Maria Haik Escudero.

  • We are committed to making theatre work that gives space to unheard stories and brave new ideas. We are also committed to the sustainability and accessibility of our shows. We believe these two things are the future. 

  • We are proud that this production supports an all female producing and creative team. 

Why we need your help

  • We are looking to raise £4000 through this campaign towards our show.

  • We are offering a range of rewards including posters signed by the cast and creative team and a thank you in the programme.

  • The contributions you make will assist us with design materials, costume, props and cast and creative wages to make this show. 

Your contribution to the future of theatre

Your contribution will make such a huge difference to us during a very tricky time for everyone -  especially the creative industries. 

  • You will be helping us to tour ground breaking theatre around the UK, which will be joyful and entertaining for people to see safely outdoors.

  • We have a successful track record with touring projects, Theatre 6 - Persuasion (UK tour), Gabriel (UK tour) and Tales Retold (Uncle Vanya, Antigone).

  • We are excited to build long lasting relationships with contributors by staying in touch and involving them in the development of our companies and our shows. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk we are facing is our performances being affected due to extreme weather and COVID restrictions.

  • We will be keeping all audience and staff safe at our venues in line with government guidelines using hand sanitiser, face coverings and social distanced seating.

  • We are performing Estella in both indoor and outdoor venues during the summer. 

  • We have a contigency plan which would involve live streaming our show and embarking on a larger 2022 tour.

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be able to contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help us spread the word:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and reshare our posts on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram @TalesRetold @Theatre6!

  • Come and see 'Estella' on tour at one of our venues in the summer. 

Thank you for reading our campaign and we hope to see you this summer at one of our touring venues!

story:
Short Summary

Come Find Me - A Christmas Musical  tells the story of Benjamin Patterson (an autistic nine-year-old), his sister Kami (a pre-med student at Yale University), and their father Harry (widowed Air Force lieutenant). When Harry is called away on a top-secret military mission just before Christmas, Ben and Kami’s already turbulent lives are shaken again. With a wish, a letter, and some unique seasonal help, the Patterson family discovers what just an ounce of belief can do.

A musical for all ages, Come Find Me - A Christmas Musical will strike a chord in the hearts of young and old alike, realizing it takes courage, humility, and sometimes a village to help keep Christmas hope alive. 

Help us bring the story to life as we take the stage on December 20, 2018 at the beautiful UT Tyler Braithwaite Recital Hall. Our concert version will include musical highlights from the show including original festive numbers and moving ballads of hope as well as unique twists on familiar holiday tunes.

 

Our Need

We need $6,000 to get our show up this December. That covers facility and equipment rental, technical staff, musicians, singers, marketing, and guest reception. 

And just to show you we appreciate you being part of OUR VILLAGE, here are a few perks for your generous support of our dream! For varying levels of contributions, you'll get:

  • Social media shout-outs
  • Your name listed on our website
  • Your name listed in our program
  • VIP seating at the show
  • Meet the show creators
  • AND MORE!

Interested in being a larger part of the future of Come Find Me - A Christmas Musical? Contact us at info@comefindmemusical.com for future development and investment opportunities.

Our Why

Have you ever wanted to be a part of something magical? To be on the creating end of something that moves and inspires? We have longed to make that happen since we first started writing and performing as children. After years of hard work and lots of patience (with each other...see video 2 above), we are working to realize the dream that has always been inside of us. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know money is tight for a lot of people. That's ok! The easiest way to help us is to share our campaign on social media. Share it with your friends. Tell your mom! I know she'd love it!

From previous readings:

Finalist, Battle of the Christmas Musicals • Brookfield Theatre of the Arts, Brookfield, CT • July, 2017

 

Developmental Reading, OhLook Performing Arts Center, Grapevine, Texas • May 2018

 

And your fearless creators at the Brookfield performance.

story:
Together, Let's Make History

For the past five years, Otherworld Theatre has received nationwide acclaim for our dedication to the performance of Science Fiction and Fantasy. Now, we have found an amazing venue in Chicago, and find ourselves with the opportunity to take our movement to the next level and give genre performance a permanent home.

Our aim is to raise money for one full operational year - around $120,000 - to help us cover the costs of city permits, paint, salaries, and equipment we will need to make the space all we dream it can become.

We have already raised 60k in pledges, but we need your help to get us to our ultimate goal.

 

The Space

The property is located at 3914 N Clark Street. The venue boasts a two-stage facility with a 120 seat main stage, 40 seat black box, bar, and lobby located a few blocks north of Wrigley Field.

Here are some renderings of our vision below:

The Work

Otherworld Theatre Company, established five years ago, has already made a splash in the Chicago Theatrical Scene.

  • We were named best new theatre company in The Chicago Reader in 2016, and our Artistic Director Tiffany Keane Schaefer was named best new theatre director in The Chicago Reader for 2017.
  • We are a 501c3 tax exempt organization. Any donations received will be followed up with a tax-exempt letter.

Below, check out our 2017 Gala Video to see clips of our previous productions:

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute to our cause. However, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Share our campaign and help get the word out that Science Fiction and Fantasy Theatre is looking for a home here in Chicago!
  • Like us on Facebook and Follow us on Instagram and Twitter

___________________________

THANK YOU FOR YOUR INTEREST IN OUR PROJECT.

If you are interested in becoming a major donor but would like to learn more, please reach out to our Director of Development Dylan Schaefer at dylan@otherworldtheatre.org.

story:
AT LEAST READ THIS PART...

Gina Femia has written a remarkable play inspired by the amazing world of all-female roller derby. The play explores female relationships and asks how much you’re willing to sacrifice – or lose – to follow your heart.  While it has a serious topic at its core, our Roller Derby team the Brooklyn Scallywags - populated with some wonderful/quirky/real characters - will guarantee  an entertaining evening filled with moments of rich humor, powerful emotion and dramatic (simulated) Roller Derby action!    

We have a theatre space, but we still need…

  • A set
  • Costumes (14 actors, multiple scenes….over 50 changes!)
  • Designer stipends – we believe these talented theatre artists should be compensated for their work
  • Programs, postcards, a banner for the front of the theatre, etc.

You get the idea.  We need to raise about $10,000 to mount the production we think this script deserves.  We are hoping to raise at least $6,000 of that with this campaign. 

THANK YOU for helping bring this script to life

Hopefully some of our perks will inspire you.  But even more importantly, we hope supporting great theatre and this exceptional script will inspire you. 

We will be grateful for any donation, no matter how small.  And, if you have no funds to give, then...

  • Help us spread the word. Tell your theatre friends (and your Roller Derby fan friends) about our campaign
  • Share us on Facebook and other social media sites

And don’t forget to come experience “FOR THE LOVE OF” opening April 26th  (with your help) at Theatre of NOTE, 1517 Cahuenga Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90028. 

 

IF YOU WANT MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PLAY AND OUR TEAM, READ THIS…

Gina Femia’s plays include The Violet Sisters (Great Plains Theatre Conference), Annie and the Fat Man (Finalist, Leah Ryan Prize for Emerging Playwrights, Honorable Mention The Kilroys), The Mermaids' Parade (Finalist, Princess Grace Award), ALLOND(R)A (Finalist, Doric Wilson Independent Playwriting Award), Super, or, How Clark Graves Learned to Fly (semi-finalist The O’Neill and The Princess Grace Award),  Mahogany Brown and the Case of the Disappearing Kid (The Brick’s Comic Book Theatre Festival), and Five-Sided Triangle (Dixon Place’s HOT!Fest, The Downtown Urban Theatre Festival). Gina is a current member of Lather, Rinse, Repeat, a New Georges Affiliated Artist and a New York Madness Company Member, has received residencies with NTI at the O’Neill, SPACE on Ryder Farm, Fresh Ground Pepper and Grin City Collective. She has been nominated for the Doric Wilson Award and the Cherry Lane Theatre Mentor Project and is a Semifinalist for the P73 Playwriting Fellowship. MFA, Sarah Lawrence College (Lipkin Prize in Playwriting).

Gina’s play For The Love Of received its World Premiere at Chicago’s Pride Films & Plays.  When Joy gets on the Brooklyn Scallywags and meets the star, Lizzie Lightning, she, and her long-term partner Michelle find their lives turned upside down.

This is a magnificent piece of writing, but to give it the production it deserves our small company desperately needs to raise some funds.  The show is slated to open at our theatre on 1517 Cahuenga Boulevard in Hollywood on April 26th, 2018 with talented director/choreographer Rhonda Kohl at the helm.

Our all-female design team includes costume designer Vicki Conrad, scenic designer Elizabeth Smith, Rose Malone designing lights, graphic designer Maybelle Pineda, and our sound design is by Gillian Moon (who skates with the San Fernando Valley roller derby league under the name “DeciBelle”).  The producers for Theatre of NOTE are David Bickford, Jenny Soo and Kelly Lingen (a/k/a/ “Lucretia Hott” of the Los Angeles Derby Dolls).

Thank you for your help! 

 NOTE:   "THE DERBY WORKOUT PERK" WILL BE AT A DATE TBD.  (Probably not April 13, as originally announced, but to a date mutually acceptable to the winners of this perk!)

-- VIDEO COURTESY OF MARINER PICTURES --

story:
About

A leading actress in an award-winning Chinese film? A contender for “The Asian Arts Award”? Once an intern working for the infamous Will Smith? Hong Kong based artist Gabby So carries multiple identities, yet her favorite one is being her own actress-producer, having created 30 one-woman-shows across Hong Kong, New York and Edinburgh. British media Sky TV recognized her as “the rising star of Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2016”, while she was covered by many international media such as The Independent, The Stage and Time Out.

But without your help, she cannot take her latest work, "Struggle for Happiness", to New York by the coming New Year. The amount is needed for the minimum production cost and touring expenses of a week run. Crowdfunding is her best means because it endows her with the responsibilities for the people, rather than to a few sponsors or donors; after all, her artistic vision is to create with the public, and especially, with you.

Fringe theater is an underrated source of creativity and freedom around the world. Your contribution will support the experimentation of raw ideas, away from censorship, free from commercial constraints - providing alternatives for the painters, the poets, and the other "fools who dream".

What We Need & What You Get

We need $10,000 USD to run the show from 9-14 January 2018 at the Studio Theatre of Theatre Row:

  • 50% - Set, Props, Costumes and Makeup
  • 35% - Theater Rental and Rehearsal Space
  • 15% - Flights and Accommodation for 3 Staffs

In return, you may get a backstage tour after a free show, or a 30-minute Skype sharing session on acting and writing if you are somewhere else. While the happy snacks are fortune cookies with her special messages for you, the ultimate happy prize is "A Day in Hong Kong with Gabby".

Let's "Struggle for Happiness"

Sophia has it all. 

Sophia is living in the dream of every female in the 19th century. She is a genius with extraordinary memory. She is the winner of the prestigious Bordin Prize. She is known to be the best Russian mathematician. She is married. Yet, to Sophia,  happiness is all but missing in her life.

Is there a cure? Is there a function one can apply to maximize one's own happiness? What are the variables for this ultimate function? Sophia is desperately looking for the answer.

As Sophia digs in to every corner of her mind, flipping through pages in her book of life, she seems to have found what she wants, in somewhere that is the least expected to her…
story_txt:
About
A leading actress in an award-winning Chinese film? A contender for “The Asian Arts Award”? Once an intern working for the infamous Will Smith? Hong Kong based artist Gabby So carries multiple identities, yet her favorite one is being her own actress-producer, having created 30 one-woman-shows across Hong Kong, New York and Edinburgh. British media Sky TV recognized her as “the rising star of Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2016”, while she was covered by many international media such as The Independent, The Stage and Time Out.
But without your help, she cannot take her latest work, "Struggle for Happiness", to New York by the coming New Year. The amount is needed for the minimum production cost and touring expenses of a week run. Crowdfunding is her best means because it endows her with the responsibilities for the people, rather than to a few sponsors or donors; after all, her artistic vision is to create with the public, and especially, with you.
Fringe theater is an underrated source of creativity and freedom around the world. Your contribution will support the experimentation of raw ideas, away from censorship, free from commercial constraints - providing alternatives for the painters, the poets, and the other "fools who dream".

What We Need & What You Get
We need $10,000 USD to run the show from 9-14 January 2018 at the Studio Theatre of Theatre Row:

50% - Set, Props, Costumes and Makeup
35% - Theater Rental and Rehearsal Space
15% - Flights and Accommodation for 3 Staffs

In return, you may get a backstage tour after a free show, or a 30-minute Skype sharing session on acting and writing if you are somewhere else. While the happy snacks are fortune cookies with her special messages for you, the ultimate happy prize is "A Day in Hong Kong with Gabby".

Let's "Struggle for Happiness"
Sophia has it all. 
Sophia is living in the dream of every female in the 19th century. She is a genius with extraordinary memory. She is the winner of the prestigious Bordin Prize. She is known to be the best Russian mathematician. She is married. Yet, to Sophia,  happiness is all but missing in her life.
Is there a cure? Is there a function one can apply to maximize one's own happiness? What are the variables for this ultimate function? Sophia is desperately looking for the answer.
As Sophia digs in to every corner of her mind, flipping through pages in her book of life, she seems to have found what she wants, in somewhere that is the least expected to her…

story:
Dear friends,

We are dancers and choreographers. We met in London in the postgraduate programme of the London Contemporary Dance School and found an immediate chemistry performing and creating together. Our site-specific collaboration was nominated one of the top student works at LCDS in 2014.  Since then, Sze moved home to Singapore and Gabi to Santiago.

In 2016, we took a gamble. We received our first international residency as dance artists, but with too short a notice to get any funding from our home countries. We bit the bullet and went to Croatia anyway, paying our own way. For three weeks we shared a room with four other artists and scrounged for salvaged vegetables in the Zagreb markets to cut our food costs. We created "Talk to me and I slap you". It's not pretty dancing. It is a high-stakes work where we challenged ourselves to reach into questions about the dynamics of violence, fear and loneliness in relationships. Whether it is the relationship of the performer to the audience, or relationships of love, family or power. We had one packed performance at midnight in a Zagreb bar. The connection with the audience was electric. A critic said we could be “a perfect mirror to the hopeless shortcomings of our present social condition.”

For the past year and a half we have worked so hard to try and bring this work to more audiences in the UK and Asia, but did not find the right opportunity. Finally, we have a chance to redevelop this work for audiences in Singapore and Bangkok in February 2018.

We have some support from the Singapore National Arts Council, but this and ticket sales will only cover 25% of our production costs. We have also been invited by Democrazy Theatre Studio in Bangkok - but too late to apply for institutional funding for travel. As the venue costs will be covered by our hosts, it will only cost another SGD 650 to fly us to and house us in Bangkok so that we can share this work there.

Can you support us, in cash or in kind? What you will be helping to support (figures in SGD):

Singapore – 13 Days, $12,260

$3200 Theatre and rehearsal space rental, staging equipment
$2000 Producing stage manager and technical crew
$500    Dramaturg
$3000  Gabi’s flight to Singapore and accommodation
$1500  Gabi and Sze’s artist fees each
$560    Marketing design and printing

Bangkok – 7 days, $650
$250   Gabi and Sze’s airfare to Bangkok
$400   Gabi and Sze’s Bangkok accommodation

Total Tour Cost: $12,910
+$1065.80    Crowdfunding platform fees (5% fee, 3% credit card fee, USD 25 transfer)
-$3000 Grant funding

Total Funds needed: SGD10,976 (USD 8,164)

About us

Sze stepped into a dance class for a university P.E. requirement, and hasn’t stopped dancing since. Since training at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (Best graduate, Diploma in Dance) and the London Contemporary Dance School (MA with Distinction) she has created and performed as an independent artist. Her unique interdisciplinary vision emphasises the intimate and sensorial, connecting the threads of the body with social issues, identity and gender. She blends conceptual, interactive, improvisatory and cross-cultural approaches for theatres, public spaces, video installation and film. Her choreographic work has been shown in Singapore, the UK, Malaysia, Indonesia, Taiwan, Croatia and Laos, as well as dance film festivals in the USA and Brazil. She has been selected for support by the Substation (Open Call 2013), Dance Nucleus (ELEMENT artist 2017), and FAKI Festival of Alternative Theatre (residency in Zagreb, 2016). She lectures on a part time basis at the LaSalle College of the Arts, and is a passionate advocate for the rights and sustainable careers of dancers in Singapore, and the development of artistic networks and exchange in Southeast Asia.

“Sze-Wei demonstrated herself as an artist with strong and brave visions.” – Noor Effendy Ibrahim, Artistic Director of the Substation 2010-2015 on Do Gorillas Peel Bananas? by Chan Sze-Wei, 2013

Gabriela is a dance artist originally from Chile. Her powerfully fluid physicality and charismatic presence have featured in tours with UK companies BalletLORENT, Experiential Dance Company, and Lizzie Klotz Company, as well as the creation of performances with Paolo Mangiola (Italy) and Joanna Kalm (Estonia). Her choreographic collaborations have been presented at the International Festival of Glasgow (with Nerea Gurrutxaga), and at the FAKI festival of alternative theatre in Zagreb (with Chan Sze-Wei). She holds a BA in Contemporary Dance from Trinity Laban Conservatoire (UK), a postgraduate diploma from London Contemporary Dance School, is a graduate of ‘The Dancers’ Course’ by BalletBoyz UK, and will be commencing a Master in Cultural Studies and Arts Management in 2018. A longtime practitioner and teacher of Flying Low/Passing Through dance technique, she is among a select group of artists worldwide directly certified to teach by founder David Zambrano. In 2017 she was the Artistic director of Estudio De Danza Francisca Garcia in Santiago. 

“[Gabriela] has a unique and individual performance quality with a sense of intrigue, mystery and wonder.” Debbi Purtill, UK choreographer

Show Synopsis

The one who loves you hits you. The one who hits you loves you. The one who loves you hurts you.
This is a piece about relationships, unfortunately.
(We can’t get away from them.)

One woman, one chair, one microphone. And a chair opposite her, for you.
In an intimate conversation, she lays her cards on the table: talk to her, and she might (really) slap you.
Playing on the anticipation of what happens when a theatre audience talks back, this piece threads together live audience encounters with funny and frightening stories of loneliness, domestic violence, authority, gender, and sensuality.

This is an encounter rather than a spectacle. Seated in the round, the audience is a group witness. The performer waits, for you. You are invited to a series of intimate one-to-one conversations in playfulness, dancing, sadness, silence… and a collective journey to confront fear, violence, love and a moment of real human connection.

story:
WHY GIVE / WHY NOW / WHY THIS

  • AMERICAN AF is happening at the NEW OHIO THEATRE SEPTEMBER 21 thro OCTOBER 7 !
  • my name is Jessica Almasy, I am an actress, writer, art maker and cofounding member of the TEAM (www.theteamplays.org). we recently staged a multigenerational cover band concert of radical reimaginings of seminal protest music in a performance called PRIMER FOR A FAILED SUPERPOWER. I was SO SET INTO ACTION by the vision and activism of our director Rachel Chavkin and musical director Orion Johnstone, that when a fortuitous turn of events delivered the opportunity to curate three weeks of theatre space I knew I needed to keep the metabolic community of PRIMER rolling
  • I am learning that everything we do is a political act and our stages both in new york city and across america - as often as they are a refuge - are still spaces where white narrative is taken as the neutral base identity and conversation and this is dangerous for everyone. this festival seeks to radically reconfigure the inequity of that centralization, to decentralize whiteness as the norm and the given with "other" or "alternate" identities as the accent or the subtext and to create a space that centralizes and illuminates artists of color and queer, radical artists and their work that is speaking IMMEDIATELY, URGENTLY, TO AND OUT OF THIS INCREDIBLY VICIOUS TIME that is both frightening and RIFE WITH POSITIVE POTENTIALITY. 

WHAT WE NEED / WHERE IT GOES

  • this is an enormous undertaking for me: Im a single mother living out of state (!) so we need to hire HELP ! our TD / technical director will be working every day with their team to get all of our artists in and out of the space with the rehearsal time they need, the gear they need, and the support to dignify their visions
  • our graphic design, web design, and art director team will be working in an incredibly speedy turnover to get our message out and create an online home base to welcome audiences, sell tickets, and make our projects easy to access and get into 
  • GIFTS ! watching whats happening in Houston now and having been thro Sandy with my family myself, its difficult to espouse physical objects or tokens as gifts but what we can give is quality content and quality experiences. in exchange for your donation your name will be posted on your website, on social media, and in our theatre space so you will be present as much as all of the artists. in addition, for our asking donation of $100 you will receive an MP3 recording of a selection of great American playwriting, oratory, or literature, chosen especially for you ! AND you get the thrilling joy of being the financial backer of an inaugural and deeply vital event 

THE IMPACT

this event is as much a performance series to bring smart as hell new work into the light as it is a the continuation and cultivation of artists looking to find and create a healing space, a space from which we can emerge ready to face the next day's challenges with clearer eyes and wiser hearts. this festival is a learning space for everyone involved and is open to the insight and kindness that everyone will bring to it 

WHAT MORE / WHAT ELSE 

 

  • GET INTO THIS WITH US !
  • PLS GET THE WORD OUT !
  • SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN, SEND US ARTISTS WHO SHOULD BE PERFORMING WITH US !
  • AND COME JOIN US !

AND COME JOIN US !

story:
Ignite the Work. Challenge the Artist. Embolden the Audience.

Theatre [Untitled] strives to provide a nurturing platform for undiscovered artists to forge igniting, challenging, and emboldening new and reinvented works. This year we are proud to announce that we are launching our inaugural season. We are excited to work with emerging playwrights around New York City to bring to the forefront relevant, exciting, and  impactful art to the New York City artistic community. We are also proud to bring Actor's Professional Theatre to the forefront of New York City artistic education with classes and workshops that focus on enriching and enhancing the mind, soul, and body of young artists across the country. 

With your help, we be able to explode on to the artistic scene working with the highest level artists in the business and bringing the highest quality art. We will use theatre to promote inclusion, kindness, and open mindedness. With your support, we will teach young artists that they have a voice and that voice has value and worth. With your help, we will ignite the work, challenge the artist, and embolden the audience. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $10,000 to fund our 2018-2019 season and educational programming. By choosing to be a collaborator with us, your contribution will go toward the salaries for our teaching artists, actors, creative team, and playwrights. Your contribution will also help fund rehearsal/class space rental costs, performance venue rental costs, marketing materials, production costs, and company startup costs. Every contribution will be used with care to make a meaningful difference in the lives of our artists and our audiences. 

We have some really great perks for all of our collaborators including tickets to our first project "The Whale Play" By: Kati Schwartz, invitations to our opening night party for "The Whale Play", classes with APTC, and a spot in our fall audition workshop with APTC. 

Risks & Challenges

Starting a company does come with special risks and challenges. Our biggest challenge will be to stand out in New York City, a city that is artistically very saturated. We intend on continuing to use our mission statement and core values as a litmus test for everything we do to ensure that we are producing work that is unique to our company that will stand out in a city full of creative energy. We intend on working with artists who are experts in their craft to push our company and educational programming to the top of artistic excellence while continuing to push the envelope and developing new ways to hone our craft.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any and all kinds of help make a huge difference! You can be a collaborator with us in more ways than just money! Please like the Theatre [Untitled] and APTC facebook and instagram pages. Please share our campaign and spread the message and the goals! Please tell us what you would like to see from us! Any form of collaboration is highly valued and appreciated.

story:
The First!

Did you know Acadia National Park is tied to the founding of the first land trust in the world? That's right, the very first statewide preservation and conservation association for public land started in Massachusetts. Then the idea was picked up by a loving father who brought it to Bar Harbor, Maine.

The stories of Acadia's journey to a National Park are ripe fruit for a new musical. From the Native American's who inhabited Acadia to now, it's a story that needs to be heard and told. 

Let's celebrate the stories of these larger than life individuals who had the vision to preserve these wild spaces, so we could all enjoy them. This is a musical that brings awareness to conservation, and shows the struggle as well. It’s not all roses trying to protect these magical places; everybody wants a piece. It takes perseverance and powerful people standing up for these wild habitats. Let's hear their stories of how Acadia National Park came to be!

A little about about the creator of this piece - Blake Whyte.  

Blake is a Broadway Actor, Singer/Songwriter, and brand new father, who brings humor, improvisation, and great storytelling to his live shows. He has starred in the shows 'Wicked' and 'Mamma Mia!' on Broadway. Unpredictable, yet fluid, and freely authentic, he is a dynamic songwriter and vocalist with supreme soul.  Blake creates experiences that reawaken our strong bonds to the earth and humanity. 

As a singer/songwriter he released his debut album entitled ‘More Like Myself’ available on Spotify and iTunes, and was named NY-1's Pick of the Week for his hit show at Joe's Pub. He has headlined over 50 shows at venues across New York City. Blake is a proud native of Portage, Michigan. Listen and hear more at blakewhyte.com

Challenges

A musical has a lot of collaborative components to it. The challenges we face are raising funds to properly develop this piece of musical theatre. All funds raised will be used for stipends, transportation, food, and housing for all creatives involved in this project.  And for further development of this musical for it's first full production! 

The world will be a better place if we all go outside for a hike.

story:
Short Summary

Continuum Dance Project blurs the boundaries of dance and theatre. Based in Trinidad and Tobago, it’s a laboratory to explore contemporary Caribbean movement. The critically acclaimed company has created and presented various works since 2004. This year, the company has been invited to represent Trinidad and Tobago at the Limon Roots Afro-Cultural Festival in Limon, Costa Rica in August, but we need the airfare to get there.  We’re asking for your help to give seven company members the opportunity to participate in this important cultural event so that we can represent our country at the world-famous National Theatre.  

EVERY LITTLE BIT COUNTS, SO WHETHER IT'S US$5 OR US$5000:  

Thanks so very much for your support!

story:
My name is Johanna Meyer. I am asking for support to fully produce piece.piece, my newest evening-length dance, for the first time in New York City. Thanks the Gibney Dance Center's fiscal sponsorship, your donation is tax-deductible. 

Piece.piece is specifically adapted to each theater venue or environment where it's performed; New York is its second iteration. Piece.piece will be performed at  Gibney Dance Center in New York City September 9, 10,11,12th. 

For tickets: 

https://gibneydance.org/performance/making-space-fall-2015/johanna-s-meyer/

WHO AM I?

I am a dancer and choreographer living and working in New York. I have been making dances since 1993. I have split my time between making my own work, choreographing for experimental theater, and performing. Since 2001, I have made several smaller works, while pursuing working for other choreographers and directors such as: Karen Sherman, Juliana Francis, Tanya Gagne, Nami Yamamoto, Ken Nintzel, Victoria Vazquez, Richard Maxwell, and DJ Mendel, among others,.

Piece.piece is the product of three years' work at The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. It was premiered at the Krannert Center For the Performing Arts. After I came back to New York, Gibney Dance Center asked me to remount piece.piece for their Making Space Fall 2015 series. Originally performed in a spacious black box theater, this new version is presented in the more intimate Agnes Varis Performance Lab located at Gibney.

WHAT IS THIS?

Piece.piece is a dance for six dancers, a sound designer, a beanbag, a fox mask, and a chair. My outlandishly talented team of performers and designers is spread out across Illinois, New York and California, and they are crucial to help reconstruct the world of piece.piece: Jennifer Allen, Angelica Angulo-Soledad, Emily Bock, Angie Pittman, Hadley Smith, Lailye Weidman, and sound designer Jeff Zahos. With your help, I will be able to bring everyone to New York, and give them the compensation they deserve.

Piece.piece is an abstract dance collaged with theatrical moments. Mundane props become a visual spectacle within intricate pathways, spilling into the vestibule and surrounding area of the theater. The security guard may  have a cameo. It subtly examines theatrical etiquettes of audience and the performers. It is part poetry, part entertainment, re-enacting fragments of YouTube nature videos and instructional dances.  Like most of my work it is humorous yet poignant. 

It's been a long time since I've made a whole evening of work in New York. Gibney Dance Center has it made it possible to do piece.piece, and I am grateful. I need to raise $10,000 to fully cover the production expenses of the project. Any amount will help and adds up to our final goal. Your donations will help with these costs:

Travel expenses

Performer fees

Designer Fees

Rehearsal Fees

Post-production editing

Any money raised above $10,000 will go towards an increase in the collaborating performer fees. 

Here is how you could help in other ways:

Share this link with others.

Spread the word in social media.

https://www.facebook.com/events/1636720719933553/

Your donations are tax deductible. And finally, come see the show.

I am asking for support to fully produce piece.piece,
my newest evening-length dance, for the first time in New York City. Thanks the Gibney Dance Center's fiscal sponsorship, your donation is tax-deductible. 
Piece.piece is specifically adapted to each theater venue or environment where it's performed; New York is its second iteration. Piece.piece
will be performed at  Gibney Dance Center in New York City September 9,
10,11,12th.  
For tickets:
